Shop locally | Visit Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Shop locally System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Shop locally Whoever said that shopping can't be sustainable? Making your purchases in small shops and local shops that are committed to healthy and environmentally friendly products is a great support for both producers and local traders. In València there is a wide range of shops with these characteristics and a network of municipal markets that are true temples of kilometre 0. 19 Fri 16º 8º Made in Valencia shops Crafts , design , fashion , jewellery , and gastronomy are some of the most productive commercial sectors in Valencia. Porcelain shops such as the internationally renowned Lladró, hand-painted silk accessories by Ensedarte, handmade fans by Vibenca or Carbonell, or a piece of silverware by Peris Roca or ceramics by Ana Illueca, are exclusive gifts with all the flavour of Valencia.  As well as very tasty local products, you will find the best brands of fashion and accessories or designer souvenirs.  You can take a guided tour to be taken to the made in Valencia places that you should not miss. Shops Made in Valencia Shops Made in Valencia What to Buy in Valencia What to Buy in Valencia Going shopping in Valencia, a huge variety Going shopping in Valencia, a huge variety Municipal Markets The Central Market and those of Ruzafa , Mossen Sorell , Cabanyal and Colón are the most popular markets in Valencia and any of them is worth a visit. They are temples of seasonal and local produce and will also be a feast for your senses. Oranges, artichokes, peppers, eels, seafood, salted fish... With the market garden and the Mediterranean as direct suppliers, they are the best larder you can imagine for tasting the quality of Valencian products. Valencia Tourist Attractions | Things to see in Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Essential places in Valencia System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin TOP 10 VALENCIA We propose you the 10 essential places that you can not miss in Valencia City Of Arts and Sciences Monuments An impressive city that can be enjoyed both inside and out, whether by watching an opera or 3D IMAX film, or visiting the interactive museum or the largest aquarium in Europe. View more City Of Arts and Sciences Monuments Cathedral and Holy Grail The Cathedral is a beautiful mixture of Romanesque, Baroque and Gothic styles. The Holy Chalice is preserved inside the Cathedral and if you go up the 207 steps of the Miguelete tower you will be able to enjoy a 360º view of the city. View more Cathedral and Holy Grail La Lonja (The Silk Exchange) Unesco World Heritage This Valencian Gothic-style civil building was declared a World Heritage Site in 1996 by UNESCO and it is a surprising and essential visit when in Valencia. View more La Lonja (The Silk Exchange) Unesco World Heritage Hortensia Herrero Art Center Discover the private collection of Hortensia Herrero at the old Valeriola Palace. More than 50 internationally renowned contemporary artists. View more Hortensia Herrero Art Center Barrio del Carmen: A cocktail of history and leisure Forget about maps and venture into the labyrinthine cobbled streets of this ancient quarter that flourished between the Muslim and Christian walls. Medieval buildings, palaces, frescoes, shops and restaurants you won't be able to resist. View more Barrio del Carmen: A cocktail of history and leisure Central Market Valencian cuisine has many things to boast about and you can find them all at the Central Market, the biggest market with fresh produce in Europe full of Mediterranean flavours and aromas. View more Central Market Albufera Natural Park Nature in its purest form, dreamy sunsets, boat trips and disconnection in capital letters. Like an urban oasis surrounded by rice fields and forest: that is the Albufera Natural Park, the place where paella was invented View more Albufera Natural Park Valencia's beaches: within the city limits or wild, the choice is yours! If you like golden sands by the sea.  When you want to bathe in the sun on your towel (always with a good sunscreen) or relax under a parasol with a drink nearby... then your place in the world is the beaches of Valencia. Without doubt the best plan. View more Valencia's beaches: within the city limits or wild, the choice is yours! Valencia Aquarium Oceanografic Europe's largest aquarium: 500 marine species represented by a whopping 45,000 specimens from the most important ecosystems of each of the Earth's seas and oceans. A real tribute to marine life, with a dolphinarium and bio-educational displays. View more Valencia Aquarium Oceanografic Marina of Valencia Enjoy in your own style miles and miles of distinguished beaches with blue flags. Relax by contemplating the sea from one of the many restaurants on the promenade or from the avant-garde Veles e Vents de la Marina building. View more Marina of Valencia Turia Garden Valencia Tour it by bike or on foot and see the 18 bridges that cross it. A lush 9-kilometer garden that keeps secrets inside: the Gulliver, the Palau de la Música, the City of Arts and Science... View more Turia Garden Valencia Iglesia de San Nicolás de Bari y San Pedro Mártir de Valencia Known as the Valencian Sistine Chapel . Open your eyes wide to admire its spectacular frescoes depicting the lives of Saint Nicholas of Bari and Saint Peter Martyr — a must-visit. View more Iglesia de San Nicolás de Bari y San Pedro Mártir de Valencia Ensanche and Ruzafa Restaurants, leisure, shops and a lot of culture in the heart of Valencia. The shopping area par excellence, with many places to enjoy the gastronomy View more Ensanche and Ruzafa Ceramics Museum. Marqués de Dos Aguas Palace Discover its spectacular façade sculpted in alabaster and enter the magnificent rooms of the palace where authentic artisanal jewels from the National Museum of Ceramics await you. View more Ceramics Museum. Marqués de Dos Aguas Palace Museum of Fine Arts of Valencia Visit the second largest picture gallery in Spain, with pieces by Sorolla, Goya and Velázquez, as well as a collection of unique medieval reredos. Free entry. View more Museum of Fine Arts of Valencia Bioparc Valencia Information A little slice of Africa in Valencia. Here you can learn about the most outstanding animals, vegetation, and landscapes found in the neighbouring continent's habitats: the savannah, the forests of Equatorial Africa and Madagascar, and the wetlands. View more Bioparc Valencia Information Valencia in three days You can visit Valencia in three days! Follow us! Valencia in three days YOU MAY ALSO LIKE The best neighbourhoods for lunch and dinner The best neighbourhoods for lunch and dinner Getting around: transport, cards and season tickets Getting around: transport, cards and season tickets Valencia Areas & Neighborhood Valencia Areas & Neighborhood Barrio del Carmen and its Palaces Strolling around its streets is a complete pleasure. El Carmen neighbourhood embraces you with its maze-like streets full of history, palaces, legends and leisure. Visit Torres de Quart and Miguelete to take in the spectacular views. Sit in Plaza del Negrito and have an Agua de Valencia, a typical Valencian cocktail, then continue your walk down Calle Caballeros and you will see how El Carmen will charm you bit by bit. Once it has, it will be one of the loves of your lives. For sure. Plaza de la Virgen and the cathedral quarter Do you love history? Learn more about the origins of the Holy Grail in the heart of Valencia. Visit the ancient cathedral, feel the thrill in the Basílica de la Vírgen de los Desamparados and discover cultural treasures such as l'Almoina. Just go to Plaza de la Virgin and wander around its surroundings. Let's go! Plaza del mercado y Lonja de la Seda (Silk Exchange) Like a trip to the past where you won’t want to come back: this is how you will feel when you visit Valencia's Central Market. Located in a magnificent pre-modernist building, there are stalls serving top-quality food and a charming je ne sais quoi all around the area's markets. Just in front of the market is Lonja de la Seda, declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. It is a must when visiting Valencia, as well as Santos Juanes Church just a few metres away. Museums Valencia is also all about art. And there are 34 museums! Culture activities are always a great idea as they make us think, feel and consider life from a different perspective. Enjoy the city's history, architecture and master pieces by famous artists from different eras, such as Goya or Sorolla at the Fine Arts Museum San Pío V. Visit the delightful National Museum of Ceramics in the Palace of Marqués de Dos Aguas. If you like contemporary art, you cannot miss out on IVAM, Centre del Carme or MUVIM. Plaza del Ayuntamiento Full of light and flower shops. The Square perfectly summaries the city's essence. It is joyful and full of colour, and its central fountain is surrounded by flowers and people wanting to immortalise the moment. There are majestic buildings nearby, such as Correos, a real treasure, the Estación del Norte train station, or the Town Hall itself that is the heart from which everything flows. Gunpowder and music in Fallas, a great atmosphere all year round, horchata stalls, theatres, restaurants and... lots of charm. The Valencia's Marina and beaches It is impossible to think about the city on the River Turia without mentioning the Marina and the beaches. It is a must to take a walk around the new trendy seafaring neighbourhood, El Cabanyal. A paella overlooking the Mediterranean Sea, sunbathing (luckily the sun is out almost all year round), an ice cream or a drink with friends at such a privileged place...these are just some of the cool things you can do in Valencia. Visit the port and see the 19th-century storage facilities (Tinglados), Edificio del Reloj (Clock Building) and Veles e Vents restaurant. You will love watching the sunset on one of the bar terraces. The Albufera Nature Park One of our favourite spots is only 10 kilometres away from the city: La Albufera Natural Park. Pure nature, dreamy sunsets, boat rides and being able to completely switch off for a while. Like an oasis surrounded by rice fields and forests. You should visit it if you want to understand the origins of Valencian cuisine. It will be magical. Will you let yourself fall in love with the area? The Turia Garden Valencia's green lungs crosses the city with a 9-kilometre long garden. Welcome to the Turia Garden! The old river course from the Turia River is now a large green space full of pedestrians, cyclists and people doing sports. If we go from one end to another, not only can we see true nature in an urban setting, but we can also find great monuments, such as Palau de la Música or the City of Arts and Sciences. It is a remarkable privilege! Bioparc and Oceanogràfic Visit Africa, Japan and even the Arctic without leaving Valencia. It is all possible at Bioparc and Oceanogràfic. If you love nature and animals, you cannot miss out. Whether you are alone or with your family, you will have a great time discovering the world through its fauna. Don't miss out!

Tickets to Bioparc and the Oceanogràfic
Get 15% off with the València Tourist Card The City of Arts and Sciences When the City of Arts and Sciences was opened in 1998, it seemed like something from a sci-fi film, but it is one of Valencia's most important signature buildings. And it is inevitable that this would happen, as Santiago Calatrava's architecture is charming. Hemisfèric, Science Museum, Umbracle, Oceanogràfic, Palau de les Arts, Ágora and the Assut d’or Bridge are seven monumental buildings that make up the City of Arts and Sciences. They are so special that each one will impress you. Mestalla Stadium Tour: A Tour for the Ages Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander System messages Close popup Price What’s included Interest info Returns VLC Tourist Card discount Customer reviews Add to favorites System messages Close popup Login is required to save this product in your favourites Log in Mestalla Forever Tour (València C.F.) 4.64 5 Based on 12 reviews 10% off Valencia Tourist Card Close popup If you add a València Tourist Card to the shopping cart, you will enjoy a discount on this product Duration: 1h Digital Ticket Guide: Spanish English Every day Gate 3, Mestalla Stadium Show Less 1 Select quantity and day / 2 Check the day and time icono adulto o entrada general General From 13 years to 64 €16.10 - + You have reached the maximum number of units reducida Reduced From 5 to 12 years old. Over 65s and / or retirees, pensioners, people with disabilities, unemployed. With supporting document €13.50 - + You have reached the maximum number of units Select date Mestalla Forever Tour Valencia CF Continue Selecciona la cantidad y la fecha para continuar Add to cart Selecciona la cantidad y la fecha para continuar Go back Total: 0 € Ver selección My selection Tickets Dates/sessions Total 0 € Continue Selecciona la cantidad y la fecha para continuar Add to cart Selecciona la cantidad y la fecha para continuar What’s included The tour where you're the soccer star If you're crazy about soccer, you can't pass up this visit to one of Spain's oldest and most iconic stadiums. Put yourself in the shoes of Valencia C.F. players as you walk through the locker rooms before stepping out onto the field of the legendary Mestalla and taking your seat on the team bench. You can also visit the press room, VIP box and trophy room , and learn about the history of the Valencian club. Victory is yours! Remember that the tour is not offered on days when there is training or a game. Interest info How it works When you book, you have to specify the day and time you want to visit. We will email you the tickets so you can print them out, or download the eTickets on your phone. The guided tour lasts about an hour and is bilingual, in Spanish and English . If you suffer from reduced mobility , please write to us after your purchase at vlcshop@visitvalencia.com, so we can prepare the adapted visit . The tour leaves from gate number 3 of the Mestalla Stadium , Avda. Suecia, Valencia. We recommend arriving 15 minutes before the tour start time. Discounts and special rates There are reduced rates for children ages 5 to 12, people with disabilities, unemployed, retirees and pensioners, with supporting documentation. Admission is free for children up to 4. If you buy the ticket together with the Valencia Tourist Card, you will get 10% off. For group rates of more than 20 people, please contact vlcshop@visitvalencia.com Returns Tickets can't be cancelled or refunded, but you can request a change of date by writing to customer service at vlcshop@visitvalencia.com . You must provide at least 48 hours' notice. You can check all the information on our refund policy by clicking on the following link: Refund information VLC Tourist Card discount Discount with the Valencia Tourist Card: 10% The 10% discount is individual and non-transferable, like the Valencia Tourist Card. If you are booking the activity for more than one person and want the discount, you will need as many VTCs as people doing the activity. When buying, you will see the final price with the discount detailed in the shopping cart. Christmas markets in Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander System messages Close popup Christmas markets for your holiday shopping in Valencia. Categories: parties and traditions, Christmas. share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Featured TOURISTIC AREA: Historical center Find the most authentic markets for your Christmas shopping. At Christmas, Valencia transforms into a city filled with lights, the scent of sweets, carols, and stalls brimming with gift ideas. In its squares and streets, the Christmas markets become the perfect meeting point for those seeking charming gifts, local products, and authentic experiences . Artisans, designers, food lovers, and local traders bring the historic center to life with proposals that combine tradition, creativity, and festive spirit. From unique handmade pieces to traditional treats or classic toys, there’s a market for every kind of visitor. Here are the best Christmas markets in Valencia to enjoy the atmosphere and find that special detail that will make someone smile. 🛍️ Christmas Craft Fair 📍 Location: Plaza de la Reina 🗓️ Dates: November 28 – January 6 🕒 Opening hours: - 10:30 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. - December 24 and 31: morning only - January 5: until 10:30 p.m. A must-visit for anyone looking for 100% handmade gifts crafted by local creators. 🎁 Central Christmas Market 📍 Location: Between Calle Hospital and Avenida del Oeste 🗓️ Dates: Open daily 🕒 Opening hours: - 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. - December 24: open until 2:00 a.m. - January 5: open until 5:00 a.m. A true classic in the historic center, featuring dozens of stalls with crafts, fashion, and gastronomy that stay open late into the night. 👑 Three Kings Market 📍 Location: Around the Cabanyal Market 🗓️ Dates: January 2, 4 and 5 🕒 Opening hours: - 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. - January 5: 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Perfect for last-minute shoppers: a traditional market where you can find the final gifts before the Three Kings’ Night . 🎅 Tapinería Market – “Ho, ho, ho!” 📍 Location: Mercado de Tapinería 🗓️ Dates: December 19 – January 5 🕒 Opening hours: - Monday to Friday: 11:00 a.m.–2:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m.–8:30 p.m. - Saturdays and Sundays: 11:00 a.m.–8:30 p.m. - December 24, 31 and January 5: 11:00 a.m.–3:00 p.m. - Closed: December 25 and January 1 A unique and creative market where you can discover original gifts and independent design right in the heart of the city. 🎅 El Corte Inglés Christmas Market 📍 Location: Los Pinazo Square 🗓️ Dates: From November 25 to January 5 🕒 Opening hours: From 10:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. A wide variety of stalls offering original proposals such as the Nativity scene, Christmas decorations, or the Atelier de la Flor flower shop. As for sweets, no one will be able to resist the caramelised nuts or the classic Lindt, Nestlé and Valor products, the spectacular Sweet Shop, and the variety of Peladillas Navarro. Alongside these decoration proposals, the toy stalls for the little ones stand out, with special spaces such as Disney, and fun gifts for children at Ho Ho Ho. Enjoy Valencia’s most authentic Christmas atmosphere , support local businesses, and experience the magic of giving something made with heart. Choirs and folklore fill Valencia with music this Christmas Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander System messages Close popup Christmas Concerts in Valencia Categories: music, Christmas. share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Featured The city fills with choirs and folklore through 48 free open-air performances. This Christmas, Valencia will sound more magical than ever. From 20 December 2025 to 4 January 2026 , music will take over the city’s squares with 48 Christmas performances combining choirs, carols and traditional folklore. Half of these concerts will fill the Plaza del Patriarca, in the heart of the historic centre, with daily evening performances. But that’s not all, as there are just as many to be experienced in the neighbourhoods of Valencia, where the squares are transformed into small stages to enjoy the Christmas spirit. Find all the information here. Concerts at Plaza del Patriarca The Plaza del Patriarca will be the city centre’s Christmas focal point. A large part of the programme will take place here and every day you will have a double ration of live music. First, the choirs will perform Christmas carols and modern arrangements, and then the folklore groups will take over with Valencian rhythms, dances and melodies. 20 December At 6:00 p.m. – Agrupación Coral Jesús y María At 7:00 p.m. – Amaltea Grup de Ball 21 December At 11:00 a.m. – Pequeños Cantores de València At 12:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses Lo Rat Penat 22 December At 6:00 p.m. – OVI Coral Corremón At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses El Garbí 23 December At 6:00 p.m. – Associació Coral Increscendo de València At 7:00 p.m. – Algadins Grup de Danses 24 December At 12:00 p.m. – Coral AAACEMA 26 December At 6:00 p.m. – Orfeó Veus Juntes At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses Entitat Cultural El Piló 27 December At 6:00 p.m. – Asociación Nox Cor At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses València va de Ronda 28 December At 11:00 a.m. – Serenata Cor de Cambra At 12:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses Santa Bárbara 29 December At 6:00 p.m. – Coral Divisi Xiquets Cantors choir At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses L’Aixovar 30 December At 6:00 p.m. – Orfeón Gregorio Gea de València At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses Sargantana 2 January At 6:00 p.m. – Orfeó Manuel Palau At 7:00 p.m. – Coral Agrupación Musical Fuente de San Luis 3 January At 6:00 p.m. – Coral Stma. Trinidad de València At 7:00 p.m. – La Senyera Grup de Danses 4 January At 6:00 p.m. – Coral Polifónica Scholapiarium Cantores At 7:00 p.m. – Quiqueries Grup de Ball Concerts in neighbourhoods and districts of Valencia Christmas also arrives in Valencia’s neighbourhoods. It does so every day with free open-air performances. A choir and a folklore group will perform simultaneously in different squares, bringing the Christmas spirit to every corner of the city. From Benimaclet to Cabanyal, passing through Nazaret, Patraix and Benicalap. Here is the full schedule. 20 December At 7:00 p.m. – Coral Horta de València Sant Marcel·lí choir – Parque plaza Joaquín Dualde in Marxalenes At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses Farfalar – Plaza del Greco, 1 in Benifaraig At 7:00 p.m. – Melomans with ‘Snow Christmas’ – Plaza Emili Lluch in Patraix 21 December At 12:00 p.m. – Cor Polifònic Santa Cecilia de Castellar-Oliveral – Plaza de la Virgen de Lepanto At 12:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses La Carraspera – Plaza Llotgeta, 1 in Massarrojos At 12:00 p.m. – Jove Big Band Sedajazz with ‘Nadal en Jazz’ – Patraix 22 December At 7:00 p.m. – Coral del Centre de Música I Dansa Nazaret – Parque de Blancanieves in Quatre Carreres At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses Postisses – San Isidro – Parque Viejo San Isidro 23 December At 7:00 p.m. – Coro de Alumnos de la Escuela Oficial de Idiomas – Plaza Nueva de la Iglesia in Benicalap At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses Alimara – Plaza de la Sequiota, 14 in El Palmar 26 December At 7:00 p.m. – Coral Polifónica Valentina – Plaza de Jesús At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses del Grau – Parque Emilio Lluch in Tres Forques At 7:00 p.m. – SongAh Chae Trio. Christmas Concert – Berklee Valencia – Outside Colón Market – Entrance on C/ Jorge Juan 27 December At 7:00 p.m. – Sociedad Ateneo Musical del Puerto – Plaza Iglesia de los Ángeles in Cabanyal At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses Tomasos – Gregorio Gea, 17 in Tendetes At 7:00 p.m. – ‘Xmas Jazz/Flamenco Review – Influencias’ by Marquina-Selfa Trío feat. Kiko Berenguer – Parque de la Amistad in C/ de Iecla and pedestrian area C/ Campoamor 28 December At 12:00 p.m. – Coro de Cámara Santa María del Mar – Plaza de Benimaclet At 12:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses El Forcat – Arzobispo Olaechea, 19 in Sant Marcel·lí At 12:00 p.m. – Melòmans with ‘Snow Christmas’ – Plaza Iglesia de Sant Roc in Benicalap 29 December At 7:00 p.m. – Coro del colegio Marni choir – Ermita de San Jerónimo in Orriols At 7:00 p.m. – Rondalla Trencacordes – Plaza Doctor Ximeno, 1 in Benimàmet 30 December At 7:00 p.m. – Coro Veus de Forn d’Alcedo – Plaza del Tribunal de las Aguas in El Grau At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses Falla Obispo Amigó – Plaça Major, 19 in Pinedo At 7:00 p.m. – Cor Jove de la Comunitat Valenciana with ‘Temps de Nadal’ – Outside Colón Market – Entrance on C/ Jorge Juan 2 January At 7:00 p.m. – Coral Polifónica d’Alcàsser – Plaza Santísimo Cristo de Natzaret At 7:00 p.m. – Rondalla Segarreta – Av. Real de Madrid, 16 in La Torre At 7:00 p.m. – Dómisol Sisters perform ‘Jingle & Jazz’ – Outside Colón Market – Entrance on C/ Jorge Juan 3 January At 7:00 p.m. – Cor Cantart Divisi – Plaza Obispo Laguarda in Torrefiel At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Ball de Torrent – Plaza de la Iglesia de la Fonteta 4 January At 7:00 p.m. – Cor Ramón Ibars Mislata – Plaza de la Iglesia in Patraix At 7:00 p.m. – Grup de Danses Realenc – Plaza Simón Bolívar in Malvarrosa A total of 48 free concerts will fill Valencia with music. If you want to keep the party going, some indoor venues in the city also celebrate Christmas with their own music series. Concert series at the Mercat del Grau The inner courtyard of the Mercat del Grau will be the venue for a series of free concerts on Saturdays 13, 20 and 27 December and 3 January, always from 11:00 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. This event is designed for you to enjoy live music while you do your Christmas shopping and support local businesses. The series will feature the Valencia String Quartet , which will fill the market with melodies that fit perfectly with the Christmas atmosphere. Details Event dates From: 13-12-2025 To: 04-01-2026 Schedule info In the Plaza del Patriarca at 6:00 p.m. except on 21 and 28 December at 11:00 h and on 24 December at 12:00 p.m. In the neighbourhoods at 7:00 p.m., except on 21 and 28 December, when it will be at 12:00 p.m. At the Mercat del Grau market from 11:00 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Price Free entry. 19 Fri 16º 8º YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED ON 3rd Series of FSMCV Chamber Music Concerts in Valencia Enjoy the 3 rd Cycle of FSMCV Chamber Music Concerts at the Alquería Julià with performances on Saturdays from September to December at 12 noon. 20/12/2025

Enjoy the Nature in Valencia | Valencia Nature Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Nature Kilometers of nature and fun Mute video button Mute video button Unmute video button System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Valencia Green Breathe fresh air in Valencia Valencia boasts two million square metres of gardens. Particular highlights include the Turia Gardens , the city's green lung, the Viveros and the Botanic Garden .  Added to this vast green space are almost 20 kilometres of beaches , all of which have been awarded European Blue Flag status. The Albufera Natural Park makes the perfect setting for a rural getaway exploring the country lanes criss-crossing El Saler and the adjacent rice fields. The same is true of the Huerta Valenciana, a compendium of small farmhouses, fields and farmsteads, surrounded by the green agriculture that envelops the city. Having such a well-stocked pantry on the doorstep makes it ever easier to find restaurants offering interesting organic or zero food miles cuisine. Close to 150 kilometres of cycle paths and 40 ciclocalles (cycle-priority streets) make visiting the city on two wheels an attractive option. A public transport network comprising 46 bus routes and 9 metro lines, as well as the growth of pedestrianised areas in the city, contribute to discovering Valencia from an environmentally friendly perspective. Valencia Beaches | Visit Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Valencia Beaches System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Valencia's beaches. Kilometres and kilometres of beaches and fun Valencia's beaches: within the city limits or wild, the choice is yours! If you like golden sands by the sea. When the view, swayed by the salt water of the Mediterranean or hiding in the dunes, with a smile on your face. When you want to bathe in the sun on your towel (always with a good sunscreen) or relax under a parasol with a drink nearby. Or if you like to exercise, swim or do any kind of sport on sand, on water or in the air... then your place in the world is the beaches of Valencia. Without doubt the best plan. There are urban ones, just a stone's throw from the city centre, full of restaurants and leisure facilities and with a very wide promenade. And also in the surrounding area, right in the L'Albufera Nature Park. Listen to the sound of the waves, feel the aroma of the salt?  Open your eyes and enjoy. You have reached your destination. 20 kilometres of sand and sea Didn't you know that in Valencia there are almost 20 kilometres of beach waiting for you? Well, that's right. You just must make up your mind and come with the time to get to know them all! They are ideal for letting your adventurous vein run free, or for enjoying them more secluded and romantic. Combine swimming and hiking or enjoy a privileged climate with your favourite mascot. The beaches are close to you, like those in Cabanyal, Malvarrosa and neighbouring Patacona, where you can afford the luxury of walking to the beach if you wish. Or a little further away, in the green lung of the capital. This is the case of the beaches in El Saler, La Devesa and La Garrofera and many others. But now you can reach them all by bicycle; they are all wide, with sand between white and golden, and the sea water is of exceptional quality. It is no coincidence that all of them fly blue flags, symbol of the highest quality. A thousand possibilities are open to you to bury stress and fatigue and make "carpe diem" the leitmotif of your life: What would you like a cold drink or your snack? You did not bring a hammock or parasol? Then rent them comfortably or go to one of the kiosks. Do you accept the challenge of the beaches of Valencia? Follow us and we will show you everything. How to arrive Underground: L4, L6, L8. Valencia Airport | Closest airport to Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Valencia Airport System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Arriving by plain in Valencia The Valencia Airport, just 8 kilometers from Valencia , is connected by all types of public transportation (bus and metro). How to go from the airport to the city center En metro There are two metro lines that connect the airport to the city: Line 5 Airport/Torrent Avinguda- Neptú and Line 3 Airport / Palmaret- Rafelbunyol (Metrovalencia). About every 15-20 minutes. The ticket costs €4.80 (plus €1 for the card).  Approximate duration: 20 minutes. PRO TIP: We recommend you buy the Valencia Tourist Card, which includes all urban public transportation with no limit on trips (includes the Valencia - Airport route). It also offers valuable discounts on museums, leisure, shops, restaurants… BUY IT HERE! By City Bus The bus line that connects directly with the center of Valencia is the 150 Metrobus . The stop is located in Terminal T1, Level 0 , right outside the arrivals area and clearly signposted. This bus passes through Manises, Quart de Poblet, and Mislata before entering Valencia, where it stops at Ángel Guimerà, Mercat Central (Avenida del Oeste), and Av. Ramón y Cajal. The journey takes about 45 minutes , and the usual frequency is every 20–30 minutes . The service runs from 6:21 to 22:36, Monday to Saturday, and from 7:35 to 22:15 on Sundays. There is also a night service: it operates from Monday to Thursday every 45 minutes, and on weekends from 3:00 onwards, connecting the airport with Valencia outside daytime hours. SEE STOPS By taxi: Approximate cost by taxi from the airport to the city center: €20. CALL A TAXI : +34  96 357 13 13 By car: Access by road is from the V-11 highway, which connects the A-3 (highway from Madrid to Valencia) with the V-30. You can book your place in the airport parking lot here . Airport services It has kiosks, duty-free shops, bars and restaurants. It also has ATMs, public telephones, Wi-Fi, medical assistance and toilets adapted for disabled people. There is also a VIP lounge, located between T1 and TR, and a tourist information office , located on the Arrivals Floor. Tourist information office Located on the arrivals floor at the Manises Airport, it offers tourist information , personalized advice in different languages, comprehensive planning for your stay in the city, tickets and reservations to tourist resources at the destination, to make sure your trip is organized properly, saving you time. Car rental at the airport In total, there are nine car rental companies at the Valencia airport , seven with offices on the ground floor of the Terminal Building, while the remaining two have their drop-off and pick-up point in the T1 parking lot. Parking at the airport Manises Airport has two public parking lots located across from the T1 Building and in the vicinity of the Regional Terminal. There is also space set aside for rental cars and tour operator buses. Environmental volunteering Valencia | Visit València Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Environmental volunteering System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Environmental volunteering Participates in sustainable initiatives in Valencia València is a city that is committed to preserving the environment . There are many public and private bodies that promote ecological sustainability through voluntary actions . Their aim is to reduce waste, take care of natural spaces and educate citizens in values. Get to know these initiatives that we present you with here, there are many more and, if you feel like it and you can, collaborate with one of them. WHERE TO DO ENVIRONMENTAL VOLUNTEERING XALOC They aim to engage society as a whole in marine conservation, and to do so, they manage a network of volunteers in a variety of activities. During the summer, they manage the turtle camp to protect the nests of loggerhead turtles, which in recent years have chosen the Mediterranean coast as a nesting area. They also organise beach clean-ups and collaborate in regenerating the dunes around the El Saler Parador, in the heart of L'Albufera Natural Park, eliminating invasive species and planting native species. + INFO CRUZ ROJA Every summer, the Red Cross organises its summer campaign to prevent forest fires in the Parc de la Devesa, which is part of Albufera Natural Park. It takes place on weekends from the beginning of June to mid-September. You can register by sending an email to devesa.voluntariado@cruzroja.es or by calling (+34) 963 60 62 11 + INFO BIOAGRADABLES The BIOagradables Association is a group of volunteer environmental activists. Since 2012 their main activity has focused on organising monthly beach clean-ups, which they see as a tool for raising direct awareness of our impact on the natural environment. If you would like to be part of their action plan and start leaving the beaches spotless, let them know at info@bioagradables.org As well as this, they organise talks and workshops on environmental education for schools (primary and secondary) and lectures for the general public. + INFO YOU MAY ALSO LIKE Practise ecotourism in Valencia Practise ecotourism in Valencia Shop locally Shop locally Municipal Markets: Shrines To Locally Sourced Products Municipal Markets: Shrines To Locally Sourced Products facebook icon https://www.facebook.com/visitvalenciaSpain/ X https://twitter.com/ValenciaCity instagram https://www.instagram.com/visit_valencia/ youtube icon https://www.youtube.com/user/Turisvalencia vimeo icon https://vimeo.com/visitvalencia Icon Linkedin https://www.linkedin.com/company/turismo-valencia/ whatsapp https://api.whatsapp.com/send/?phone=34667630430&app_absent=0 Subscribe to our Newsletter! Valencia European Green Capital 2024 | Visit Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Valencia European Green Capital 2024 Mute video button Mute video button Unmute video button System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Valencia, European Green Capital 2024 Valencia invites you to celebrate another important recognition of the city's commitment to sustainability: its election as European Green Capital 2024. This distinction, awarded by the European Commission, recognizes the city's efforts to improve the environment and the quality of life of its residents and visitors alike. It takes into account factors such as the numerous green spaces and sustainable mobility initiatives that can be enjoyed in the city, and that we invite you to discover on your visit. 19 Fri 16º 8º Green Routes DISCOVER THEM GREEN CAPITAL EVENTS A green city You can feel Valencia's green credentials as soon as you arrive. You just have to see the number of gardens and green spaces where you can escape from the urban bustle and enjoy nature without leaving the city... almost five million square meters of green areas ! We won't ask you to visit them all, but some you really should see. Start with the Jardín del Turia , an impressive nine-kilometer route of gardens and sports and leisure spaces that crosses the city where the Turia River once flowed. Then explore hidden spots for a romantic stroll, such as the Jardín de Monforte, or new esplanades recently added to the urban landscape, such as the Parque Central, with more than 100,000 square meters of land. Valencia is home to gardens for all tastes. Choose your favorite! Turia Garden Valencia Turia Garden Valencia Parks and Gardens Parks and Gardens Route of the monumental trees Route of the monumental trees Parque Central Parque Central A city with two natural parks Valencia not only has multiple green spaces in the urban center, but also two natural parks on its periphery that are easily accessible by public transportation or bicycle. The Parque Natural de l’Albufera is a veritable oasis just half an hour away from the city, not only for people but also for the thousands of birds that frequent its important wetlands every year. You can explore its different ecosystems on foot or by bike, or on a relaxing boat ride, and top it all off with a traditional Valencian paella among the rice fields that gave birth to this dish. Going up the course of the Turia River you will find the Turia Natural Park , more than 8,000 hectares of Mediterranean forest, which you can explore on foot, by bike or on horseback. In the warmer months, it is the ideal space to take shelter in the shade of the pines or take a dip in its natural pools. If you want to dive even deeper into the nature of the province, a short distance away you will find true natural paradises , such as the small villages that make up two Biosphere Reserves, or Starlight destinations from which to contemplate the universe with no light pollution. Albufera Natural Park Albufera Natural Park Turia Nature Park: Valencia’s green corridor Turia Nature Park: Valencia’s green corridor Trails in Valencia's L'Albufera Trails in Valencia's L'Albufera Biosphere Reserves: earthly paradises just an hour away from the city Biosphere Reserves: earthly paradises just an hour away from the city Starlight Destinations in Valencia: an astronomical experience Starlight Destinations in Valencia: an astronomical experience The world's breadbasket Valencia is home to another green space of transcendental importance not only to Valencia, but to the whole world: the Huerta . Surrounding the city are 120 km2 of fertile vegetable and fruit farms whose produce is not only exported, but supplied to local markets and restaurants. You are guaranteed to enjoy authentic local cuisine in Valencian restaurants, with seasonal products that have barely any environmental footprint. It's one of the reasons the city was named Capital of Sustainable Urban Food in 2017. In addition to tasting delicious dishes in its restaurants, be sure to visit the Mercado Central or one of the other municipal markets in Valencia to get the freshest products, whether as a snack on the spot or to take home. Discover the orchard: The Valencian pantry with its own name Discover the orchard: The Valencian pantry with its own name Municipal Markets: Shrines To Locally Sourced Products Municipal Markets: Shrines To Locally Sourced Products Valencia, model for food sustainability Valencia, model for food sustainability Mobility that leaves no trace Transportation is also green in Valencia. Not only can you get around the city easily using mass transit, but, even better, you can do so by bike. With over 200 kilometers of bike lanes and practically flat terrain, riding on two wheels through the city is a pleasure, and the most sustainable way to get to all its landmarks. If you don't like pedaling, you can also enjoy 94 km2 of pedestrian areas , including the new spaces in Plaza de la Reina, Plaza del Ayuntamiento and Plaza de Brujas, between the Mercado Central and La Lonja. Reduce emissions as you get around in Valencia Reduce emissions as you get around in Valencia Getting around: transport, cards and season tickets Getting around: transport, cards and season tickets Cycling in Valencia Cycling in Valencia Your contribution to an even greener Valencia We can all do our bit to help keep Valencia a green city, even after its year as European Green Capital, and help combat climate change . In addition to being able to move around sustainably, you will find many other ways to reduce your carbon footprint and be a responsible tourist ; for example, by minimizing waste, supporting the economy and local communities with your purchases and consumption, or taking part in ecotourism activities. 3 Days in Valencia | What to See in 3 days in Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander 3 Days in Valencia System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin 3 days in Valencia You can visit Valencia in three days! Follow us! If you only have three days in which to visit Valencia, you can take a basic tour without missing any of the most important sights. We’ll tell you where to go, so you can get the most out of your visit. Before we start, it’s a good idea to organise your visit using all of the city information and practical documentation available. Download the ' Visit València in 3 Days ' Guide to discover recommendations on where to eat, what to see and do, get the best city maps, and explore interesting tourist routes The easiest and most affordable way to get around València is with the València Tourist Card , offering unlimited transport for 24, 48, or 72 hours . Plus, enjoy free entry to municipal museums and monuments , up to 50% discount on top attractions and many shops in València, and a free tapa with a drink DAY 1 HISTORIC CENTRE Discover the historic city centre and its rich artistic heritage. You can visit the genuine Holy Grail at Valencia Cathedral; the Silk Exchange, a jewel of Gothic civil architecture; the Central Market, one of the largest and finest purveyors of fresh produce in Europe; the spectacular frescoes at the Church of San Nicolás; and many other breathtaking sites. In the afternoon, head to the City of Arts and Sciences, where you can discover the secrets of science at the Science Museum, explore the seabed at the Oceanogràfic, or take in a film at the Hemisfèric. If you have any time left over, you can enjoy a pleasant stroll through the Turia Gardens, which stretch for 8.5 kilometres along the bed of the diverted river. You can enjoy a trip in a traditional fishing boat and savour a Valencian paella in its genuine place of origin. In the afternoon, transport yourself to the African savannah with a trip to Valencia’s Bioparc! If you're visiting in summer, the park is open until 20:00. In winter, it’s open until 18:00. Going shopping en València | Shopping Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Shopping in Valencia A city where you can have fun shopping Mute video button Mute video button Unmute video button System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Enjoy shopping in Valencia Are you a shopaholic? If shopping is your thing, you'll find plenty of choices in Valencia. You’re not? Well, even if you're one of those people who get bored shopping, we challenge you to try Valencia! Of course, here you will find the main national and international brands , big shopping centres and shopping areas . But Valencia has many other hidden surprises for you... Cutting-edge proposals from Valencian designers , small craft workshops, alternative and vintage shops, typical products ... take the opportunity to buy unique clothes and souvenirs that everyone will be green with envy of. There is also the charm of the street markets, the traditional stalls in the Plaza Redonda , architectural gems like the Mercado de Colón , or the atmosphere of places like the Mercado de Tapinería , where you can always take a break for some tapas. Shopping in Valencia is a real joy! We make it easy for you: Shopping Long opening hours In general, shops are open from 10am to 9pm from Monday to Saturday, and even on Sundays in central areas, although with reduced opening hours. Plenty of time for shopping! Descuento estrella Fantastic bargains Take advantage of the sales from 7 January to the end of February, and from 1 July to 31 August, as well as special offers in many shops. Where to Eat Paella in València | Paella Experience Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Paella Experience Search Submit València Tourist Card Guided tours Offers Tickets Science city & Oceanogràfic Experiences System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Would you like to try an authentic Valencian paella? Paella is Valencia's most international dish and Albufera Natural Park is the true home of paella. In this natural setting you'll find Restaurante El Palmar, located in El Palmar, where, as well as enjoying an authentic Valencian paella made with ingredients from the market gardens surrounding this wetland, you can also take a boat trip on one of the traditional vessels known as "albuferencs". While you're there, we recommend you try to catch one of the spectacular sunsets from among the rice fields. Sustainable Tourism in Valencia | Ecotourism in Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Sustainable Tourism in Valencia System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Make your visit more sustainable Valencia is an increasingly accessible, intelligent, and sustainable city. Committed to the Sustainable Development Goals, it is a pioneer in the world in measuring and certifying the carbon footprint of its tourist activity in search of actions to reduce and offset it. If you are one of those travellers who is concerned about the protection of cultural and natural heritage, respectful of and feeling responsible for the destination you visit, in Valencia you will find various initiatives that will help your holiday have the least possible impact. Discover the city while taking care of the planet! The challenge is great, but as the writer Eduardo Galeano said, "many small people, in small places, doing small things, can change the world".  Shall we get started? Information Bioparc Spain | Valencia Bioparc Opening Times Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Bioparc Valencia Information Avenida Pío Baroja 3, 46015 - València TOURISTIC AREA: Bioparc and Cabecera park BIOPARC VALENCIA, A NEW GENERATION ZOO Congolese Gorillas, Madagascan Lemurs, Savannah Lions and Nile Hippos. There are close to a thousand animals of 150 different African species at Valencia’s Bioparc, with specially designed habitats to ensure their utmost well-being and comfort. Here the barriers are practically invisible. It aims to give visitors the chance to experience the African continent, and learn the importance of protecting natural environments. Situated in Cabecera Park, within the former Turia riverbed, the Bioparc covers an area of over 100,000 m2 and is divided into four main areas . In the dry Savannah you can find rhinoceros, zebras, ostriches and hyenas, while the Wetlands house giraffes, antelopes, gazelles, meerkats and lions. The perfectly recreated baobab forest is home to a dozen elephants, one of the largest groups of the species in Spain. The island of Madagascar is certainly worth a visit as you are able to get up close and personal with the lemurs, who often climb down the branches of the trees to greet you. A re-creation of the Kitum cave is home to hippopotamus and crocodiles. In the forests of Equatorial Africa, visitors will encounter pythons, otters, leopards and gorillas , one of the park’s biggest attractions. The Bioparc’s many rivers are full of fish. There is also has an amphitheatre, with a capacity of 1,000 people, offering displays of birds and marine mammals. Th e family leisure zone boasts an indoor restaurant, with a large outdoor terrace overlooking the African savannah. The complex first opened its doors in 2008 and there are long term expansion plans for both Asian and American habitats. The park is open 365 days a year from 10:00 to 18:00. From April to September opening hours are extended to 20:00 and 21:00. Ticket offices close half an hour before park closing time, but tickets can also be purchased by phone or online. Ticket prices are 23,80 euros for adults and 18 euros for children (under the age of 12). BOOK ONLINE Details Schedule info OPENING TIMES:​ The Bioparc is open 365 days a year and its opening hours will change depending on the daylight hours in the different months of the year. The tickets offices will remain open from 10am until 1 hour before the Bioparc closes. Winter and autumn: from 10am to 6pm Summer and spring: 10am to 8pm Consult the opening times here BIOPARC A piece of Africa in Valencia Buy your ticket here! Cruises from Valencia| VisitValencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Cruises from Valencia System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Cruises from Valencia Arriving in València by sea, watching how the city slowly takes shape, spotting the silhouette of the Veles e Vents building and, with a bit of luck, crossing paths with the fishing boats that return to port every day at four in the afternoon, is one of the best ways to approach the city. So, why not do it on a cruise? Two companies depart regularly from the Port of València, the perfect excuse to come or stay a few more days to get to know the city in depth . València is an embarkation port for two of the main cruise lines in the Mediterranean: Costa Cruises and MSC Cruises. Both companies include the city in their routes and offer regular departures with different ships throughout the year. The itineraries and destinations vary each season, allowing travellers to enjoy multiple options to explore the Mediterranean starting directly from València. Since 2023, València is one of the airports offering direct flights from Spain for itineraries in Northern Europe departing from Hamburg, and in the Western Mediterranean with departures from Venice. The fly & cruise service allows travellers to choose itineraries that start far from their location at a more affordable price, offering a more comfortable and flexible way to travel for passengers. Other cruise lines also call at València , such as Royal Caribbean, Azamara Cruises, Aidacruises, Silversea, Viking Cruises, Norwegian Cruise Lines, Celebrity Cruises, Seabourn Cruises… You can check all cruises that pass through the Port of València here . THE VERY BEST WELCOME The cruise port of Valencia is 4.5 km from the city centre. Taxis will take you wherever you wish to go or bus lines will take you to the city’s historic centre or to the Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias. If your cruise berths at the docks known as Cruceros 1 or Cruceros 2 , there is an internal free shuttle to the Transmediterránea terminal. GET THE BEST OUT OF YOUR VISIT If you want to discover the city on your own, buy the 24-hour Valencia Tourist Card . With this card, you will have unlimited access to public transport, free entrance to museums and municipal monuments and discounts on other tourist attractions, shops, restaurants and tourist services.You can also use the Tourist Bus to get to know the essence of València in a few hours and in comfort. What to do in València | Things to do in València Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Things to do in València System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Things to do in València Discover the main things to do in València and the touristic areas of the city Are you going on a getaway and still don't know what are you going to do in València? You won’t get enough of this Mediterranean city, with more than 2,000 years of history, green spaces, various museums, historic buildings, lively squares with terraces to enjoy the sun, not to forget the long sandy beaches... The list is long, but here’s a selection of the essential things you need to do in Valencia. It begins with a view of the historic centre and its rich artistic heritage. You can see the Holy Grail in the Cathedral; the Silk Exchange (Lonja de la seda), a jewel of civil Gothic; the Central Market , one of the most alive and appetizing in Europe; the ancient Roman ruins in the Almoina Museum , or go up to contemplate an unbeatable panoramic view of the city from the Miguelete or the Torres de Serranos . Another must see, is the City of Arts and Sciences . We recommend you to combine it with a bike ride along the old course of the River Turia . The Turia Garden crosses the entire city, with the Cabecera Park and Bioparc at one end and the City of Arts and Sciences at the other, and more than eight kilometres of gardens to cover on your walk. Also, you can’t miss enjoying a good Paella by the beach. Nine kilometres of fine sand and a stone's throw from the centre. The beaches of València are waiting for you! You have the urban beaches of El Cabañal and La Malvarrosa , in the area of Poblados Marítimos, next to the famous neighbourhood of El Cabañal. A little further north continues the beach of Patacona, and to the south follow the beaches of Pinedo, La Devesa and El Saler, in the Natural Park of L'Albufera. All of them have a blue flag, are accessible by public transport and have good restaurants to enjoy the gastronomy of the area. And if you still have time, there are many things to see in Valencia. The city has more than 30 museums for everyone, from Fine Arts to Lead Soldiers, Science and IVAM. In addition, you must have to try the authentic Valencian horchata or a good hot chocolate with churros. The Colón Market, the Plaza de la Reina or the Plaza de la Virgen have good establishments for this and are also very atmospheric and interesting places to visit in Valencia. Don't think about it anymore and visit Valencia. 19 Fri 16º 8º WHAT TO SEE IN VALÈNCIA The complete guide to València to know what to see and do in València 10 Essential places to visit 10 Essential places to visit You can visit Valencia in three days! Valencia NightClubs | Valencia Night Out Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Valencia By Night System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Nightlife in Valencia There are hundreds of options to have a great time Valencia’s nightlife offering is very diverse and lasts all year thanks to the good climate. At the weekend, which is when there is more atmosphere, the bustle starts after dinner and can go on until the early hours of the morning because, although pubs close at 3.30am, clubs are open until 7.30am. So, if you are looking to party, this is your city (but don’t get too carried away, please). Join us for a tour from area to area to see which one suits you best!! El Carmen Right in the historic centre, the area of el Carmen is the liveliest. We recommend sitting at a terrace in Plaza Negrita, el Tossal or el Doctor Collado to spend the evening clinking glasses or walking around the back streets until you find the perfect place to have some tapas. Other typical things to do in el Carmen include drinking Agua de Valencia in Café de las Horas bar, listening to live jazz in the Jimmy Glass bar or dancing until the morning at Radio City. Ruzafa neighbourhood The area of Ruzafa, in L’Eixample, is the most alternative of the city. Here, you can mix with the most modern Valencians in restaurants like Canalla Bistró, Dos Estaciones or Nozomi Sushi Bar. Are you looking for culture? Explore the interesting alternative cultural route in Ruzafa at the Ubik book shop or the Espai Tactel gallery. If what you want is to dance, great music awaits you in the small bars or clubs such as Oven and Play. Marina de Valencia The Marina is an eclectic zone that is especially lively during the summer months. The Marina Beach Club, with a swimming pool right by the sea, is the place to be seen. The Fábrica de Hielo is a place to have a drink in a more relaxed atmosphere. If you want to let yourself go more, then the La 3 club on Avenida Blasco Ibáñez is for you. City of Arts and Science If you are looking for something more sophisticated, the City of Arts and Sciences is your place. From June to September, L’Umbracle is transformed into the most beautiful terrace in the city and, if you are looking for more of a party, you only have to go downstairs to the famous club, Mya. There are also many well-known bars on the nearby streets like 48 and On The Rocks. Other areas But nightlife in Valencia doesn’t end there. If you go to other areas of the city looking to party, you’ll find that on Thursdays the student nightlife is at Benimaclet, Plaza Xúquer, Honduras and el Cedro, and that the older audience (who still want to have a good time) often go out near Calle Juan Llorens, Avendia de Aragón or Plaza Cánovas. Jubilee Year of the Holy Chalice | València celebrates the Jubilee Year Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Valencia City of the Holy Grail Mute video button Mute video button Unmute video button City of the Grail Jubilee Year The Holy Chalice History Chapel Guided tour System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Valencia, city of the Holy Grail One of Christianity’s most venerated relics, the Holy Grail , has been kept since 1437 in Valencia Cathedral, where it inspires devotion and admiration in the chapel that has housed it since 1916. The cup that may have been used by Jesus Christ at the Last Supper arrived in the city in 1432 after a long historical journey. València, then immersed in a period of cultural and economic splendour, provided the perfect setting to welcome such a precious symbol of faith. Third Holy Grail Jubilee Year It will take place from October 30, 2025, to October 29, 2026, and visitors can receive plenary indulgence, a privilege reserved for such exceptional occasions. DISCOVER MORE Third Holy Grail Jubilee Year Valencia and the Holy Grail: history, art, and spirituality Discover the ancient origin of the relic, its details, its chapel, and the routes that connect faith and culture in the heart of the city. Holy Grail Visitors Centre Visit the Holy Grail Centre at the Almudín in València, a unique exhibition about the history, art, and faith surrounding this relic. How to Get to Valencia | Getting to Valencia (Spain) Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander How to get to Valencia System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin To get to Valencia Valencia is accessible by air, land and sea. It boasts travel links to many major Spanish and European cities. The airport , situated just 8 kilometres from the centre of Valencia, has regular daily flights to popular domestic and international destinations. The city also has two main railway stations , the Estación del Norte, from which the local train network operates, and Joaquín Sorolla, offering AVE high-speed rail services to Madrid, Cuenca, Seville and Córdoba. ALVIA and EUROMED long-distance trains also depart from Joaquín Sorolla, providing connections to cities including Barcelona. Valencia is home to one of the most important commercial ports in the Mediterranean. The port , which operates passenger services to both the Balearic Islands and Italy, is fast becoming a popular destination for cruise ships, which dock at Poniente Pier, enabling passengers to spend a few hours exploring the city.  For those travelling by car, Valencia is equipped with a modern motorway network making it easily accessible from any city on the mainland. These include the AP-7, which runs north to south along the Mediterranean coast connecting the city with Barcelona, and the A-3 running from Valencia to Madrid. Valencia Tourist Card Unlimited transportation, free admission to many museums and more discounts Buy it here INFORMATION OF INTEREST: Valencia Airport : 8 km from the centre. Metro (lines 3 and 5), bus (line 150) or taxi (approx €20 for the journey) Joaquin Sorolla AVE High Speed Train Station :​ 1 km from the centre. Metro (lines 1 and 5), free bus to the centre and taxi rank. Bus 64. Bus (lines 4, 30, 95) and taxi rank. Ferry trips to Ibiza, Mahón and Palma de Mallorca Cruise Port : 6 km from the centre. There is an internal shuttle service at the port which takes passengers to the main terminal. Tourism news in Valencia | Visit Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander What's new in Valencia News Name Start date End date Search System messages Close popup Valencia inaugurates the Visitor Reception Centre of the Holy Grail 21 Oct 2025 Valencia has inaugurated the new Visitor Reception Centre of the Holy Grail , a new welcome and information point during the 3rd Jubilee Year of the cup, which will begin next Thursday, 30 October. READ MORE Valencia inaugurates the Visitor Reception Centre of the Holy Grail Valencia city image gallery Register to get access to the best Valencia city images Credits: visitvalencia.com IMAGE MANAGER Valencia city image gallery Why València should be your next destination Download the free guide! DOWNLOAD Why València should be your next destination New reasons to travel to Valencia in 2026 08 Oct 2025 The city celebrates the Third Jubilee Year of the Holy Chalice and inaugurates new spaces that enrich its cultural offer. Green will be the color of the year with original urban gardens, the XII Gay Games will arrive with a message of inclusion, and the Valencian sky will offer a unique spectacle with the total solar eclipse of August. READ MORE New reasons to travel to Valencia in 2026 Valencia opens a new natural collections museum: El Paleontològic 29 Jul 2025 The city of Valencia inaugurates El Paleontològic – Museum of Natural Collections, embracing interactivity and cutting-edge technology to transform the former Museum of Natural Sciences into a pioneering center for scientific dissemination. The museographic approach aims to turn each visitor into an active explorer through key innovations: READ MORE Valencia opens a new natural collections museum: El Paleontològic Valencia Will Open a Museum Dedicated to Sorolla in 2026 25 Jul 2025 Next year, Valencia will add a new center to its museum offerings where 220 works by Joaquín Sorolla can be admired. Sorolla is the most internationally recognized Valencian painter, known for capturing Mediterranean light like no one else. The new museum will be located in the Palacio de las Comunicaciones, situated in the Plaza del Ayuntamiento, right in the city center. READ MORE Valencia Will Open a Museum Dedicated to Sorolla in 2026 Valencia, the source of modern chess for 550 years. 06 Jun 2025 Three Valencian poets from the 15th century were the first to describe the movement of the queen piece in chess in the poem Scachs d’amor (1475), thus establishing the rules of modern chess. Two decades later, another Valencian author published the new rules of the game in one of his works, which spread across Europe thanks to an exceptional ally: the printing press. READ MORE Valencia, the source of modern chess for 550 years. 21 sea turtles born in València return to the sea at El Saler beach 05 Jun 2025 El Saler beach became the setting this morning for the release of 21 young sea turtles (loggerhead sea turtles). They have been cared for over the past year at the Oceanogràfic of València as part of the Head Starting conservation programme, promoted by its Foundation. READ MORE 21 sea turtles born in València return to the sea at El Saler beach Valencia renews its 7 Blue Flags and ensures safe and high-quality beaches for this summer 08 May 2025 Valencia's beaches once again fly the 7 Blue Flags this summer, certifying their excellence in quality, safety, sustainability, and services. Despite the effects of the last DANA that affected part of the Valencian coast in the autumn, the cleaning and recovery efforts have been effective, and the beaches are fully prepared to welcome both locals and tourists. READ MORE Valencia renews its 7 Blue Flags and ensures safe and high-quality beaches for this summer Valencia welcomes new spaces of luxury, design and flavor 06 May 2025 Valencia continues to establish itself as a destination for discerning travelers eager for new experiences. The Grand Hotel Centenari Valencia, Autograph Collection, a luxurious five-star hotel, has just opened its doors in the iconic Telefónica Building (1928), right in the heart of Plaza del Ayuntamiento. READ MORE Valencia welcomes new spaces of luxury, design and flavor Valencia celebrates Las Fallas 2025 13 Jan 2025 Valencia is beginning to feel the build-up to Las Fallas 2025 , which has been declared an Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity event and is widely considered to epitomise Valencian culture. READ MORE Valencia celebrates Las Fallas 2025 New reasons to visit Valencia in 2025 03 Dec 2024 Valencia's European Green Capital legacy is clear for all to see. Projects that reinforce the city's commitment to sustainability and restaurants distinguished for their dedication to local produce join the celebration of the Jubilee Year of the Holy Chalice and new openings that promise a very appetising and fun agenda for 2025. Valencia Areas | Best areas to stay in Valencia Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Valencia Areas & Neighborhood System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Neighbourhoods and areas in Valencia Discover the most charming neighbourhoods and areas in Valencia Valencia is an amazing city full of life, with a Mediterranean atmosphere and fascinating spots all over the 19 districts that are subdivided into 88 neighbourhoods. Here you can find a guide on the most notable neighbourhoods in the city, organised into 6 areas so you can plan your time and not miss out on anything. See the map with the most interesting neighbourhoods and areas to visit in Valencia so you can enjoy a complete experience in the city . Historic Centre Valencia has one of the oldest historic centres in Europe. The city has over 2000 years of profound history and a rich artistic heritage; therefore, it is a must see. Both La Lonja and the Water Tribunal, which meets every Thursday at the Cathedral's Door of the Apostles, are part of the prestigious UNESCO World Heritage Site list, as well as the local festivity, Fallas, which takes place in March. The list of essential visits in the historic centre is long, with treasures such as the Cathedral and the Holy Chalice, the Central Market, the frescoes in the Church of San Nicolás, the Torres de Serranos, Plaza Redonda or the Palace of Marqués de Dos Aguas, among others. You will need a full day to see them all. VIEW MORE Alameda, City of Arts and Oceanogràfic As it is a large area of the city, the best way to discover it all is on foot or by bike through the Turia Garden and see the 18 bridges that cross them. You can start at Alameda with the Viveros and Monforte Gardens and the Museum of Fine Arts, a spectacular classical picture gallery. Afterwards, you can then move on to the old Turia river bed, where you can visit the City of Arts and Sciences, Puente de la Exposición and Palau de la Música. We recommend you take a full day to visit all of the above, as visiting the Oceanogràfic and the rest of the City of Arts and Sciences will take approximately 5 hours. VIEW MORE The Marina, beaches and the Cabañal neighbourhood This area is ideal to enjoy Valencian cuisine with a sea breeze and spectacular views. The Valencia Marina is a famous area with plenty of space to walk, ride a bike, enjoy the local cuisine and do water sports. The Cabañal and Malvarrosa beaches, the promenade and the Cabañal seafaring neighbourhood area trendy areas due to their lifestyle. It is a large area with a varied leisure and cuisine offer, therefore we recommend you take your time when visiting it. You can go for a swim at the beach, ride a bike, try a Valencian paella and enjoy the lively atmosphere on the terraces next to the beach. VIEW MORE Albufera Natural Park The Albufera Natural Park is only 10 kilometres from the city. It is a Mediterranean ecosystem with a combination of wild dune beaches, pine forests, rice fields and a huge freshwater lake. You don't need a car to reach it, bus number 25 takes you straight there or you can take the Albufera Bus Turistic for a panoramic visit. In order to learn more about the area's biodiversity, take a boat ride on the lake's calm water or take a bike ride or stroll along one of the six marked routes in the park. Paella was invented in this area, so why not try one? You can also discover other local culinary delights, such as all-i-pebre or llisa adobada. We recommend you spend at least 6 hours on this visit in order to take a boat ride, discover a part of the park and try some of the local cuisine. VIEW MORE Bioparc and Parque de Cabecera At the other end of the Turia Garden, to the west of the city, one of the largest green areas in Valencia, Parque de Cabecera, can be found. You can visit a small part of Africa in the ecosystems recreated by Bioparc Valencia, with species and vegetation from the African savannah, forests from equatorial Africa and Madagascar, as well as wetlands. Bioparc will take 3 hours to visit. It could be longer if you walk around Parque de Cabecera or go out on a pedal boat in the lake. VIEW MORE Ensanche and Ruzafa Ensanche has a great amount of modernist architectural treasures and is the best shopping area in the city. Ruzafa is also a great area known as the Valencian "soho". Plan your visit and enjoy the best shops, cuisine and lively atmosphere at the Colon Market, as well as other alternative shops and galleries in the Ruzafa neighbourhood. Famous Valencian chefs have chosen this area to open resturants, such as Habitual or Canalla Bistró by Ricard Camarena, Mercatbar by Quique Dacosta or RiFF by Bernd Knöller. VIEW MORE ​ Neighbourhoods and touristic areas: Old Town Alameda, Ciutat de les Arts and Oceanogràfic Marina, beaches and Cabañal Albufera Natural Park Bioparc and Cabecera Park Ensanche and Ruzafa 19 Fri 16º 8º YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN You can visit Valencia in three days! The Mestalla Forever Tour opens the doors to the oldest stadium in LaLiga and one of Spain’s most historic football temples. Whether you’re a loyal Valencia CF supporter or simply love the beautiful game, this experience is unique: Step onto the pitch where your idols play. Visit the team’s locker rooms. Sit on the bench like a real ché player. And that’s not all: Explore the trophy room and relive the club’s greatest moments. Feel the tension of a press conference in the official press room. Discover the stories and secrets that have made Mestalla legendary. The guided tour lasts about 1 hour and is conducted simultaneously in Spanish and English. Book your ticket now and experience Mestalla from the inside. Amunt València! Valencia city centre turns into a Christmas park Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander System messages Close popup What to do in Valencia this Christmas: ice rink, train and carousel Categories: with children, Christmas. share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin Featured TOURISTIC AREA: Historical center Enjoy the magic of Christmas in the city centre. From 28 November 2025 to 6 January 2026 , Valencia will be filled with Christmas activities that you won’t want to miss. Yes! The Association of Shopkeepers in the Old Town and Ensanche district will once again transform the streets into the city’s best Christmas park, with activities to enjoy with your family or group of friends. Staying at home is not an option this year. Three must-see experiences are waiting for you here, the ice rink, the classic carousel and the retailers’ train, which are joined by two new additions: Alice in Wonderland Train and the Children’s Ferris Wheel in Plaza de San Agustín. Ice rink – Plaza del Ayuntamiento – 1 Divertivale + €7 or €10 Put on your skates and enjoy the winter without leaving the centre of Valencia with a 30-minute session on ice and under the Christmas lights of the City Hall. Don’t forget to bring your gloves! DATES AND TIMES From 28 November 2025 to 6 January 2025. Monday to Sunday from 11:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. (ticket office closes and last show at 10:00 p.m.). 24 and 31 December from 11:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. (last admission at 7:00 p.m.). Classic carousel – Plaza del Ayuntamiento – €4 Hop on the horses of this vintage-style merry-go-round that will delight both young and old alike. DATES AND TIMES Until 22 December: Monday to Friday from 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. and from 4:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. Saturdays, Sundays, and public holidays from 11:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. From 23 December to 6 January: every day from 11:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. 24 and 31 December from 11:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Shopping Train – Departure from C/ Roger de Lauria – 1 Divertivale or €3 Take the most entertaining train of Christmas and travel through the streets of the historic centre on five different routes without getting tired. DATES AND TIMES December: 6, 7, 8, 13, 14, 20, 21, 22, 23, 26, 27, 28, 29 and 30 January: 2, 3, 4 and 5. You can choose from departures between 11:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. here , so there’s no excuse not to come for a ride. Alice in Wonderland Train and Children’s Ferris Wheel – Plaza de San Agustín The fantasy of “Alice in Wonderland” also takes centre stage in Valencia with a train that will delight the little ones. And if you’re left wanting more, you can complete the experience with a ride on the Children’s Ferris Wheel, a colourful attraction with spectacular views of the square. DATES AND TIMES Until 22 December: Monday to Friday from 5:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays from 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. and from 3:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. From 23 December to 6 January: Monday to Sunday from 11:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. 24 and 31 December from 11:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Do you want to get Divertivales? The Divertivales are the gift that the shops in the centre give you for your Christmas shopping. To get them, simply redeem your tickets at Plaza del Ayuntamiento (next to the ice rink ticket office) or on Roger de Lauria Street (next to the shopping train), and you’re all set! Skate, laugh, take a train ride, ride the Ferris wheel and experience a fairytale Christmas in Valencia. Valencia, the best city to study in Spain Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Valencia, study destination Study in Valencia Schools and universities Requirements to study Tips for students Learning Spanish Housing for students System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin VALENCIA, THE BEST CHOICE It is considered one of the top 100 university destinations in the world by the QS Best Student Cities ranking, which rates it as affordable and desirable. If you're looking for a practical, dynamic city with quality of life and a prime location, Valencia is the place for you. Why Valencia? You'll soon find out why it attracts over 3,000 international students annually. alquiler de bicicleta Accessible Connected by land, sea and air, it has an excellent public transportation network and a bicycle path that connects all neighborhoods and student areas through the metro, tram, bus or bicycle. Guías turísticos oficiales Affordable Valencia is the third largest city in Spain, after Madrid and Barcelona, but its cost of living is much lower compared to them and most European destinations. Playas Warm Because the sun shines almost year-round. It has an average temperature of 19 degrees, six months of beach season, 135 kilometers of coastline, extensive green areas and delicious Mediterranean cuisine. Ocio en Valencia Lifestyle Diverse, open and welcoming, day and nightlife are equally intense here. It has an unbeatable variety of leisure and cultural experiences to enjoy. EDUCATIONAL SERVICES AND ACCOMMODATIONS Valencia offers a wide range of multilingual training, provided by leading and prestigious public and private institutions. It also offers a wide variety of lodging options for all tastes and budgets. Museums and Monuments | What to see in València Skip to main content EN Language selector es en nl fr de it va 0 Search button Search Submit Search Close Mobile menu expander Museums and Monuments in València System messages Close popup share whatsapp facebook twitter linkedin MUSEUMS AND MONUMENTS TO SEE IN VALÈNCIA Valencian culture is part of the essence of the people, displayed in over 60 cultural spaces including museums, monuments, and multidisciplinary spaces. Valencia is rich in history, as well as in the production of arts and crafts, which is why it is possible to find contemporary art museums, guild museums, museums with Gothic works or hidden treasures such as the revered Holy Chalice or Santo Cáliz. All of these are located in eclectic and interesting architectural spaces, from the Gothic to the latest and most modern architectural trends. Discovering them is to discover the heart and soul of Valencian culture.
