Safety | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Add to my trip Print Share Safety Photo : Martin Heiberg Copenhagen is in general a safe city to visit. But just like in any other city, you should take certain precautions. Safety in general In addition to following the official travel guidelines of your own national authorities, you can consult Danish Police here . Christiania The area is loved by many but has been a turning point for strong debate due to illegal drug dealings, which have also been subject to safety concerns for visitors. The community and authorities have worked together to improve safety and address criminal activities. (Danish legislation prohibits the dealing, buying, and possessing of illegal substances). On April 6, 2024, the residents of Christiania took a significant step by digging up the cobblestones on “Pusher Street”. This act was a symbolic gesture to mark the end of the open drug market in the area. It is advised not to search out Christiania for any sort of illegal substances. Pickpockets love distractions Photo : Thomas Rousing Around Copenhagen Central Station you should pay extra attention to pickpockets. The area around City Hall Square and the beginning of Strøget (the pedestrian street) is very busy, and also an area to be aware of thieves. Each summer, Copenhagen Municipality, in collaboration with Copenhagen Police, run a campaign warning against pickpockets. They use a variety of distractions and tactics to relieve victims of their personal items. Please ask yourself the following questions: Are you aware of your valuables in a crowd? Are your phone and money safely stored? When you pay with a card, do you always cover your pin code? Crowded areas Strøget , City Hall Square and Gothersgade can be crowded areas by night – especially during weekends. Fake police On a few rare occasions, tourists have been scammed by fake police officers. The victims have either paid on-the-spot fines for "breaking the law" or have been frisked and unknowingly robbed. If contacted by a police officer, demand to see legit identification. You can always contact the police by calling 114. In case of urgent matters, call 112. Looking for more inspiration for your trip? Check out these guides. The Tietgen Residence Hall | Architecture | VisitCopenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search © Photo : The Tietgen Residence Hall Shape Directions Group 2 View photos The source of inspiration for the new Students' Residence in Copenhagen were the traditional Tulou houses in Southeastern China - village communities with individual dwellings and communal facilities. Five vertical intersections divides this circular building into sections and acts as passage ways between them, and to the inner courtyard, allowing for both communal and private life. The architects were determined to make space for communal as well as private life in the building. Much attention has been given to creativity and individual expression in the design of all student rooms. A sustainability guide to Copenhagen | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Gro Spiseri Add to my trip Print Share A sustainability guide to Copenhagen Photo : Giuseppe Liverino Get to know the green and sustainable Copenhagen and how you can make the most eco-friendly choices when visiting. Hit the streets and harbour baths with this guide made in collaboration with Copenhagen Municipality. Eating out: When organic is the logical choice, not a luxury The New Nordic Cuisine put Copenhagen on the culinary world map. It also sparked a revolution with its focus on local, organic ingredients in season. Today, this focus is maybe stronger than ever among restaurants in Copenhagen, and you’ll find many climate-friendly and organic eating options in all price ranges from noma, and Geranium to Reffen street food market. In Copenhagen, buying organic produce is not considered a luxury, but merely logical. Organic food make up 24% of the total food sale in Copenhagen, and 88% of the food consumption in the City of Copenhagen’s public institutions is organic. Add to my trip Organic restaurants Great restaurants catering to all tastes and budgets. Common for these places is their strong focus on quality, taste and organic and/or bio dynamic food and wine. Add to my trip Restaurants that take sustainability to another level Organic produce is not enough if restaurants want to minimize their carbon footprint. Growing their own veggies, re-using resources and re-thinking energy consumption into all processes are all green initiatives that set these super sustainable (and really delicious) restaurants apart. Add to my trip Best vegetarian and vegan restaurants Looking for vegetarian or vegan food? Try out Copenhagen's restaurants that are either entirely vegetarian and vegan or are guaranteed to offer vegetarian and / or vegan courses next to the meat courses. Eco-friendly behaviour, transport and accommodation We want you to enjoy your Copenhagen experience to the fullest. Luckily, sustainable choices do not compromise with that ambition. Read our 10 easy tips below before exploring the world's best bike city and finally ending your day at one of the eco-certified hotels in Copenhagen. Finding one is easy since the majority of the hotel rooms in the city are eco-certified. 10 ways to act sustainably See 10 concrete ways you can act sustainably while here and help keep Copenhagen on the green track. Developed in collaboration with The City of Copen ... Add to my trip Sustainable shopping in Copenhagen The words sustainable and shopping don’t always go hand in hand, but with this guide in hand, you can go on a Copenhagen shopping spree with a clean c ... Add to my trip Eco-certified hotels in Copenhagen Looking for an eco-certified place to stay in Copenhagen? Look no further! The majority of all the city’s hotel rooms hold an official eco-certificati ... Biking in Copenhagen Copenhagen is best explored on two wheels. It is the best bike city in the world after all. We'll tell you everything you need to know about why Copen ... Architecture and urban development Water, light, green spaces and innovative thinking are key elements in Copenhagen’s architectural development and some of the ingredients that combine sustainable actions with a high quality of life. How Copenhagen is pioneering in sustainable urban development Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Sustainable activities and things to do in Copenhagen We've gathered some ideas for environmentally-friendly things to do. Because your choices matter. The essential guide: Summer in Copenhagen | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Add to my trip Print Share The essential guide: Summer in Copenhagen Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Spending summer in Copenhagen? Enjoy the long days and bright summer nights by hanging out with the locals in some of the many parks, urban spaces and city beaches in Copenhagen or join in the variety of activities offered along the harbour front. 7 reasons  to spend your summer in Copenhagen Photo : Thomas Rousing In and out of the water A lot of the summer fun in Copenhagen is centered around water. If you want to find true summer localhood we suggest you try out some of these recommendations. Add to my trip Copenhagen's harbour baths and beaches In Copenhagen, you are never far from a beach, and during summer you can also go for a swim in the many centrally located harbour baths. If you want more in-depth information on the Copenhagen Harbour, download the dedicated app for that here: KBH Havn . Add to my trip Ways to conquer Copenhagen's canals It doesn't take much more than a few rays of sunshine before Copenhagen's waterfront is filled with renewed energy and joyful faces. Here are some tips on how to enjoy the city's beautiful lakes and canals. How to Copenhagen the Wozniacki way Photo : Lukas Bukoven Summery snacking Since summertime in Copenhagen means spending as much time as possible outside we suggest you explore the city's many food markets, unless you'd prefer just sticking to ice cream. Either way, we'll present to you the best of the best. Add to my trip Photo : PR Street food markets in and around Copenhagen Lately, Copenhagen has seen an influx of food trucks feeding the street food-craving locals. At the permanent food markets as well as the caravans popping up at events all over the city. Add to my trip Photo : Ismageriet | PR The best ice cream in Copenhagen Let's admit it: Spring and summer are really just a convenient excuse to eat otherwise inappropriate amounts of ice cream. Here’s our guide to some of the best places for ice cream in Copenhagen. Add to my trip © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Marc Skafte-Vaabengaard Sips in the sun: Copenhagen’s best outdoor cafés & bars When the sun shines in Copenhagen, everything changes. Locals flock outside to soak up the sun while enjoying lunch, dinner, coffee or cold drinks. From cosy corners on Vesterbro to unique spots on vibrant Nørrebro. Here's all the best outside dining venues for a true Copenhagen summer. Take a deep dive into all things Copenhagen Regardless of the seasons, there are mainstays in Copenhagen that never gets old. Get your full overview of the food scene, the art scene, and last but not least, the many diverse neighbourhoods of Copenhagen just waiting for you to get explored. Nature or architecure? - Either way get ready to be awed Copenhagen has been awarded UNESCO-UIA - World Capital of Architecture in recognition of its strong legacy within architecture and innovative urban development. Get your guide to where to go and what to see. Or if you're looking for an amazing to the surround areas of Copenhagen, look no further. Photo : Rasmus Hjortshøj Experience world-class modern architecture Copenhagen's architectural legacy is strong and all-pervading, but it is also more relevant than ever, as the city will be UNESCO-UIA—World Capital of Architecture in until 2026. Green Copenhagen In the winter the Copenhageners go into hibernation, but the second the sun rays deliver heat, everyone comes outside. The best parks and gardens Photo : Maria Sattrup Copenhagen is buzzing all year around Copenhagen is blessed with four very distinct seasons each with their own special flavour. Whether you're looking for a vibrant summer vibe, colourful autumn, cosy winter or beautiful spring - Copenhagen is incredible no matter the time of year. All neighbourhood guides | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search The Copenhagen neighbourhood guide Copenhagen is divided into a pack of very different yet equally loveable neighbourhoods, each with their own distinct vibes and looks. From gritty and industrial Refshaleøen to posh and classy Frederiksberg , Copenhagen has a neighbourhood to fit any liking. Dive into the Copenhagen localhood here or outside the city on a day trip off the beaten track. The "bros" Hitting up these three neighbourhoods is quintessential to any Copenhagen trip. The original residents areas are full of life, creativity and great dining. Vesterbro Once, Vesterbro’s claim to fame was its status as the red-light district of Copenhagen. Today, the popular neighbourhood is equally cool and authentic while mixing family living with hip nightlife, fashion boutiques, sex shops and old school gritty vibes. Nørrebro Nørrebro is a true melting pot of all things delicious, fun and vibrant. As Copenhagen's most culturally diverse neighbourhood, this is both the place to go for the best shawarma you've ever had, your new favourite ramen joint or a handful of tacos to die for. Creativity and street culture ... Østerbro This elegant part of town is a treasure trove when it comes to great experiences for young and adults alike. And as the greenest neighbourhood in Copenhagen, Østerbro’s parks, water front and shopping streets are perfect for a bike ride or a stroll. Regardless what make you tick, this guid ... Photo : Copenhagen App Gritty and upcoming Former industrial and working class areas are bustling with creative outposts and gastronomy these days. Head a bit off the beaten track, and the city completely opens up anew. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Refshaleøen In recent years, the former industrial district has become one of Copenhagen’s hippest areas and a hub for creativity, alternative urban development, ... Photo : Asger Støttrup Jensen Nordvest A culturally diverse neighbourhood off the beaten track and a place to experience an authentic and local part of Copenhagen. Nordvest often stands in ... Photo : Marie Sattrup Sydhavnen Sydhavnen is a less trodden path in Copenhagen and a neighbourhood that mixes nature, an architectural boom and authentic harbour-side living on the e ... Photo : Thomas Høyrup Christensen The Carlsberg City A strong cultural heritage comes to life in Copenhagen’s newest neighbourhood, The Carlsberg City District. A unique neighbourhood, where historical b ... Waterfront living Copenhageners love to swim, dip, boat, bathe, paddle and dive into the canals and sea surrounding the city. The waters bring quality of life with it, and in these areas, it's right out the doorstep. Christianshavn The coloured houses and idyllic canals make Christianshavn (and the island of Holmen) unique and one of Copenhagen’s most picturesque neighbourhoods. Made up of a group of small islands, the neighbourhood is a real charmer, and ideal to explore by bike, on foot along the quays or even from ... Amager Sea and nature meets the city! Amager is so much its own creature and yet still such an integral part of the city. Consisting of a few areas, incuding East Amager, Islands Brygge and Ørestad. Gastronomy, liveability and life on the water is booming out here! Oh, and you can go skiing on a ... Nordhavn From brand-spanking new architecture to top-notch bathing and eating in the sky, Nordhavn is a hot-spot for impressive architecture, design studios and new gastronomy. The classics Each of the city's areas put so much on display, but the good ol' classics still have a special Copenhagen charm to offer. The city center: Cultural hub The city's historic center is a treasure trove of culture, great restaurants, attractions and fun things you don’t want to miss. Frederiksberg Sophisticated, green and delicious. Frederiksberg is its very own municipality, with broad tree-lined boulevards, green gardens and streets filled with sidewalk cafés and gourmets spots. Dig right in! Our favourite streets Whether it's for shopping, hunting for grub or the best coffee in town. Some streets have it all, and some specialize in a specific segment. All our favourite streets in Copenhagen have one thing in common though, that they all have their own special vibe and identity. Check out our neighbourhood videos Get a deeper sense of the neighbourhoods presented by the people who live there. Photo : Thomas Høyrup Christensen Keep discovering ... Podcast: Insider's Guide to Copenhagen | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Add to my trip Print Share Podcast: Insider's Guide to Copenhagen Photo : Mellanie Gandø Whether you're a Copenhagen local or visiting, you will discover plenty of new spots in this podcast! Radio and television host Esben Bjerre joins different Copenhageners in their favourite activities, places to eat, where they bring their friends, and many hidden gems around the city. Listen on Apple Podcast , Spotify or on your favourite podcast app . Mark Tanggaard Classic culture, deep-rooted history, and fresh seafood Rhea Leman came to Copenhagen in 1976, and was immediately in love with the city. She felt safe regardless of where and when she was, which was a big contrast to her native New York City. She particularly enjoys how history is present on every street in Copenhagen, and she loves to stroll through the parks and museums and indulge in delicious food in restaurants. Listen to Rhea's guide here Mark Tanggaard Winter bathing, ancient artifacts and retro coolness Justine Bell is an architect, and was educated in London. Orignally from Cape Town in South Africa, Copenhagen is very different from what she has been used to before. Here, she is close to an ocean, less rowdy than the Atlantic Ocean. The walkable and bike-friendly city, combined with the rapid change of seasons, has Justine fall in love with Copenhagen and call it her home. Listen to Justine's guide here Daniel Rasmussen Food from abroad, crispy wines and retro arcade gaming A decade ago, New York chef Nick Curtin and his Danish wife decided to move to Copenhagen, and he has been in love with the city ever since. He found coming to Denmark fascinating because it differed from his life in the United States. He states, "Copenhagen is very international, but still very Danish!" Living in Copenhagen has taught him many things about himself, such as how he interacts with people and how he thinks about food. He emphasises the green spaces and the international food scene, where people have come from their home country and found a space for their native foods in Copenhagen. Listen to Nicks' guide here Mark Tanggaard Deer safari, a royal hunting palace and Danish design galore Inan Isik, a Turkish fashion designer, might get Danes better than most - at least what the trends in Danish fashions are! Having worked for both GANNI, Marlene Birger and Bestseller, she has a finger on the pulse regarding what is trendy. Join Inan as she shows Esben where she spends his time in Beyond Copenhagen. It is only a short train ride from multiple stations in Copenhagen, and with many trains per hour, the destinations are easily reachable. Listen to Inans' guide here Mark Tanggaard Architecture, Italian food and waterfronts When Enlai Hooi was looking to relocate from Australia, he knew he wanted to go to Europe, and "by luck" ended up in Copenhagen. With an Irish-Chinese background, he feels that he blends perfectly into the multicultural Copenhagen, where "nobody cares where you are from." As an architect, the medieval buildings that almost intertwine with each other never cease to amaze him, along with the water that glues the city together. Listen to Enlai's guide here Mark Tanggaard Nature, tranquillity and a uniquely preserved village Kriti Prajapati had never heard of Copenhagen when her husband accepted a job there. Seven years later, she has now shifted her career from engineer to comedian, where she mostly looks at Danes from the outside and lovingly pokes fun at them. She feels safe in Copenhagen and connected to nature here, even though Dragør can be hard to pronounce! Listen to Kriti's guide here Mark Tanggaard Blixen, Shakespeare and maritime Elsinore When Keri was out celebrating a friend in New Zealand, she got hungry and started to chat with a Danish tourist with a pizza. The rest is history, and now she works as an author in Denmark, living, observing and writing about the Danish way of life Listen to Keri's guide here Mark Tanggaard Danish design, wine and kayaking Dressed in almost exactly the same outfit, HAY designer Sam shows Esben a more design-oriented Copenhagen. As Sam has noticed, design, art, and furniture are such an essential part of Danish history and heritage, which Copenhagen reflects. The architecture, the food quality, the design, and the atmosphere are all of the best quality—both on land and in water! Listen to Sam's guide here Mark Tanggaard Bikes, coffee and urban spaces When Aldo fell in love with a Danish woman, he begged her to bring him to Copenhagen. When he arrived, it was snowy and windy, and people were still on their bikes. Flabbergasted by the stubbornness of Danes, combined with his own passion for cycling, he knew he had to move here. For Aldo, the bike equals freedom. With freedom and the love of Copenhagen, he has found a balance that keeps him relaxed. Listen to Aldo's guide here Mark Tanggaard Art, wellness and a spectacular view According to Mamie Beth Cary, Copenhagen is a "small dog with a big dog mentality." Born in central London, she moved to Copenhagen in 2016 and works as Director of von Bartha. Copenhagen has a great art scene where Mamie quickly discovered a simple life was possible. She says, that there is " this kind of charm in Copenhagen" where life is more simple, there is more quality, the streets are clean, and where water and height combine with the landscape. Listen to Mamie's guide here Mark Tanggaard Adrenaline rushes and exotic food When Rosio Sanchez first came to Copenhagen, it was to work as a pastry chef for Noma; She actually heard about Noma, before she heard about Copenhagen! Now, Copenhagen is home. To her, Copenhagen is a city that "has more or less everything" and feels like a breath of fresh air. The walkable city with cycle paths everywhere keeps you active and as she said, "it's is a special city that changes how you are." Listen to Rosio's guide here Mark Tanggaard Beer, bathing and solo traveling Laura Hall visited Copenhagen for the first time as a solo traveller. Later, she moved back and thought she would be here for two years. After six months, Laura and her husband looked at each other and decided the easy Copenhagen lifestyle was for them. She feels that Copenhagen is safe, notably for women travelling solo, and that Danes are kind and caring. And the weather? Laura has taken the Danish saying “There's no such thing as bad weather, only unsuitable clothing” to heart! Listen to Laura's guide here Mellanie Gandø Kids in the city When Annie Samples's husband got a job offer in his dream city, Copenhagen, the Texas-born mother of four packed everything up and made the move despite never having set foot on Danish soil. Fortunately, she fell in love with Copenhagen and to her, this is now home. After the initial cultural shock, for instance, coming to terms with the Danish stroller practice, she and her family fell in love with the architecture, flowers, bakeries, and much more. Listen to Annie's guide here Mellanie Gandø Drinks and Danish Smørrebrød When Harry Bell wanted to expand his horizons and leave Italy, his friend told him, "Do you want to be in the place where everything already happened or do you want to be in the place where everybody needs to be?" Harry went to Copenhagen because he knew it as a place with a strong food scene. His plan was to stay for a year - and eight years later, he is still here. According to himself, he has lost his heart to Copenhagen. Let's explore Beyond Copenhagen | Day trips from Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card Beyond Copenhagen North East South West Elsinore My Trip Search Explore beyond Copenhagen Photo : Ty Stange & Marvin Kuhr Just a short train ride from Copenhagen lies a world of natural beauty, history, architecture, culture and hygge all year around. Areas of beyond Every area of beyond Copenhagen has something different to offer. From UNESCO World Heritage sites to excellent food, winter bathing opportunities to world-class art museums and many more great experiences. Photo : MArvin Kuhr North of Copenhagen Along the northern city limits of Copenhagen runs a patch of rich forest land and a marvellous coastal line. © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Arken South of Copenhagen In Copenhagen South is a mix of bold architecture, contemporary art at ARKEN, and vast nature with beaches, meadows, and forests. Photo : Marvin Kuhr East of Copenhagen Copenhagen East has grandiose nature, cosy villages and many great attractions. Take a break from the city's hustle and bustle here. Photo : Maria Kathrine Preisler West of Copenhagen Just west of Copenhagen, you'll find captivating stories, trash art, giant trolls, and amazing open-faced sandwiches. The cultural pearl Elsinore in royal and historic North Zealand The 800-year-old market town exudes a unique maritime cultural history that you will not come across anywhere else. If you let go, you have the opportunity to step into a piece of Danish history, strolling through the old cobbled streets and feeling the breath of history from the market town of the past. Explore Elsinore © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Lukas Bukoven No persuasion needed Getting to and around beyond is easy, as there are multiple buses and trains every hour from central Copenhagen. If you still don't feel quite convinced, please check out the 11 reasons why going on a day trip to Beyond Copenhagen is a must! Add to my trip © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Lukas Bukoven Getting around beyond Copenhagen Getting to and around Beyond Copenhagen is a lot easier than you might think. On this page, you will find multiple guides for a smooth ride, regardless of it being by train or bike. Add to my trip © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Marvin Kuhr 11 reasons to go Expand your horizons and get out of Copenhagen to experience some of the best hidden gems around. Add to my trip © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Lukas Bukoven Adventures along The Coastal Line World-class art museums, UNESCO World Heritage and unique history. Jump on the train along The Coastal Line, going all the way from Copenhagen Central Station to Elsinore, and begin an unforgettable journey towards great experiences while enjoying beautiful views of the Sound. Highlights Add to my trip Photo : Lukas Bukoven Attractions beyond Copenhagen Just a short journey from Copenhagen, there is a variety of fun attractions to do! Add to my trip © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Anders Bøgild Things to do with your family beyond Copenhagen Just outside Copenhagen, you'll find a wealth of family-friendly experiences that both children and adults will love. Add to my trip © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Marvin Kuhr Stunning nature just outside the city Pack your backpack with your outdoor gear and replace the noise of the city with the nature of Zealand, which ranges from beautiful coastlines, magnificent forest landscapes and open fields. Add to my trip Photo : Mark Tanggaard Casual dining experiences beyond Copenhagen You don't have to go far from Copenhagen to find a lot of hidden gems of dining experiences in beautiful local surroundings. Here's an overview of casual and cosy cafés, eateries and bars located outside the city that are worth a visit if you find yourself in these areas. Add to my trip © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Marvin Kuhr History and culture beyond Copenhagen The cities and areas outside Copenhagen are full of exciting culture and history that you can explore either on your own or at one of the many museums that are often only a short drive away. Use this guide and get inspired to explore the exciting history of Denmark. Add to my trip Photo : Mark Tanggaard Discover diverse culinary experiences beyond Copenhagen Denmark’s culinary landscape extends far beyond the city limits, offering a range of exciting local food experiences in charming out-of-town locations. Venture outside the bustling city of Copenhagen to discover the hidden gems of Denmark’s picturesque countryside. Go beyond Copenhagen with the Copenhagen Card With the Copenhagen Card, you don’t just get access to Copenhagen’s top museums and attractions — you can also explore incredible destinations outside the city center, such as The Open Air Museum, Kronborg Castle, and ARKEN. What's included? Find out here If you want to delve deeper into the metropolitan area, Beyond Copenhagen magazine is for you - here you can get the locals' top tips for things not to miss. Day trips from Copenhagen Copenhagen, a vibrant capital city, offers a wealth of experiences. But just beyond its bustling streets lies a diverse landscape brimming with history, natural beauty, and charming towns. Embarking on a day trip from Copenhagen is the perfect way to immerse yourself in the authentic Danish experience, discovering hidden gems and creating lasting memories. Why Choose a Day Trip from Copenhagen? Easy Access: Denmark's compact size and excellent transportation network make exploring beyond Copenhagen incredibly easy. Whether you prefer scenic train journeys, comfortable bus rides, or the freedom of a rental car, you'll find convenient options to reach your chosen destination. Variety of Experiences: From majestic castles and Viking history to dramatic coastlines and serene countryside, the areas surrounding Copenhagen offer a diverse range of attractions. Whether you're a history buff, a nature lover, an art enthusiast, or simply seeking relaxation, there's a perfect day trip waiting for you. Escape the City: While Copenhagen is a fantastic city, sometimes you need a break from the urban buzz. A day trip allows you to escape the city's hustle and bustle and reconnect with nature, explore quieter towns, and experience a different pace of life. Rich Cultural Heritage: Denmark's history and culture are deeply intertwined with its landscapes and towns. Day trips offer a unique opportunity to delve deeper into Danish heritage, visiting historical sites, exploring museums, and experiencing local traditions. Create Lasting Memories: Whether you're traveling solo, as a couple, with family, or with friends, a day trip from Copenhagen is a chance to create unforgettable memories. These experiences will add another dimension to your Danish adventure. Discover Copenhagen's countryside Copenhagen's vibrant energy is undeniable, but the true heart of Denmark often lies in its tranquil countryside. Just a short journey from the capital, a world of rolling fields, charming villages, and picturesque coastlines awaits. Embarking on a countryside day trip from Copenhagen offers a refreshing escape, allowing you to experience the authentic beauty and peaceful rhythm of rural Danish life. Immerse Yourself in Nature's Embrace: Rolling Landscapes & Open Skies: Leave behind the city's concrete jungle and breathe in the fresh, clean air of the Danish countryside. Vast fields of golden wheat, vibrant green pastures dotted with grazing cows, and expansive blue skies create a sense of tranquility and connection with nature. Coastal Delights & Seaside Charm: Denmark's coastline is never far away, and countryside day trips often lead to charming fishing villages, sandy beaches, and dramatic cliffs overlooking the sea. Enjoy the salty air, the sound of crashing waves, and the picturesque beauty of the Danish coastline. Forests & Lakes: Discover hidden forests perfect for hiking and exploring, or relax by the serene shores of crystal-clear lakes. The Danish countryside offers a variety of natural landscapes, providing opportunities for outdoor activities and peaceful contemplation. Experience Rural Life & Local Charm: Charming Villages & Quaint Towns: Explore idyllic villages with colorful houses, cobblestone streets, and friendly locals. Discover hidden gems, browse local shops, and experience the authentic charm of rural Danish life. Local Produce & Culinary Delights: The Danish countryside is a haven for food lovers. Sample fresh, local produce, enjoy traditional Danish cuisine at charming farm-to-table restaurants, and discover the region's culinary specialties. Farm Visits & Rural Experiences: Many farms offer tours and activities, allowing you to experience rural life firsthand. Learn about agriculture, interact with animals, and gain a deeper understanding of Denmark's farming traditions. Discover History & Heritage in the Countryside: Manor Houses & Castles: The Danish countryside is dotted with magnificent manor houses and castles, offering a glimpse into the country's rich history and aristocratic past. Explore opulent interiors, wander through stunning gardens, and imagine life in a bygone era. Ancient Sites & Historical Landmarks: Discover ancient burial mounds, Viking settlements, and other historical landmarks scattered throughout the countryside. These sites offer a fascinating glimpse into Denmark's past and its cultural heritage. Copenhagen Weather - A Guide To All Seasons | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Add to my trip Print Share Copenhagen Weather - A Guide To All Seasons Photo : VisitCopenhagen The weather in Copenhagen changes seasonally and each season brings its own unique twist on the Copenhagen experience. So, whether you're into sun-drenched adventures or cozy café crawls, let's break down what each season has in store. Table of contents: Winter weather in Copenhagen Spring weather in Copenhagen Summer weather in Copenhagen Autumn weather in Copenhagen Average monthly temperatures Average monthly sea water temperatures Winter Weather in Copenhagen Winter in Copenhagen allows you to bring out your inner viking by diving into the ice cold, yet refreshing water in the many harbour baths. Photo : Daniel Jensen Winter in Copenhagen isn't just cold; it's an experience . Think twinkling lights, the scent of cinnamon and pine, and a cozy atmosphere that wraps you up like a warm blanket. It's the season of hygge , that uniquely Danish feeling of comfort and contentment. Winter Weather/Temperature: Cold and often snowy, typically between 0-5°C (32-41°F). Layers are your friend – think warm sweaters, waterproof jackets, and definitely a good hat and gloves. Here are some typical things you definitely want to experience in the Copenhagen winter weather: Winter Bathing: A popular activity in Copenhagen, and it's not for the faint of heart. But if you're feeling adventurous, it's an exhilarating way to experience the Danish winter. Take a dip in the icy water, followed by a warming sauna, and you'll feel invigorated and alive. Several harbors and beaches offer winter bathing facilities, often with saunas or hot tubs nearby. It's a truly unique and invigorating experience! Ice Skating: The city boasts several fantastic ice skating rinks. Glide across the ice under the twinkling lights, enjoy some festive music, and embrace the winter spirit. Whether you're a seasoned skater or a beginner, it's a fun activity for all ages. Several rinks pop up throughout the city during the winter months, often with skate rentals available. Cozy Cafés: Copenhagen's café culture is strong year-round, but it really shines in the winter. Find a cozy spot, sink into a comfy armchair, and treat yourself to a rich hot chocolate, a spiced latte, or a flaky pastry. It's the perfect way to warm up after a day of exploring. Winter Walks: Don't let the cold keep you indoors. Copenhagen is beautiful in the winter. Take a stroll through the city's parks, which transform into snowy landscapes. Or explore the charming streets of the old town, where the colorful buildings look even more picturesque dusted with snow. Museum Hopping: If the weather gets too chilly, escape indoors to one of Copenhagen's many world-class museums. From art and design to history and culture, there's something for everyone. And many museums offer special winter exhibitions and events. ➜ Learn more about winter in Copenhagen Spring Weather & Blosomming Vibes Bispebjerg Cemetery On a sunny spring day, Bispebjerg Cemetery makes for a special excursion. Guests come from near and far to take photos of one of the garden’s main attractions: the avenue of Japanese cherry trees that, when in bloom, form a spectacular long, pink tunnel. Photo : Thomas Høyrup Christensen Spring in Copenhagen isn't just a season; it's a transformation . The city shakes off its winter coat, the parks burst into color, and there's a palpable sense of renewal. It's the perfect time to explore, discover, and soak up the vibrant energy. Spring Temperature/Weather in Copenhagen:: Mild and getting warmer, usually between 5-15°C (41-59°F). Layering is key – think light jackets, sweaters, and maybe a scarf for those cooler evenings. Here are some Spring-activities you've got to try: Coastal Exploration: Ditch the city center crowds and head north along the Øresund coast. Charming towns like Elsinore , with its impressive Kronborg Castle (Hamlet's castle!), offer a glimpse into Danish history and stunning sea views. Rent a bike and cycle along the scenic coastal roads, breathing in the fresh sea air. Dyrehaven Delights: Escape to Dyrehaven (Deer Park), a vast, natural park just north of the city. Explore the blooming forests, spot wild deer roaming freely, and enjoy a picnic amidst the greenery. It's a perfect escape from the city bustle. Blossom Bliss: Copenhagen's parks and gardens are at their peak in spring. Wander through the King's Garden , admire the cherry blossoms in Bispebjerg Cemetery , or explore the botanical gardens. It's a feast for the eyes and a perfect spot for a relaxing stroll. Cycling City: Copenhagen is a cycling city year-round, but spring is an especially great time to hop on two wheels. Rent a bike and explore the city at your own pace, discovering hidden gems and enjoying the fresh air. Cycle along the harbor, through the parks, or explore the charming neighborhoods beyond the city center. Harbor Hangouts: As the weather warms up, Copenhagen's harbor comes alive. Grab a coffee or a beer at one of the many waterfront cafes and bars, and watch the boats go by. It's a great place to people-watch and soak up the spring sunshine. Outdoor Dining: Spring is the perfect time to enjoy al fresco dining. Many restaurants and cafes set up outdoor seating areas, allowing you to enjoy your meal while soaking up the spring atmosphere. Spring in Copenhagen is a time of renewal, a chance to experience the city at its most vibrant and beautiful. It's a season for exploring the outdoors, indulging in local flavors, and embracing the energy of a city coming to life. ➜ Read more about spring in Copenhagen Copenhagen Weather During Summer Østergro is a unique urban farm located on a roof top in the heart of the city. Perfect for those vibrant summer evenings. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Summer in Copenhagen? It's pure hygge under the midnight sun (well, almost!). The city comes alive, buzzing with energy, outdoor events, and a relaxed, carefree vibe. Days are long, and the possibilities are endless. Summer Temperature/Weather: Warm and sunny, typically between 20-25°C (68-77°F). Sunscreen is a must, and light, breezy clothing is your best friend Some of the best activities to enjoy in the Copenhagen summer weather: Harbor Life: Copenhagen's harbor is the heart of the city in summer. Skip the crowded canal tours and explore the waterways by kayak or paddleboard. It's a unique way to see the city from a different perspective. Or simply relax on the harborfront, grab a cold drink, and watch the boats go by. Beach Days: Copenhagen might not be known for its beaches, but the Amager coastline offers some surprisingly good spots for swimming, sunbathing, and watersports. Amager Strandpark is a popular choice, with its sandy beaches, dunes, and clear waters. Park Life: Copenhagen's parks come alive in the summer. Pack a picnic and head to Kongens Have (the King's Garden), Ørstedsparken , or Frederiksberg Have . Enjoy the sunshine, play some frisbee, or simply relax and people-watch. Outdoor Events: Summer is festival season in Copenhagen. From music festivals and food markets to cultural events and open-air concerts, there's always something happening. Street Food Scene: Copenhagen's street food scene is booming, and summer is the perfect time to indulge. Explore the various street food markets and food trucks, offering everything from gourmet burgers and tacos to international delicacies and local specialties. Bike Adventures: Copenhagen is a cycling paradise, and summer is the ideal time to explore the city on two wheels. Rent a bike and cycle along the harbor, through the parks, or explore the charming neighborhoods beyond the city center. Open-Air Bars and Cafés: As the weather warms up, Copenhagen's bars and cafes spill out onto the streets. Enjoy a cold beer, a refreshing cocktail, or a delicious meal at one of the many outdoor seating areas. It's the perfect way to soak up the summer atmosphere and enjoy the long, light evenings. Summer in Copenhagen is all about embracing the outdoor lifestyle, enjoying the long days and warm nights, and soaking up the city's vibrant energy. It's a season for relaxation, exploration, and creating unforgettable memories. ➜ Learn more about summer in Copenhagen Autumn temperature & activities in Copenhagen Royal lifeguards marching by Kings Garden. Photo : Christian Lindgren Autumn in Copenhagen is a study in hygge . The city slows down a bit, the air turns crisp, and the leaves explode into a riot of color. It's a time for cozy sweaters, warm drinks, and appreciating the beauty of nature. Temperature/Weather In Autumn: Cooling down, usually between 10-15°C (50-59°F). Layering is essential – think light jackets, sweaters, and maybe a scarf. Experiences: Forest Hikes: Autumn is the perfect time to explore the forests surrounding Copenhagen. Gribskov , one of Denmark's largest forests, is a must-visit. Hike through the colorful foliage, breathe in the fresh air, and enjoy the tranquility of nature. Nørrebro Exploration: Explore the vibrant and multicultural Nørrebro district. Browse the unique shops and galleries, discover hidden cafes, and soak up the neighborhood's bohemian vibe. It's a great place to experience Copenhagen's diverse cultural scene. Museum Hopping: If the weather turns chilly, escape indoors to one of Copenhagen's many museums. Explore art, design, history, and culture at world-class institutions like the National Museum of Denmark , the Glyptoteket , or the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art (just a short train ride from the city). Harvest Festivals: Autumn is harvest season, and many farms and orchards around Copenhagen host harvest festivals. Pick your own apples, pumpkins, or other seasonal produce, and enjoy the festive atmosphere. Cozy Cafés: Copenhagen's café culture is thriving year-round, but it's especially cozy in the autumn. Find a charming café, curl up with a good book, and enjoy a warm drink like a spiced latte or a rich hot chocolate. Autumn in Tivoli: Tivoli Gardens takes on a special charm in the autumn. The park is decorated with pumpkins, gourds, and other autumnal decorations, creating a cozy and festive atmosphere. Enjoy the rides, explore the gardens, and soak up the autumn ambiance. Art and Design: Autumn is a great time to explore Copenhagen's vibrant art and design scene. Visit galleries, studios, and design shops, and discover the latest trends in Danish creativity. Autumn in Copenhagen is a time for reflection, appreciation of nature's beauty, and embracing the cozy moments that make life special. It's a season for slowing down, enjoying the simple things, and finding hygge in the everyday. ➜ Learn more about autumn in Copenhagen Copenhagen weather/temperature (monthly averages) January: 2.4 (°C) / 36.6 (°F) February: 2.5 (°C) / 36.5 (°F) March: 4.2 (°C) / 39.6(°F) April: 8.0 (°C )/ 46.4 (°F) May: 12.2 (°C )/ 54.0 (°F) June: 16.0 (°C) /61.7 (°F) July: 18.0 (°C) / 64.4 (°F) August: 17.9 (°C) /64.2 (°F) September: 15.0 (°C) /59.0 (°F) October: 10.8 (°C) / 51.4 (°F) November: 7.2 (°C ) / 45.0 (°F) December: 3.7 (°C) / 38.7 (°F) Source: www.dmi.dk Copenhagen sea/water temperature (monthly averages) January: 4-5 (°C) / 39-41 (°F) February: 3-4 (°C) / 37-39 (°F) March: 3-4 (°C) / 37-39 (°F) April: 5-7 (°C) / 41-45 (°F) May: 9-12 (°C) / 48-54 (°F) June: 14-17 (°C) / 57-63 (°F) July: 17-20 (°C) / 63-68 (°F) August: 18-21 (°C) / 64-70 (°F) September: 16-19 (°C) / 61-66 (°F) October: 12-14 (°C) / 54-57 (°F) November: 8-10 (°C) / 46-50 (°F) December: 5-7 (°C) / 41-45 (°F) Source: seatemperature.info Get Social : Useful links Web Accessibility Editorial policy Other sites Wonderful Copenhagen Cruise Denmark – Copenhagen and beyond Copenhagen Convention Bureau Travel Trade Copenhagen Card Intl. press room Contact Contact VisitCopenhagen Visit Copenhagen © 2025 Data Protection Notice English

Guide: Winter in Copenhagen | Everything you need to know Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Embrace the Copenhagen winter days Visit Copenhagen in the colder months, and you’ll find a different kind of warmth than the warmth from the sun — it’s the warmth that arises between people when the temperatures make you seek togetherness rather than shade. So, dear visitors, consider this your warm welcome to a cool city - an invitation to uncover the truth that Copenhagen is warmest when it's cold. Top 5 things to do in Copenhagen in winter © Visit Copenhagen Photo : Daniel Jensen Winter experiences and activities Copenhagen doesn't slow down during winter, from culinary and cultural experiences to outdoor activities and events, there's plenty for you to dive into. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Enjoy the outdoor In Copenhagen, we embrace the chill of winter by taking our activities outdoors. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Enjoy the culture Copenhagen is ready to entertain you. From royal history to contemporary art and design classics. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Culinary experiences Whether you are into bistros or Michelin-starred restaurants, you will find it in Copenhagen. Photo : Abdellah Ihadian See events We have listed attractions, services, places to stay and more right here. Highlights Here you'll find some of the unique highlights of Copenhagen. From delicious seasonal pastry to insider tips and local recommendations. Photo : Mark Tanggaard Podcast: Insider's guide to Copenhagen Whether you're a Copenhagen local or visiting, you will discover plenty of new spots in this podcast! © Visit Copenhagen Photo : Daniel Jensen Our winter recommendations Explore this collection of our best winter recommendations from the Copenhagen unfolded newsletter. Plan your winter holiday All the practical stuff that will help you to plan the best possible trip to Copenhagen. Useful before and during your stay. Where to stay in Copenhagen Photo : Mellanie Gandø Metroen How to get around Copenhagen © Visit Copenhagen Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Save money with Copenhagen Card © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Mellanie Gandø Get answers about Copenhagen in Winter Find answers to the most frequently asked questions about visiting Copenhagen in winter. What's the winter weather like in Copenhagen? What's the weather like in Copenhagen? The climate in Copenhagen follows the four seasons of the northern hemisphere, but temperatures can vary considerably during the year. February is generally the coldest with an average of 2 degrees Celcius and 35 degrees Fahrenheit. Unfortunately, snow is not something we can guarantee each winter. When it occurs, it’s typically from December until spring, but snow rarely lasts long. Temperatures in Copenhagen The average winter temperatures in Celcius in Copenhagen are (month: day / night): Dec: 3,7 / -0,5 Jan: 1,9 / -2,0 Feb: 2,0 / -2,4 Month: day / night (average temperatures in Fahrenheit): Dec: 38,7 / 31,1 Jan: 35,4 / 28,4 Feb: 35,6 / 27,7 What to wear in Copenhagen in winter? There is no bad weather, only bad clothing. In Denmark, we have a saying: "There is no bad weather, only bad clothing." This couldn’t be more true in winter. While temperatures may not look extreme on paper, the high humidity and biting westerly and northerly winds can make it feel much colder. Without the right clothing, exploring Copenhagen during winter can quickly become an uncomfortable experience. Layers is the key The key to staying comfortable is layering. Start with a good cotton or wool base layer that fits snugly to your body. Add a thicker, slightly looser wool sweater or fleece for insulation, and top it off with a high-quality jacket that’s both waterproof and windproof. Pair this with long underwear, a cozy beanie, and you’ll be ready to enjoy hours outdoors in the beautiful winter scenery of Copenhagen. Why wool? As you might have noticed, there’s a recurring theme here: wool. For generations, it has been a trusted material in the Nordic region—and for good reason. Wool naturally regulates temperature, keeping you warm in winter and cool in summer, making it the perfect thermal material. Plus, a classic Nordic wool jumper isn’t just practical—it looks fantastic too. Embrace the local style and wrap yourself head to toe in wool for both comfort and charm. What's open in the winter in Copenhagen? Restaurants, museums and shops are all open all year round, in winter you're just more likely to bump into a local than another tourist. Outdoor experiences, like canal cruises, also operate year-round, though some operate with fewer boats in the winter season, so keep that in mind. Tivoli is one exception. In winter, it’s usually open only for Christmas, from mid-November to the end of December, and then remains closed until reopening for Easter in April. Looking for more information on all seasons? Visit our Copenhagen weather guide. Restaurants Copenhagen | VisitCopenhagen | Explore now Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search noma Find the best restaurants in Copenhagen Photo : Ditte Isager & PR | noma The big question: Where to eat and drink in Copenhagen? Whether you are into bistros or Michelin-starred restaurants, you will find it in Copenhagen. The restaurant scene is among the world's most distinct and innovative, and it caters to all budgets, tastes and situations. On Copenhagen's menu is delicious food from all over the world and a strong focus on making exquisite meals from local ingredients in season. An approach started by noma and the New Nordic cuisine and a way of cooking that still makes Copenhagen's restaurants culinary trailblazers. Add to my trip Best smørrebrød and other traditional Danish food A truly Danish food experience, you can get at lunch time in Copenhagen with the renowned smørrebrød (open faced sandwich). But at dinner you should treat yourself to some other Danish classic dishes too. They might claim less internatinal fame, but are loved by locals - for good reason. Add to my trip Value-for-money restaurants Looking for a quality meal that will not blow your budget? No worries, a lot of bistros and value-for-money restaurants offer high-quality tasting menus and great settings for under 500 DKK/$75/€70. You can also check out all of our restaurant guides for much more inspiration. Add to my trip Great budget eats in Copenhagen Long known as a culinary hotspot boasting Michelin stars , the world's best restaurant , and the New Nordic cuisine movement, Copenhagen is also foodie-friendly for budget travellers. Let us guide you to some of the best places serving up great food for around 150 DKK or less. Alouette Get familiar with Copenhagen's 15 Michelin-starred restaurants Photo : Alison Vagnini Eating out with kids or a special someone? These themed guides are for you. Searching for an extra family-friendly restaurant, a romantic dinner spot or an extra nice waterside location serving up harbourfront views of the city? These guides got your back. Add to my trip Family-friendly restaurants Many of Copenhagen’s cafes and restaurants have special children's menus, and provide a special high chair for toddlers. Some places though, go out of their way to make children welcome. Add to my trip Waterfront restaurants in Copenhagen When the sun is out, the Copenhageners are out. Luckily, the Copenhagen harbour has plenty of perfect places to soak up some sunshine while enjoying stunning waterfront views and delicious foods. Here are some of our favorites. Add to my trip Street food markets in and around Copenhagen Lately, Copenhagen has seen an influx of food trucks feeding the street food-craving locals. At the permanent food markets as well as the caravans popping up at events all over the city. Taste the whole world or go local On top of the open-faced sandwich " smørrebrød ", and the New Nordic cuisine, Copenhagen is spoiled with an extensive range of restaurants from all over. Many chefs have come here to work at some of the city’s most prestigious restaurants and have later opened their own restaurants bringing local tastes and flavours to Copenhagen. Best eateries by neighbourhood The possibility of gaining unforgettable food experiences is one of the better reasons for you to explore more than just one neighborhood. Browse thro ... Add to my trip New Nordic restaurants The New Nordic kitchen has gained international ground around the world. The New Nordic kitchen is characterized by its uniquely Nordic identity among ... Here's where to drink The last decade’s gastronomic development has also drawn talent and quality to the city’s many bars and cafés , making Copenhagen an internationally acclaimed coffee and cocktail destination. Add to my trip The best cocktail bars in Copenhagen Traditionally, Danes have been famous for beer , but in recent years, a cocktail revolution has put Copenhagen on the map as a top-tier cocktail destin ... Add to my trip Best beer bars No matter where you find yourself in Copenhagen, you’re never far from a world-class beer bar to help you quench your thirst. Add to my trip Best coffee bars in Copenhagen Copenhagen runs on coffee. Scattered about town are some of the very best brewers in the world, serving up top-notch speciality coffee for the Copenha ... Still hungry? Best vegetarian and vegan restaurants Street food markets in and around Copenhagen The best burgers in Copenhagen Organic restaurants Get gastronomic at these hotel restaurants Best take away in Copenhagen A captivating restaurant scene Copenhagen’s restaurant scene is a culinary paradise that captivates food enthusiasts from around the world. Enjoy a luxurious dinner at a world-class award-winning restaurant, or grab a quick snack from one of the many popular street food markets around town. No matter what you are looking for – we guarantee that the restaurants and many food stalls will have something to satisfy your taste buds year-round. Experience restaurants in Copenhagen The restaurants in Copenhagen are perhaps among some of the most innovative ones in the world. Many local chefs and restaurateurs consider food and dining an art form and something that must not just be eaten and digested - but rather experienced. One of the unique innovators is Gro Spiseri , Denmark’s first rooftop farm located in the heart of the city. If long-table dining and home-grown greens sound appealing to you, you should try out this place. Copenhagen is also a hot spot for all things Asian. Make sure to check out these amazing Asian restaurants while you're in town. Best restaurants Copenhagen If you want to experience some of the world’s best restaurants, you are in for a treat. Copenhagen is somewhat of a Michelin-haven for those who want to dine extraordinarily well. You might want to order a table before your arrival in Copenhagen, as table reservations can be quite hard to get. Perhaps Noma, Geranium, or Alchemist rings a bell? – and for good reason, they should, as these restaurants always seem to find their place amongst the top-ranking restaurants in the world. But don’t worry if you are looking for something a little less pricey; Copenhagen has you covered with many affordable and delicious places to visit while you are here. Find restaurants near you We hope this comprehensive guide helped you find restaurants near you in Copenhagen and Beyond. If you're still in doubt as to where to eat feel free to hit us up on our social media channels, and we'll gladly assist you further. Christmas in Copenhagen | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Add to my trip Print Share Christmas in Copenhagen Photo : Marc Skafte-Vaabengaard The merriest of times in the merriest of places. Copenhagen simply oozes Christmas spirit and "hygge" of course. Experience the exclusive atmosphere of Copenhagen Christmas, where traditional customs are mixed with plain fun and good times. Christmas experiences Christmas markets are plenty in Copenhagen and so are places to check out fine art. We recommend doing both. Photo : Marc Skafte-Vaabengaard Christmas Markets Copenhagen is a genuine Christmas city, where it is impossible not to get in the spirit for the Christmas holiday season. The best place to soak up the atmosphere is at one of Copenhagen’s many Christmas markets. Photo : Maria Kathrine Preisler Art and culture in Copenhagen Copenhagen is a great city for art lovers and home to internationally acknowledged art museums, and also boasts some fantastic themed and historic museums. Photo : Mark Tanggaard Copenhagen Christmas Walk If you want to get everything Christmas in Copenhagen in one go, it can seem overwhelming. Luckily, Copenhagen Christmas Walk has created a guide on their app so you can do it all! Christmas beyond Copenhagen Food and Delicacies The Danish Christmas food is a huge part of the Danish Christmas "hygge". Check out our guides to where to find the best traditional restaurants, cafés, bars, and pastries for the holidays. Photo : Mark Tanggaard Glögg Guide Glögg is the perfect drink to consume after a cold day or while you stroll through one of Copenhagens many Christmas Markets. Photo : Marc Skafte-Vaabengaard Traditional Danish Christmas lunch Danish Christmas is tied to a lot of traditions, and Danish Christmas food is a complete chapter in itself. Photo : Mellanie Gandø Christmas beer - a Danish tradition Special Christmas beers are Copenhagen favourites as the spirit of Christmas is in the air - You’ll love them too. Photo : Maria Kathrine Preisler The best bakeries and pastry shops The tradition of Christmas pastries goes a long time back, but the last decades' focus on elevated gastronomy has sparked a new pastry revolution. It's a classic you can't miss out on The Tivoli Gardens are something special all year round and worth a visit for young and old. But of course, Tivoli is going all in on bringing the fairytale Christmas atmosphere you would expect. Christmas in Tivoli Get your dose of the special atmosphere Holiday shopping Coming home from Copenhagen emptyhanded won't do. Got to go find the perfect gift for your dearest ones or even make it yourself. Check out the many vintage and second-hand stores for that unique Christmas present. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Second hand and Vintage If you are a second-hand or vintage lover, you have come to the right place. Copenhagen is full of stores giving clothes and furniture a second life, ranging from thrift stores supporting charities to upscale stores focusing on high-end vintage pieces. Photo : Ana Cecilia Gonzalez Creative spaces Remember the time when we actually made our gifts ourselves? It’s a long-forgotten art to sit down and create and put your love into a unique and personalised gift. But now it’s time to bring back that tradition. Experience the floating Santa Lucia parade in Copenhagen’s canals. 13 December, you can experience an alternative take on the traditional, Danish Santa Lucia parade, when kayaks sail through the canals dressed in lights and Christmas decorations. Santa Lucia parade in kayaks Photo : Lukas Bukoven Warm and cosy or chilly and refreshing There is nothing like stepping into a warm and cosy setting after a full day in the brisk December weather. Or the other way around. If you want to go all the way, you do like many of the local Copenhageners, and dip into the icy waters of the harbour. It's a special treat, that you will remember for a long time. On the contrary, if you're more into warm and relaxing experiences, going to one of the many spas in Copenhagen might be more up your alley, after a day at the ice rink. Looking for christmas markets in Copenhagen? Click here Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Spa and wellness Indulge in the world of wellness that Copenhagen has to offer. Relax in the lounge at Amazing Space d'Anglettere Spa, enjoy a hot stone massage at Ni'mat Massage & Spa, or get pampered at AIRE Ancient Baths. Photo : Broens skøjtebane Go ice skating in Copenhagen Ice skating in Copenhagen is the perfect way to embrace the chilly winter months – cosy, fun, and a little active! Find the cozy ice rinks here. Photo : Mellanie Gandø Ice Swimming Where to find the best places to go ice swimming in Copenhagen? If you have built up your courage to go for an exhilarating icy dip then you can't go wrong with these places. Fairytale castles and palaces The history of Copenhagen is something that can't be denied and some of the most evident examples are the many castles and palaces scattered around the city and beyond city limits. You might just find the true historical holiday cheer here. © Visit Copenhagen Photo : Copenhagen Mediacenter Rosenborg Castle A royal hermitage set in the King’s Garden in the heart of Copenhagen. Photo : Martin Heiberg Christiansborg Palace Experience 800 years of royal history at the awe-inspiring Christiansborg Palace. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Kronborg Castle Drama-packed Kronborg is one of Northern Europe’s finest Renaissance castles. Follow us on Instagram Want to keep up on Copenhagen on a day to day basis? Then you should give us a follow on @visitcopenhagen Copenhagen is buzzing all year around Whether you're looking for a vibrant summer vibe, colourful autumn, cosy winter or beautiful spring - Copenhagen is incredible no matter the time of year. You can't miss autumn in Copenhagen | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Add to my trip Print Share You can't miss autumn in Copenhagen Photo : Lasse Bruhn There is something special about the Copenhagen autumn. It brings a certain type of atmosphere when all the green turns gold and yellow, and the "hygge" starts to gain momentum. The complete guide to autumn in Copenhagen Orange is the new green, as the air gets crisper and the days shorten. Autumn (or fall) days in Copenhagen are a little less crowded and a peak season for “ hygge ”. Expect a mix of beautiful, sunny days - even some late summery ones calling for long walks outside, and the occasional wet or windy ones calling for indoor activities. Either way, this guide got you covered. Copenhagen's top museums Photo : Daniel Rasmussen When the leaves wither, Copenhagen's museum scene blooms As the autumn weather kicks in with its occasional rainy or windy days, head inside Copenhagen’s many museums to see the new art exhibitions that open every year around this time. Photo : Anders Sune Berg Why you shouldn’t underestimate Copenhagen’s art and design scene In Copenhagen, creativity is everywhere. From the crafty shops and galleries filling the local streets, to the inviting urban space , to the modern and historic masterpieces decorating the grand halls of the city’s magnificent museums . Photo : Martin Auchenberg Experience Copenhagen Cultural District Within 10 minutes’ walk in the heart of the historic city centre 19 museums and cultural institutions make up Copenhagen Cultural District. Explore Danish and international culture and history in a small area with a large cultural significance. Photo : Jens Bangsbo Fun attractions for kids Reserved places on buses and trains for prams and pushchairs, children's menus in restaurants, art museums in kids' height and of course reductions at all attractions. Copenhagen is kids friendly and full of adventures for the whole family to enjoy. Don't forget Opportunities are all around - no matter the weather. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen 6 places to see Copenhagen in its autumn coat Autumn is the season where Copenhagen really shows its true colours. We've picked out six spots in and around the city you should make sure to see if you want a bit of that autumnal vibe. Photo : Thomas Høyrup Christensen Things to do in Copenhagen when it rains Danish weather can be tricky, but do not worry. There are plenty of things to do in Copenhagen on a rainy day. Besides being true moments of " hygge ", these days are perfect for a visit to a museum and also a great excuse to go shopping. Happening this autumn in Copenhagen © VisitCopenhagen Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Food and drink isn't just food and drink Warm yourself on a world-class cup of coffee or how about eating with locals that you have just been seated with? Fancy a lager in historical surroundings? Here you'll find an array of good food and drink experiences, which offer a little more than the usual Photo : Mellanie Gandø Best coffee bars in Copenhagen Copenhagen runs on coffee! And scattered about town is some of the very best brewers in the world, serving up top notch specialty coffee for the Copenhageners. Coffee bars are where to meet your friends, work out of office or just enjoy the vibes or soak up a ray. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Best smørrebrød and other traditional Danish food A truly Danish food experience, you can get at lunch time in Copenhagen with the renowned smørrebrød (open faced sandwich). But at dinner you should treat yourself to some other Danish classic dishes too. They might claim less internatinal fame, but are loved by locals - for good reason. Photo : - Communal dining in Copenhagen Communal dining has in recent years gotten more and more popular in Copenhagen. And to be fair, what's not to like about delicious and diverse food at reasonable prices combined with great company in a cozy environment? Best historical pubs in Copenhagen Photo : Erik Refner Urban farming and Architecture Parks and green oases have always been an integral part of Copenhagen, but lately, something new is happening. Gardens are established all over the city, on rooftops, on former industrial sites and so on. Locally grown crops are a thing now. Copenhagen is constantly evolving and the city planning and infrastructure are having a direct effect on the people both living and visiting here. Photo : VisitCopenhagen Experience world-class modern architecture The architectural legacy in Copenhagen is strong and all-pervading. But also more relevant than ever, as the city will be UNESCO-UIA - World Capital of Architecture in 2023. Photo : Peter Leschly Copenhagen Beyond The laid back Copenhagen lifestyle stretches far beyond the city limits. Do like the locals and head for the coast or countryside to enjoy, relax and grow. You don't need to travel very far, or for very long, to widen your horizon on what Copenhagen and the surrounding areas have to offer. ... Copenhagen is buzzing all year around Copenhagen is blessed with four very distinct seasons each with their own special flavour. Whether you're looking for a vibrant summer vibe, colourful autumn, cosy winter or beautiful spring - Copenhagen is incredible no matter the time of year. Guide to modern architecture in Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search The Tietgen Residence Hall Add to my trip Print Share Experience world-class modern architecture Photo : VisitCopenhagen The architectural legacy in Copenhagen is strong and all-pervading. But also more relevant than ever, as the city holds the title as UNESCO-UIA World Capital of Architecture from 2023 to 2026. Copenhagen has been awarded  UNESCO-UIA - World Capital of Architecture in recognition of its strong legacy within architecture and innovative urban development, along with its high ambitions on climate, sustainable solutions, and liveability. It’s no coincidence since Copenhagen is home to some heavy hitters on the global architectural scene. Bjarke Ingels Group (BIG) is probably the most celebrated in recent years, but let’s not forget Henning Larsen Architects, Cobe, Gehl Architects, C.F. Møller, 3XN, Lendager Group, Dissing & Weitling, Lundgaard & Tranberg, Dorthe Mandrup, and many more. Get the low down on Copenhagen’s world-class architecture and how to experience it firsthand 8 House Go Explore 20 architectural masterpieces in Copenhagen Photo : Martin Heiberg The Architect's Guide to Copenhagen Since Copenhagen has been awarded UNESCO-UIA - World Capital of Architecture in 2023, we have asked a couple of Danish architects to give their opinions on what makes Copenhagen special. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Anders Lendager See Copenhagen through the eyes of renowned Danish architect Anders Lendager, as he points towards some of his favourite places. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Sofie Lund Michaelsen Discover the Copenhagen waterfront architecture and lifestyle, guided by Danish architect Sofie Lund Michaelsen Photo : Lukas Bukoven Dan Stubbergaard Take a ride through Copenhagen with Danish architect and founder of COBE Dan Stubbergaard, as he points out some of his favourite spots around the city. Photo : Lukas Bukoven Marie-Louise Høstbo Explore the North of Copenhagen with Danish architect Marie-Louise Høstbo, Head of Design at Fritz Hansen, as she guides us towards some of her most treasured spots. Copenhagen - a city built for bicycling Bikes and Copenhagen are an integral part of each other. Copenhagen simply wouldn't be the same without its many, many kilometres of bike lanes, dedicated bike bridges, and so on. Getting around in Copenhagen is easiest on a bike, but it might also be the best way to really get a sense of how important city planning is if you aim for an urban space full of emission-free two-wheeled vehicles. Photo : Rikke Westesen Experiencing my own city as a tourist I set off on one of the many guided tours that Copenhagen has to offer. After looking through our own recommendations, I come across a trip that particularly draws me in. A half-day guided bike tour exploring the architecture of Copenhagen. Photo : Thomas Høyrup Christensen The Architectural BIG bike tour Explore some of Copenhagen's finest architecture by biking in the footsteps of world-famous architect Bjarke Ingels on this 22-kilometre bike tour. Photo : Terry McLaughlin Bike bridges in Copenhagen Copenhagen is very much a city made for bikes – and the bridges are no exception. Jump in the saddle and go for a ride across the harbour. Here are the bridges, you cannot miss on your bike ride. Want to know more about the Copenhagen bike culture? Check out this article. What is the recipe for becoming a World Capital of Architecture? Creativity, craftsmanship and democracy are all elements that for decades have helped position Denmark as a frontrunner in architecture that improves lives. Israel's Square The Legacy How Copenhagen became an architecture and design paragon Photo : Eleonora Costi Let's walk you through it From a museum all about architecture to guided and self-guided tours, and festivals. The architectural activities in Copenhagen are many, interesting and fun. Photo : @boyanoo Copenhagen Architecture Festival Copenhagen Architecture Festival (CAFx) is a place that explores, discusses and disseminates architectural and urban challenges through a number of in ... Photo : Mathias Brandt Danish Architecture Center Much more than a museum about Danish architecture, it's a full experience with walks, talks and more. Photo : Rikke Westesen beCopenhagen guided architecture tours Urbanism and architecture bike tours plus an extensive range of bikes to rent for all th family. Photo : NORD Architects, Adam Mørk Experience Ørestad - architecture tours City walks, guided bus tours and presentations about Copenhagen’s Nordic architecture with Experience Ørestad. Photo : Thomas Høyrup Christensen Sustainability, the good life and architecture Water, light, green spaces and innovative thinking are key elements in Copenhagen’s architectural development and a crucial part of obtaining a combination of sustainable actions with a high quality of life. Konditaget Lüders The Future How Copenhagen is pioneering in sustainable urban development Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Follow us on Instagram Looking for more inspiration? Check out these guides. Breathe in the Copenhagen lifestyle Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Breathe in the Copenhagen lifestyle Photo : Daniel Rasmussen & PR: GoBoat With a thriving food and beverage scene, world-class museums and galleries, and a bustling nightlife, there is always something new to experience in Copenhagen. The Copenhagen way Explore and take part in the Copenhagen lifestyle, where easygoing Copenhageners create a friendly atmosphere. Where innovative gastronomic endeavours meet traditional Danish cuisine. Where sustainable efforts are turned into opportunities to enhance the quality of urban outdoor life. That’s the Copenhagen Way of living. Photo : Alberto Grasso Discover Copenhagen Copenhagen is a unique city with a wide range of activities waiting to be discovered. Modern museums, beautiful historic castles, world-class shopping and innovative high-tech architecture are just a few reasons to visit Copenhagen. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Gastronomic diversity The gastronomic scene in Copenhagen is among the world's most distinct and innovative. With it's big variety of restaurants it caters to all budgets, tastes and situations. Photo : Giuseppe Liverino The Green City The focus on sustainability shines through in everything from cuisine and architecture to infrastructure, benefitting both residents and tourists. Get lost in all the lively areas  of Copenhagen Discover the diversity of every single neighbourhood and explore the charm of the areas beyond Copenhagen. Photo : Thomas Høyrup Christensen Neighborhood guides Copenhagen is divided into a collection of very different yet equally loveable neighbourhoods, each with its distinct vibe and look. From gritty and industrial Refshaleøen to posh and classy Frederiksberg. Explore more about the Copenhagen localhood here. Photo : Jacob Lisbygd Beyond Copenhagen Book a train ride and discover the gems located just outside the city. Copenhagen's suburbs and beyond are easy to reach and are packed with beautiful landscapes, cosy beach towns, historic castles and modern museums. The dynamic life of Copenhagen Copenhagen is buzzing energy with everything from outdoor markets, exciting exhibitions and hidden gems you just can't miss Photo : Lukas Bukanov Events around the city Make the most out of your stay in Copenhagen. Check out our event calendar, where we have gathered an overview of exhibitions and activities in and around Copenhagen so you don’t miss anything. Metrolink tram in St Peter's Square How to get around Manchester Bus, tram and train Transport for Greater Manchester (TfGM) is the official public transport body for the city. Its Bee Network website has a wealth of information and a number of journey planning tools to take the stress out of travelling. It includes: Bus services across Greater Manchester helping you get out and about. The Metrolink network, which is one of the most successful light railway systems in the UK. With frequent services there’s no need to worry about a timetable, just head to your nearest stop and the next tram won’t be far away. Metrolink can transport you to popular venues and attractions across the region and, if you’re planning on sightseeing, Travelcards offer unlimited travel across the network. Please be sure to purchase a ticket from the on-stop ticket machines before boarding or tap in and out at the contactless terminals. In addition to the inter-city links, the rail network connects you to the neighbouring towns and districts of Greater Manchester including Ashton-under-Lyne, Bolton, Oldham, Rochdale, Stockport and Wigan. Use TfGM's Bee Network journey planner free bus free bus services operate around the city centre and are free of charge. All buses are wheelchair accessible. View the free bus routes and timetables Cycling Manchester is a bike-friendly city with many marked cycle lanes and dedicated routes throughout the city centre and beyond. Visit the Transport for Greater Manchester cycling website for everything you need to know about cycling in Greater Manchester, from maps and route planning to local events and news. You can also hire bikes from various locations across the city, including the Starling Bank Bikes . View the TfGM cycling site Walking Manchester is easily explored on foot, with a city centre that you can navigate within 30 minutes. City Hosts are dotted around the centre to guide you with directions, public transport information and details on events taking place. Maps Download one of our maps to help guide you around the region. Ratings Powered by
