Back Festive Football Magic: Your Ultimate Guide to Manchester City This December By Visit Manchester on Dec. 05, 2025 3 min read The festive season is in full swing at the Etihad Stadium. December is bursting with opportunities for football enthusiasts and families to dive headfirst into the exciting culture of Manchester City Football Club. Manchester City Football Club, based in the heart of Manchester, stands tall among the giants of the Premier League, boasting a legacy of triumphs and a passionate global following. Whether you’re a devoted Cityzen or simply seeking an unforgettable visit, get ready for an experience that’s second to none. From securing your tickets and planning your travel, to soaking up the roar of match day and exploring behind the scenes at the iconic Etihad Stadium, we’ve got you covered. Here are 3 unmissable ways to make the most of this magical month: 1. Feel the electric atmosphere at a live home game Secure your spot for the explosive Manchester City vs Brentford Carabao Cup Quarter Final on Wednesday, 17th December. The stakes are high, the action is fierce, and the Etihad will be buzzing with anticipation. Watch two top teams battle it out in the Carabao Cup - one of the biggest prizes in domestic football, and a must-see for any true fan. Starting each August, the Carabao Cup brings together all EFL and Premier League clubs in an exhilarating knockout contest - seven rounds of win-or-go-home drama, culminating in a two-legged semi-final before the finalists take to the Wembley pitch in Spring. Don’t miss your chance to witness breathtaking football under the dazzling floodlights this December. Tickets, Tours & Hospitality Tickets start from just £22.50, with special rates for under-18s from £5. Upgrade your match day with exclusive bar access with premium food, drinks, a laid-back vibe and padded seats for maximum comfort. Or opt for a hospitality ticket and watch the beautiful game in style, enjoying fine dining and the luxurious surroundings of the Etihad. Manchester City Football Club Stadium and Club Tour Manchester City Football Club VIP Stadium Tour 2. Step into the festive magic with Etihad Stadium Tours Go behind the scenes with the Manchester City Stadium Tour, running from 1st to 24th December. Discover secret corners, walk the players’ tunnel, and soak up exclusive festive surprises that make every moment memorable for kids and grown-ups alike! Imagine stepping pitch-side to a sparkling light show, accompanied by carols from the Hallé Youth Choir - with a signature City twist! It’s a Christmas spectacle you won’t forget. Explore the players’ dressing room, take Pep’s seat pitch-side, and interact with your favourite stars, Pep, Haaland, or Ake, thanks to cutting-edge augmented reality in the Press Conference Room. Try the new ‘Beyond the Blue Moon’ VR experience and keep your eyes peeled for Santa’s hidden daily gifts. 19 Dec 2025 - 24 Dec 2025 Christmas Stadium Tours at the Etihad Stadium It’s beginning to look a lot like Christmas at the Etihad Stadium - and visitors can now enjoy one of our Christmas-themed Stadium Tours running throughout December!  From Monday 1st December to Wednesday 24th December, Stadium Tours will continue to gift visitors with a behind the scenes… 3. Enjoy Etihad Stadium after hours for a truly unique Christmas treat Manchester City Football Club will be putting on ‘Etihad Stadium After Hours’ tours on 7th, 12th, 14th, 18th, 22nd, 23rd 5.30PM & 6PM for you to get the full experience of the light display and also an offering of mulled wine or hot Vimto before you start your tour! Not only are these stadium tours a perfect Christmas treat for the little ones, they also offer a touch of City for everyone with a truly immersive experience this Christmas! Secure the perfect gift Don’t forget to swing by the merchandise store - find the perfect present for the football fan in your life and make their Christmas extra special. Travel information With the stadium just a short stroll from Manchester city centre and easily accessible by all forms of transport, it’s the ideal destination for a festive family day out or a football fan’s dream adventure. Getting Around Explore Manchester easily with our travel guide on getting around. Find practical tips, transportation options, and maps for a seamless city exploration. Whether by tram, bus, or foot, our guide ensures you make the most of your visit, navigating Manchester with convenience. Festivals in Manchester Manchester is a city alive with vibrant festivals and events throughout the year. From festive winter wonderlands to lively summer carnivals, there's always something happening in this dynamic city. Explore our guide to Manchester’s festivals and discover the charm of one of the UK's most exciting cultural hubs. Whether you're visiting and you're looking at what festivals and events are on in the city near you, or you're looking for festivals on in Spring, Summer, Autumn, and Winter, there's always something to suit every taste. Explore Manchester's range of festivals and events throughout the year, from Music Festivals and Concerts to Arts and Culture Festivals, and plan your visit to Manchester now. Music Festivals and Concerts Food and Drink Festivals Family-Friendly Festivals Pride Festival in Manchester Art and Culture Events in Manchester Plan Your Visit Music Festivals and Concerts Back to Top of List Manchester is a city synonymous with music, and its festivals reflect this vibrant legacy. The Parklife Festival is a standout event in the city’s summer calendar, drawing music lovers from all over the world. Held in Heaton Park, this multi-day festival features multiple genres, with stages showcasing international acts and up-and-coming talent. Alongside Parklife, the Manchester Jazz Festival brings a different musical energy to the city each spring. Celebrating the best in contemporary jazz, the festival features performances by world-class musicians, from cutting-edge new talent to established jazz legends. The Manchester Folk Festival is another major music event, drawing folk music enthusiasts with its traditional yet contemporary offerings. Artists from around the world perform on indoor and outdoor stages. Sounds of the City is another exciting music festival in Manchester that brings the sounds of live music to multiple venues across the city. Featuring a variety of genres including rock, indie, and alternative. Music fans can enjoy the indie and alternative vibes of Manchester Psych Fest , featuring cutting-edge bands and art installations or RADAR Festival , an indoor, contemporary and modern celebration of progressive music. The Neighbourhood Festival brings the best new talent to stages across the city, offering a thrilling one-day celebration of live music. Manchester is iconic for its music scene, with festivals and events all year round to suit every taste. Food and Drink Festivals Back to Top of List Manchester’s food scene is as diverse as its festivals, offering a year-round celebration of flavours, from craft beers to international cuisine. The Manchester Beer and Cider Festival is a must-attend for craft beer lovers, with over 500 varieties of beer and cider available. With food trucks, live entertainment, and a relaxed atmosphere, it’s a fantastic opportunity to discover new flavours and meet fellow beer enthusiasts. Another key food event is Festa Italiana , which celebrates Italian food, culture, and traditions. Held annually in the heart of Manchester, this festival bring the best of Italy with its wide selection of authentic dishes, from pizza and pasta to regional delicacies. Festa Italiana is a celebration of everything Italian, featuring live Italian music, cultural performances, and cooking demonstrations. In the autumn, Manchester's iconic Oktoberfest brings a Bavarian twist to Manchester’s food and drink scene. This festival is all about celebrating German beer culture, with Munich-style tents offering a variety of traditional beers, hearty German food like bratwurst and pretzels, and lively music. Family-Friendly Festivals Back to Top of List Manchester is a city that caters to all ages, with many family-friendly events throughout the year. The Manchester Day Parade is a colourful spectacle celebrating the city's spirit, with giant puppets, dancers, and community groups. Families can also enjoy the lively atmosphere of the Chinese New Year celebrations, offering entertainment for all. As winter approaches, Manchester's Christmas markets once again provides a magical experience for children and adults alike, with a huge variety of stalls, food, and events! Halloween in the City is an annual family-friendly celebration of all things spooky, with the favourite inflatable monsters adorning building's across the city, as well as a roaming procession of puppets and plenty of opportunities for the family to get involved. This February half-term, Manchester’s public spaces, squares and venues transformed into exciting Play Zones, with games, dancing, activities, crafts, performances and more to enjoy in the first Super Duper Family Festival . Pride Festival in Manchester Back to Top of List Manchester’s Pride Festival is one of the largest and most celebrated LGBTQ+ events in the UK. Held annually, the festival brings together people from all walks of life to celebrate equality, diversity, and inclusion. The highlight of the festival is the Manchester Pride Parade , a vibrant and colorful procession that takes over the city’s streets, with participants donning incredible costumes and waving rainbow flags. Throughout the weekend, you’ll find a range of performances, live music, and events at various venues across the city, including The Village Party in the heart of Manchester’s Gay Village. With a focus on promoting visibility and supporting LGBTQ+ rights, Manchester Pride is a celebration of love, acceptance, and unity. Manchester Pride Festival ​​​​​​Manchester Pride Festival brings thousands of people to the streets of Manchester each year… Art and Culture Events in Manchester Back to Top of List Manchester’s art and culture scene is world-renowned, and its festivals highlight this rich tradition. The biennial Manchester International Festival is a global event, showcasing innovative performances and exhibitions. It's a a dynamic showcase of world-class performances, art installations, and cutting-edge creativity that transforms the city into a cultural playground. The Manchester Histories Festival invites attendees to reflect on the city’s past through engaging storytelling and activities. For those seeking cutting-edge creativity, the Manchester Fringe Festival offers a platform for emerging artists, with theatre, comedy, and performance art taking center stage. The home of football, Manchester is fit to burst with of a number of sporting attractions and events, and with a huge arts and culture scene , it's almost impossible to run out of things to see and do in Greater Manchester. After joining UNESCO's worldwide Creative Cities network as a City of Literature, Manchester's radical literature history has been catapulted into the limelight, with plenty of book-based attractions and events taking place year-round. With a thriving LGBT scene, including the world famous canal street, LGBT travellers won't be disappointed. If it's rolling hills and beautiful countryside you're seeking, Greater Manchester has it in abundance, with over 500 square miles of inspiring countryside, crisscrossed by historical waterways and dotted with picturesque towns and fascinating attractions that make for great days out of the city. Shoryu Ramen Japanese Restaurants in Manchester Looking for the best Japanese food in Manchester? Whether you're craving sushi, a bowl of ramen, or the excitement of teppanyaki, Manchester’s Japanese dining scene has something for everyone. From casual spots to upscale venues offering fresh sashimi and seafood, there’s no shortage of options to satisfy your taste buds. Indulge in classic bento boxes, gyozas, and steaming bowls of ramen paired with saké at some of the city’s top Japanese restaurants. Whether you're a sushi lover or new to Japanese cuisine, you'll find the perfect place to explore Japanese food in Manchester. Top Sushi Spots in Manchester For the best sushi in Manchester, visit Sexy Fish for an upscale, chic dining experience, or enjoy a fun, interactive meal at YO! Sushi with its conveyor belt dining. Shoryu Ramen pairs fresh sushi with their signature ramen dishes, while Sushi Mami offers elegant, freshly made sushi. Unagi stands out as one of the largest sushi bars in the North. Best Ramen in Manchester If you're craving a bowl of rich, flavourful ramen in Manchester, head to Shoryu Ramen for authentic ramen. For a modern twist, Wagamama offers a vibrant atmosphere and a variety of noodle dishes perfect for any ramen lover. Teppanyaki Dining in Manchester For a fun and interactive meal, enjoy teppanyaki in Manchester at Teppanyaki Chinatown or Sapporo Teppanyaki , where talented chefs cook your meal right at the table, creating a dynamic dining experience. Innovative Japanese Flavours If you're looking for something a bit different, Lucky Cat Manchester blends traditional Japanese flavours with contemporary twists, while Peter Street Kitchen offers a fusion of Japanese and global influences. Fusion & Pan-Asian Dining Explore a variety of Asian flavours at Umami , which offers a mix of Pan-Asian dishes alongside traditional Japanese favourites. Tampopo combines Southeast Asian and Japanese influences for a bold fusion dining experience, and Yuzu Japanese Tapas offers a fresh, tapas-style approach to traditional Japanese dishes. Discover the best Japanese restaurants in Manchester and enjoy an unforgettable dining experience, whether you're in the mood for sushi, ramen, or something a bit more adventurous. Local Produce in Manchester Manchester is a city that takes pride in its rich culinary heritage, with a growing emphasis on locally sourced, regional produce. As a local resident or visitor, the city's food scene offers a variety of dining options that showcase the best ingredients from the surrounding areas. Why Choose Locally Sourced Produce in Manchester? Choosing locally sourced food not only supports the region’s farmers and producers but also ensures that your meals are fresher, tastier, and more sustainable. Manchester boasts a diverse range of restaurants, markets, and food spots that focus on showcasing high-quality ingredients from the North of England. From seasonal vegetables to artisan meats, the emphasis is on bringing the best of the region to your plate. Family-Friendly Markets for Local Food Lovers If you're looking for a family-friendly destination to enjoy regional food, look no further than Manchester’s local food markets. Many markets feature independent vendors offering a wide range of local produce, perfect for a weekend outing with the whole family. Enjoy fresh bread, artisanal cheeses, local meats, and much more at these lively hubs, where food and community come together. Altrincham Market House is a great option, home to 10 independent food operators. Here, you’ll find everything from fresh, locally produced foods to gourmet street food, ideal for food lovers of all ages. Independent Cafes and Bars Championing Local Ingredients Manchester's independent cafes and bars are also at the forefront of the city's food movement, incorporating locally sourced ingredients into their menus. Stopping for a quick coffee or enjoying a leisurely lunch, these establishments are dedicated to supporting local farmers and suppliers. All the Shapes in Prestwich is a perfect example of this ethos. As an independent bar and café, it champions local ingredients with every dish and drink served, creating an inviting space to relax and enjoy the region’s finest produce. Intimate Dining Experiences with a Focus on Regional Produce For those seeking an intimate dining experience with a focus on high-quality, locally sourced ingredients, Manchester offers a range of fine dining options. These restaurants take pride in offering seasonal menus, where the dishes are carefully crafted to highlight the best regional produce. Enjoy a memorable evening while learning about the ingredients sourced from nearby farms and suppliers. Support Local Producers at Independent Food Halls Manchester is home to several independent food halls, where local food producers gather to offer fresh, regional produce directly to customers. These food halls provide a space for both established and new producers to showcase their products. Looking for fresh vegetables, cured meats, or handcrafted goods, these venues are a great way to support local businesses and explore the variety of products the region has to offer. Where to Find Fresh, Local Ingredients in Manchester If you're interested in cooking with locally sourced ingredients, Manchester has a few specialty shops and markets dedicated to fresh, regional produce. Visit these spots to find everything from organic vegetables to locally made cheeses and explore the wide variety of goods available straight from the source. These venues are perfect for those who want to cook with the best the region has to offer. Read More Search for something... Continue your Manchester story by exploring further. Independent shops in Manchester Independent shops in Manchester Searching for a unique gift or a statement outfit that turns heads? Manchester’s independent shopping scene is packed with hidden gems, offering everything from vintage fashion and sustainable second-hand finds to limited-edition artwork, handmade crafts, and stylish homeware. Discover Manchester’s best independent shops — you are bound to find something truly distinctive! Independent Speciality Shops Manchester’s speciality stores are perfect for finding unique gifts, rare books, and locally inspired souvenirs. The Sculpts and Manchester Souvenirs celebrate the city with one-of-a-kind designs, while Comic Den in Oldham is a go-to for comic book fans. For independent magazines and hard-to-find titles, visit Rare Mags , and if you're looking for stylish home décor, Still Life Story offers a carefully curated selection of Nordic-inspired homewares. Best Vintage Shops Manchester is a top destination for vintage shopping, offering a wide range of retro clothing, second-hand fashion, and sustainable style. Stockport has become a go-to area for vintage lovers, home to Top Of The Town Vintage , Never Make Waste , and 20th Century Stores , where you can find everything from preloved designer pieces to reworked fashion and rare collectibles. Top Independent Boutiques in Manchester For those looking to shop local, Manchester’s independent boutiques offer a mix of vintage-inspired clothing, contemporary womenswear, and ethical beauty products. Shop sustainable skincare at Amaranth , or discover second-hand gems at the RSPCA Vintage Boutique in the Northern Quarter. Whether you’re after retro tea dresses, statement accessories, or stylish wardrobe staples, Manchester’s boutique scene has something for everyone. Manchester's Best Antique Shops If you're searching for antique furniture, vintage home décor, or rare collectibles, Manchester has a thriving antique shopping scene. Johnson’s Vintage Antiques , located in Levenshulme Antiques Village, is a must-visit for historic finds, while Manchester Craft & Design Centre showcases handcrafted pieces from local artisans. Whether you’re a collector or simply looking for a unique homeware piece, these antique stores offer a treasure trove of discoveries. Read More Search for something... Rapha Shopping in Manchester City Centre Spend your day shopping in Manchester and dive into an unrivalled selection of international brands. Manchester is known around the world for its incredible shopping district. Manchester Arndale fulfils high-street shoppers' dreams with a huge selection of exciting shops, while Selfridges offers an extraordinary shopping experience, with some of the most sought-after designer brands and beauty products. Harvey Nichols and House of Fraser also add to the list of fantastic department stores that the city centre has to offer. The Jewellery Quarter is the perfect place to find that one-of-a-kind gift, with boutiques such as Mappin & Webb Jeweller and Boodles offering stunning collections that are impossible to resist. Take a stroll down King Street , New Cathedral Street or Spinningfields where there are more designer shops, as well as independent alternative stores. Why not visit the Northern Quarter where you can explore more of the independent urban scene, with vintage shops, record stores and local food vendors? The Northern Quarter is also home to the world-famous Afflecks and inspiring arts and craft stores such as Fred Aldous . Looking to spice up your home, look no further. Manchester’s unique style shines through offering hygge-inspired Danish homeware at Søstrene Grene to British lifestyle at Oliver Bonas and Marks & Spencer , where Manchester is home to their flagship store. Visit Molton Brown to find the perfect final touches with luxurious beauty products and fragrances, ideal for gifting yourself and others. Head to The Whisky Shop , where the staff will lead you on a luxurious and educational journey, celebrating the heritage and craftsmanship of their whisky products – you definitely won’t be left empty-handed. For the activewear seeker, Patagonia strives to be an ethical and environmentally friendly sports shop with the perfect attire for climbing, skiing, snowboarding, surfing, fly fishing, trail running and mountain biking. For the avid cyclist, Rapha sells the world’s finest cycling clothing suiting beginners through to professionals. Back The Ultimate Guide to Attending Events at Co-op Live By Visit Manchester on Apr. 18, 2024 4 min read To make your life easier, we have pulled together the ultimate guide of ‘everything you need to know’ when attending events at Co-op Live. From getting to and from the venue, to where to stay and eat nearby, to what other things you can get stuck into across the city. Co-op Live: Setting a New Standard for the City's Entertainment Manchester’s newest music venue and the UK’s biggest indoor arena (23.5k Capacity), Co-op Live has finally opened its doors. Going forward it will be one of Manchester’s main music venues, with the likes of Charli XCX playing this Autumn and Billie Eilish playing in 2025! Click here to find out more. Where is Co-op Live? For those unfamiliar with the location of Co-op Live , it is located East of the city over by Etihad Stadium and right next to Etihad Campus tram stop, a short journey from the city centre on the Ashton-Eccles Metrolink Line. Getting Here: There are several ways you can get to the venue: Tram – Ashton-Eccles Metrolink Line Bus – 53, 216, 230 Train – Avanti West Coast, Northern, TransPennine Express, CrossCountry and Transport for Wales Car – Limited parking spaces On foot – From Piccadilly it takes around 25 minutes For more departure times, journey planning, tickets and travel information click here Tram Information Frequent trams run on the Ashton-Eccles line to the Etihad Campus stop , located directly next to the venue. Trams run every 6 minutes from the city centre, and until 01:00 on Fridays and Saturdays. You can access the Ashton-Eccles Metrolink Line via: Deansgate – Castlefield St. Peter’s Square Piccadilly Gardens Piccadilly Station New Islington Plan your journey via Metrolink Co-op Live also offer their own 'Getting Here' information Getting home: It is advised to plan return travel in advance of arriving at Co-op Live and to take into consideration operating hours across public transport links. Tram For first and last tram times To see the full Network Map for Greater Manchester Other modes of transport Taxis will be available to order from the venue. For other bus options and to find out what is leaving soon, how to plan your journey and buy tickets click here The ‘CityLink’ walking route Plans are still underway to implement interactive lighting installations, busking spots for local talent and pop-up food and drink stalls. This is to offer a safe, well-lit alternative to getting home. With the venue only being a 25-minute walk from Piccadilly it's a great incentive for groups to walk back together. And the CityLink walking route will remain staffed up until 00:00 following all main performances at Co-op Live. Where to stay: For those wanting to experience the most of the city and stay central, Ancoats and Piccadilly would be your best options. Ancoats has become a lively, vibrant neighbourhood full of trendy bars and restaurants. A hidden gem worth visiting, especially if you are visiting for the first time! Additionally, Piccadilly is one of Manchester’s key central points, and allows you to access any destination, venue, or attraction within minutes. Accommodation: Sometimes it can be stressful looking for accommodation or you just might not know where to start... Below we have pulled together a list of hotels that are close to or near transport links to the venue. A 5-minute walk… Motel One There are three Motel One Hotels across the city – Royal Exchange, St. Peter’s Square and… Maldron Hotel Manchester City Centre Within walking distance of Oxford Road train station and 5-minutes from St. Peter’s Square. The Reach Piccadilly A 4-minute walk away from Piccadilly train station, within 5-minutes of Piccadilly Gardens. The Marriott Hotel Piccadilly The Marriott Hotel is a 2-minute walk from Piccadilly Station and right next to the CityLink getting… For more information head to our ‘Where to Stay’ page. Visit Manchester Well We take climate change seriously in Manchester, so we want everyone who comes to our great region to be able to Visit Manchester Well. With our walkable city, extensive public transport network, farm to table eating, accredited accommodation, and brilliant local businesses and attractions, it’s easy to make your stay here a sustainable one. Here you’ll find handy tips on how your stay with us can make the smallest impact on the environment possible, with information on sustainable hotels, restaurants, attractions, transport, shops, days out, and much more. Help us reach our target of being a Net Zero city by 2038 by having a positive impact during your stay. Smithills Hall Read More Explore Bolton There are many reasons why you would come to Visit Bolton, so where to start! Firstly, you can enjoy Bolton’s culture and there is lots of it! They have a staggering six theatres including the Octagon , a highly regarded producing theatre across the country, the amazing Bolton Albert Halls which has been a key part of cultural enjoyment for over 100 years and the historic Victoria Halls and Bolton Little Theatre. Culture is knitted into the town’s urban environment with the stunning architecture of Le Mans Crescent providing a backdrop to popular film and TV productions like Peaky Blinders, The Ipcress File, Passenger and A Gentleman in Moscow, giving us the nickname the ‘Hollywood of the North’. The centre is also home to the museum with one of the largest collections of Egyptology outside London as well as the ever-popular aquarium. They have a range of public spaces like Victoria Square and Queens Park which play host to national events such as the annual Bolton Food and Drink Festival which attracts over 500,000 each year, IRONMAN weekend and the Right to Roam festival. Enjoy a fantastic range of shopping destinations, including Market Place Shopping Centre with a host of high street shops and independent brands. They are also proud to have the Middlebrook Retail Park which is one of the largest leisure, sports, and retail venues in the country. Of course, you may just want to get in touch with nature in their great outdoors walking, cycling or just relaxing on the West Pennine Moors or Rivington Pike . Portland Basin Museum, Tameside Read More Explore Tameside Tameside stretches eastward from Manchester to the fringes of the Peak District National Park. Its landscape encompasses urban centres, moorland and the spectacular vistas of Werneth Low . The borough was created in 1974 and includes Ashton-under-Lyne, Audenshaw, Denton, Droylsden, Dukinfield, Hyde, Longdendale, Mossley and Stalybridge. It takes its name from the River Tame which was the traditional border between Lancashire and Cheshire. Tameside was at the heart of the Industrial Revolution and was once a centre for cotton, engineering, coal mining and hatting. Among the famous personalities born in the borough are Sir Geoff Hurst, Mick Hucknall, Kathy Staff, Howard Donald and Ricky Hatton. Top attractions include: Portland Basin Museum , a family-friendly attraction dedicated to telling the story of the history of Tameside across the past 200 years; the Museum of the Manchester Regiment ; Werneth Low Country Park; Park Bridge Heritage Centre ; and Ashton Market , one of the oldest and largest markets in the region. The Trafford Centre Shopping at the Trafford Centre The Trafford Centre is a world-renowned shopping and entertainment complex, located just 5 miles from Manchester city centre. With over 200 stores, stunning granite and marble boulevards, and a vibrant mix of shopping, dining, and entertainment, it’s the perfect destination for a day out. Shop High Street Favourites & Luxury Brands Whether you're looking for high street fashion, luxury labels, or everyday essentials, The Trafford Centre has it all. Explore a range of stores and shops, from must-have brands to department stores, covering fashion, beauty, electronics, and homeware. Here's a snapshot of what you find: Selfridges John Lewis Next River Island Zara Lush Sephora Restaurants & Dining Options at the Trafford Centre With a vast selection of restaurants, cafés, and food outlets, there’s something for every taste. Enjoy international cuisine, family-friendly dining, and quick bites at the Orient food court. Halal options are also available, catering to diverse dietary needs. Trafford Centre Entertainment & Attractions for All Ages The Trafford Centre is more than just shopping—it’s a leisure hub. Catch the latest films at the cinema, enjoy arcade games, or visit exciting attractions for the whole family to enjoy. If you're here for family fun, date nights, or group outings, there’s plenty to explore. SEA LIFE Manchester Legoland Discovery Centre ODEON Paradise Island Adventure Golf Easy Access from Manchester & Free Parking Getting to The Trafford Centre is simple. Travel by tram or bus from the city centre, or arrive via major stations like Manchester Piccadilly, Oxford Road, or Victoria. If you’re driving, ample parking makes your visit even more convenient. Opening Hours & Best Times to Visit Most stores are open until 10 PM on weekdays, with slightly earlier closing times on weekends. Dining and entertainment venues may have slightly different hours, so it’s always best to check in advance. Plan Your Visit to The Trafford Centre Opened in 1998, The Trafford Centre continues to be one of Manchester’s top shopping and leisure destinations. Marple, Stockport Explore Stockport Situated just 10-minutes south of Manchester city centre by train, Stockport is well worth a visit. Over the past couple of years, Stockport has seen a wealth of independent restaurants, bars, shops, art and more, with the old town gaining a reputation as ‘one of the coolest little corners of the country'. There’s a hive of activity around Little and Great Underbanks, two historic streets situated next to Stockport Market Place. The Underbanks are fast becoming well known for their array of independent stores and traders. Here, you’ll find stores such as Still Life Story and Squound, where you can pick up a unique souvenir, check out clothing stores Old Town General Stores and Emiko Studio, or browse the shelves of Rare Mags, where you’ll be sure to discover all sorts of titles, books and magazines. There is a growing food and drink scene in Stockport, which is headlined by the small but popular Where the Light Gets In , known for its seasonal, local, no-menu approach to cooking. Other places to check out include The Produce Hall with a number of food hall style vendors set inside a 160-year old market building, Ate Days a Week , which has gained a cult reputation for its pun-filled menu and pies; Cherry Jam for great cocktails and , which offers a weekly pop-up of traders in Stockport’s Old Town. Recent announcements include Bohemian Arts Club , a new cocktail bar led by Blossom’s singer Tom Ogden. Foodie Friday, which offers a monthly street food event with local traders, craft ales and live music at Stockport Market. The borough, which is laced with history, was made famous in the 19th Century as the home of the nation’s hatting industry. Visitors are able to celebrate the town’s unique history in the Hat Works Museum, the UK’s only dedicated hatting museum. Alongside the cobbled streets and old architecture, be sure to pay a visit to the 15th Century Staircase House, Stockport Air Raid Shelters, Bramall Hall and Stockport Viaduct, which is the largest brick structure in the UK. The Northern Quarter Shopping in the Northern Quarter Manchester’s Northern Quarter is a hub for independent shops and unique boutiques, offering a diverse shopping experience. Known for its creative atmosphere, the NQ boasts an eclectic range of shops in Manchester, from vintage stores to contemporary fashion outlets. Whether you’re hunting for quirky clothing, rare collectibles, or stylish accessories, the Northern Quarter is the ultimate destination for those seeking one-of-a-kind finds in the heart of Manchester. Afflecks: A Must-Visit for Vintage Lovers A standout destination in Northern Quarter shopping is Afflecks Palace , an iconic shopping centre known for its wide array of alternative fashion and vintage treasures. Filled with independent stalls, Afflecks is a must-see for anyone seeking retro clothing, unique jewellery, and quirky trinkets. Its vibrant atmosphere and variety of goods make it a cornerstone of shopping in the Northern Quarter, offering something for everyone in the heart of Manchester. Norther Quarter’s Best Vintage Shops The Northern Quarter is home to some of the best vintage shops in Manchester, offering everything from retro clothing to rare collectibles. Whether you're after a classic leather jacket, a vintage tee, or unique accessories, the area’s vintage stores are packed with timeless finds that capture the charm of bygone eras. These shops are perfect for anyone who loves discovering hidden gems and one-of-a-kind items that reflect Manchester’s creative spirit. Streetwear in Northern Quarter If you’re looking for high-quality streetwear brands in the Northern Quarter, don’t miss out on stores featuring Carhartt and Fred Perry . These iconic labels offer a mix of streetwear and timeless styles, providing a modern twist on Manchester’s fashion scene. Explore Northern Quarter Shopping Whether you’re browsing the shops in Northern Quarter for vintage treasures, designer fashion, or unique collectibles, there’s something for everyone in this creative corner of Manchester. Back Manchester named as one of the best places to visit in 2024 by The New York Times By Visit Manchester on Jan. 10, 2024 2 min read Manchester has been selected by The New York Times to feature in its annual ‘52 Places to Go’ list for 2024 . The US publication’s annual list of where to travel features Manchester as a ‘music-mad city’, selecting it at number 12 in the global destinations it recommends visiting in the year ahead . Major musical milestones for the city are cited, including the opening of Co-Op Live, which will be the UK’s biggest music venue when it opens in April with a 23,500-capacity venue, and the Worldwide Music Expo (WOMEX), which will bring over 2,600 music professionals to the city in October. The article also mentions the reopening of Band on the Wall, Manchester’s oldest music venue, and New Century, one of the latest new venues to open, as reasons for the city’s inclusion in the prestigious list. The listing opens by stating: “Music has long been at the core of Manchester’s gritty soul, from Joy Division and the Stone Roses to Oasis and, now, Harry Styles, who is backing Britain’s largest new music arena, Co-op Live, set to open in April.” Recent cultural investments in the city are mentioned, including Aviva Studios, which opened as the home of Factory International in October 2023, and large-scale events including Beyond The Music, which brings a four-day music festival and conference to the city’s venues from 11-14 October 2024. Whilst already well-known for its rich music history and heritage, in recent years Greater Manchester has carved out a solid reputation as a place to enjoy live music. In addition to year-round gigs and performances at venues of all shape and size, Manchester’s spring and summer months are packed with outdoor concert series and festivals held at the city’s sporting stadiums, Castlefield Bowl, and Heaton and Wythenshawe Parks, then the city becomes a clubbing mecca throughout autumn and winter months at venues like Warehouse Project. The city’s reputation for a wider genre of music has also strengthened in recent years – the beloved Hallé Orchestra will this year welcome a new Principal Conductor and Artistic Director, Kahchun Wong, taking over from Sir Mark Elder who has led the orchestra for 24 years. In March, Manchester will host the Royal Philharmonic Society Awards – ‘the biggest night in UK classical music’ – for the first time outside of London. And it was announced in late 2023 that the English National Opera will relocate its main base from London to Manchester by 2029. Manchester’s inclusion in the global list places it alongside destinations including Singapore, Paris, Brisbane, and Vienna, and is the only destination in England to be included in the list of 52 locations . Find out more Unmissable Music in Manchester From Parklife to Warehouse Project and Pride to ground-breaking performances in offbeat venues including the White Hotel and Hidden, Manchester is the home of Unmissable Music. Mediacity and The Quays Explore Salford Ideally located where Salford meets Manchester on the banks of the River Irwell, Salford showcases the very best in heritage, arts, culture, sport, shopping, relaxation and stunning scenery. The city of Salford is a city and metropolitan borough of Greater Manchester made up of the towns of Salford, Eccles, Swinton, Pendlebury, Walkden and Irlam. Discover Salford's fascinating heritage through many historic places of interest both on land and water such as the picturesque Worsley village and Bridgewater Canal which played a pivotal part in the industrial revolution. Other highlights include Ordsall Hall , the haunted Grade 1 listed Tudor house, Salford Lads' Club where visitors from across the globe relive 'The Smiths' legacy and one of the most unusual libraries in the world - the Working Class Movement Library . Salford's contribution to world cuisine goes way beyond the Eccles cake with a wide range of award winning venues which have put the city on the national map. With over 60 parks and open spaces, visitors to Salford can explore open woodland and meadows to enjoy vibrant wildlife, lakeside walks and picnics. The Quays , Greater Manchester’s waterfront destination boasts spectacular architecture with The Lowry , Imperial War Museum North and MediaCityUK as well as outlet shopping, watersports, cruises and sport. With lots of things to see and do, explore and experience, make sure you plan a visit to Salford. What's on at AO Arena Experience the Best Events at AO Arena in Manchester Step into the heart of Manchester's entertainment scene at the AO Arena , where unforgettable events and electrifying performances take center stage. This iconic venue, formerly known as the Manchester Arena, stands as one of the largest and most renowned indoor arenas in Europe. Boasting a capacity to host mega concerts, thrilling sporting events, and spectacular shows, the AO Arena has become synonymous with unparalleled entertainment experiences. From chart-topping music acts to world-class sporting showdowns, the arena consistently attracts a diverse array of events that cater to a broad spectrum of interests. Located in the heart of the city, the AO Arena stands as a testament to Manchester's reputation as a cultural and entertainment powerhouse, drawing crowds from near and far to revel in the magic of live performances. AO Arena Seating Plan View the AO Arena seating plan here . Visitor Information and Tips The AO Arena is located at Manchester Victoria Station which has both train and tram connections. The Lowry Theatre Read More Art and culture in Manchester Spend a day in Manchester and it rapidly becomes apparent just how much the city has reinvented its industrial past into a new, trendsetting present - and an ambitious future. Today, the listed buildings of the world’s first inter-city passenger railway house the Science & Industry Museum , a globally important heritage site, while the monumental columns of a former trading hall - once an international cotton exchange - hold up the UK’s biggest theatre in the round at the Royal Exchange . Manchester’s world-class art and textiles collections, held by Manchester Art Gallery and the redeveloped Whitworth , were amassed as a result of the city’s great post-industrial wealth and world standing - without which, exceptional buildings such as the Grade I listed John Rylands Library would not have been possible. The Quays - now home to MediaCityUK, the largest media hub in Europe, national museum IWM North and Manchester’s most visited cultural attraction The Lowry - is an area that has been transformed from the busiest industrial dock in the UK, to a 21st century cultural centre in just over 100 years. Of course Manchester is synonomous with football and you’ll find world-class collections at the National Football Museum . Italian Restaurants in Manchester Manchester has had an Italian community from the nineteenth century when many Italians moved to Manchester from north-western and southern Italy. It's no surprise then that Manchester's Italian restaurants are many and ' molto buoni '. Manchester city centre and the surrounding areas have the usual selection of chain Italian restaurants, like Pizza Express , Zizzi , so you can always be gauranteed a good meal at great value. The independant restaurant scene is flourishing with several Italian restaurants consistently topping the 'best of' lists. Some of the highlights are Salvi's Cucina , inspired by the laid back Italian eateries found dotting the streets of Naples, Don Giovanni , Manchester's oldest independently owned Italian restaurant and, of course, the famous Cibo , set in a Grade II listed building in Manchester's popular King Street. From the bustling streets of Manchester city centre to the charming market towns and designer outlets, the region offers a diverse array of shopping opportunities. Explore the iconic Manchester Arndale for a wide range of high-street brands or wander through the Northern Quarter's independent boutiques for unique finds. For those seeking luxury, The Trafford Centre , one of Europe's largest shopping malls, is a must-visit destination. And don’t forget to stroll down the prestigious King Street , known for its historic architecture and a selection of high-end designer boutiques, making it a mecca for luxury shopping in Greater Manchester. Ullswater Cruise, Lake District © Rich J Jones & Visit England Manchester - Gateway to the North Thanks to our position in the heart of the country, Manchester is the gateway to the north of England and Wales so why not expand your Manchester visit even further with a day trip or excursion . We're surrounded by beautiful countryside , including the Lake District. the Peak District and Wales, and cosmopolitan cities such as Chester, Durham, Leeds, Liverpool, Newcastle and York. From heritage and history and arts and culture to food and drink and shopping , the North has it all. See great sports and events and visit the many incredible family attractions in the north of England and Wales. Use our map to see what's nearby or check out the box office to purchase tickets for attractions and events. Discover some of Northern England and Wales' top attractions and events with our map below. Travelling around Northern England Visit the cities of Durham, Newcastle, Liverpool, Leeds and Hull by train with a North of England 4 in 8-Day Rover ticket . The ticket is valid for 8 days and within that time you will be allowed 4 days of unlimited travel so you can travel to each city to explore its cultural offer. Sit back, relax and enjoy the beautiful countryside as you travel through the north of England. Day Trips and Excursions Manchester is an ideal base for day trips to explore the beautiful countryside, cities, culture and history of northern England.  Enjoy a lake steamer trip and discover Beatrix Potter’s home in the Lake District or head to the waterfront at Liverpool. Delight in the seasonal blooms at Dunham Massey , where the picturesque gardens offer a tranquil retreat for families to explore. For the football fanatics, the National Football Museum hosts interactive exhibits and football-themed activities that blend sports history with entertainment. Embrace the outdoors at Platt Fields Park , offering playgrounds, nature trails, and open spaces for a delightful family picnic. Rochdale Pioneer's Museum Read More Explore Rochdale Rochdale is Greater Manchester's Town of Culture where a spectacular calendar of festivals, performances, exhibitions and art making offers fantastic opportunities for lots of amazing days out. The title, awarded by the Greater Manchester Combined Authority, celebrates the town’s rich history, creativity, talent and diverse arts scene. Rochdale is building on the town’s cultural capital and international reputation as the home of the co-operative movement with an ambitious programme that runs until March 2026. ‘People power’ will be centre stage, with residents helping to plan, develop and deliver much of the line-up of creative activity alongside a number of big events. Rich History and Cultural Gems Rochdale boasts a robust calendar of events, from the Feel Good Music Festival to Ignite Fire Festival, and Feel Good Family Picnics. The magnificent Town Hall and the vibrant Baillie Street Quarter showcase the town’s heritage. Enjoy cosy folk nights or explore inspiring museums and small theatre spaces. Outdoor Adventures Rochdale is perfect for outdoor enthusiasts with key beauty spots like Hollingworth Lake, Blackstone Edge, and a network of reservoirs and canals. These spots offer sailing, watersports, hiking, cycling, and more. There are also campsites and glamping pods for those who love the fresh air and adventure. Food and Drink The town features a host of eateries, from traditional pub grub to South Asian cuisine on Milkstone Road. Enjoy local favourites like The Baum and The Flying Horse, or visit new hotspots like Spotland Mills with its microbreweries and gin distilleries. Family-Friendly Activities Rochdale offers a range of family-friendly attractions, including parks, ten-pin bowling, golf, cinemas, and the East Lancashire Railway. Engage in art clubs, theatre groups, and circus arts, or explore museums like the Rochdale Pioneers Museum and Touchstones. Shopping The historic streets of Rochdale’s town centres are perfect for shopping. From high street names to independent shops, markets, and cafes, there's something for everyone. The Pennines provide a beautiful backdrop to Littleborough's historic centre, ideal for finding unique gifts. Whether you’re a history buff, outdoor adventurer, food lover, or family, Rochdale has something to offer everyone. Visit Rochdale and experience its rich culture and community spirit. Cycling in Castlefield Bike hire in Manchester If you’re looking for a way to get around Manchester whilst keeping fit, why not hire a bicycle for your time in the city. Manchester is bike-friendly with many marked cycle lanes and dedicated routes throughout the city centre and beyond. Bee Network Cycle Hire Transport for Greater Manchester, working in partnership with Manchester City Council, Salford City Council and Trafford Council, launched Greater Manchester's first publicly operated, self-service, 24/7 cycle hire scheme in November 2021. ​ Cycle hire stations, which have been placed across parts of Manchester, Salford and Trafford are typically be between 300-500m apart, ensuring that people are never more than a five-minute walk from a bicycle. The scheme, rolling out in stages, introduced 1,500 bikes—including e-bikes—available to the public, providing hundreds of thousands of residents, workers, and visitors with an affordable, convenient, and quick way to get around More information can be found at the Bee Network website. Manchester Bike Hire Hire a bike for your time in the city with Manchester Bike Hire. From manual bikes to electric, they offer something to suit everyone. You can also join a guided tour if you’ve got some time to spare and don’t want to worry about getting lost. Find out more . Blooms & Bicycles Blooms & Bicycles is a community-based bicycle hire company from Manchester with a difference. Offering floral bicycle tours around the city and locally sourced bicycle picnic hamper packages, the combination of retro-styled Pashley bicycles, wicker baskets, soft wool picnic blankets, Roberts Revival portable leather radios, fresh flowers and Canterbury Classics books are put together to help you create the memories of a lifetime. Find out more . Travel information Getting Around Explore Manchester easily with our travel guide on getting around. Cheshire Oaks Designer Outlet Outlet Centres in Manchester Looking to grab designer brands at unbeatable prices? Manchester is home to several fantastic outlet centres where you can shop for your favourite labels at a fraction of the cost. Whether you’re after last season’s styles, overstock items, or simply love a bargain, these outlet destinations offer premium brands without the hefty price tag. Why Shop at Outlets? Outlets are a haven for budget-conscious shoppers. They provide huge discounts on brand-name products, meaning you can shop quality clothing, shoes, accessories and homeware at significantly reduced prices. Many retailers use outlets to sell overstock or past-season items, making them a great place to find a bargain from top designers. Outlet Shopping Centres Near Manchester Cheshire Oaks Designer Outlet For a premium shopping experience, Cheshire Oaks Designer Outlet is a must-visit. Just a 50-minute drive from Manchester city centre, this shopping haven boasts Tommy Hilfiger, Coach, Crocs, and many other renowned brands under one roof. With discounts of up to 60% off retail prices, it’s the ideal spot for luxury lovers on a budget. Quayside MediaCityUK Located in Salford Quays, Quayside MediaCityUK is one of the closest and most convenient outlets to Manchester. Home to high-street and designer discount stores like Next Outlet and M&S Outlet, this centre is perfect for picking up quality fashion at discounted prices. The best way to reach Quayside MediaCityUK from Manchester city centre is by tram, which takes approximately 20 minutes and costs between £2 - £3. Traders Outlet, Altrincham Looking for something unique? Traders Outlet in Altrincham is a hidden gem, housing over 40 local independent concessions. If you love supporting small businesses and discovering one-of-a-kind pieces, this is the place for you. From boutique fashion to artisan gifts, you’ll find plenty of treasures at great prices. Plan Your Next Shopping Trip If you're after designer discounts or independent finds, Manchester’s outlet shopping scene has something for everyone. Plan your visit and grab some fantastic deals! Manchester United Based in Manchester, England, Manchester United Football Club is one of the most iconic and successful football clubs in the world, with a rich history and a passionate global following. A giant of the Premier League, United's legacy stretches across decades of triumphs and legendary players. Whether you're a devoted Red Devil or visiting the city to take in the electric football atmosphere, here’s everything you need to know - from securing match tickets and navigating travel, to watching a game at the historic Old Trafford and exploring behind the scenes at the Theatre of Dreams. History of Manchester United Matchday tickets, tours & hospitality Where to stay near Old Trafford Explore Manchester United's premier league fixtures How to get to Old Trafford Key matchday information Pre-match entertainment Manchester United Women History of Manchester United Back to Top of List Manchester United Football Club, often known as Man United or simply United, is one of the most famous football clubs in the world. Based in Trafford , Greater Manchester, the club was founded in 1878 as Newton Heath and renamed Manchester United in 1902. They’ve played at Old Trafford since 1910 and currently compete in the Premier League, the top division of English football. Known as the 'Red Devils,' Manchester United has a rich history of success. Under legendary manager Sir Alex Ferguson, the club won 38 major trophies in 27 years, including five Premier League titles, the UEFA Champions League, and five FA Cups. Manchester United has been home to some of the greatest football players of all time. George Best dazzled in the 1960s with his flair and skill. Bobby Charlton, became a symbol of resilience and is one of the club’s top scorers. Eric Cantona’s arrival in the 1990s helped spark a new era of dominance. Academy legends Ryan Giggs and Paul Scholes defined consistency and loyalty, while Cristiano Ronaldo emerged as a global superstar during his first spell at the club. With decades of football excellence, legendary players, and global fan support, Manchester United continues to be a powerhouse in world football. Discover more Matchday tickets, tours & hospitality Back to Top of List Match day tickets Looking to buy Manchester United tickets? Tickets for games at Old Trafford are available exclusively to Official Members through their ticketing website . To purchase, simply create an online account, log in, and browse upcoming fixtures. All tickets are digital and accessible through the official Manchester United App for a seamless matchday experience. Find out more Hospitality Experience Manchester United in style with Matchday Hospitality at Old Trafford. From luxury lounges like the Warwick Suite and No.7 Suite to vibrant, informal settings like the Red Café and Victoria Warehouse , there’s a hospitality package to suit every fan. Enjoy premium seats, all-inclusive dining and drinks, exclusive entertainment, and unforgettable matchday experiences. Find out more Old Trafford tours Step inside Old Trafford and experience the history of Manchester United like never before. From walking through the players’ tunnel to exploring the iconic dressing rooms, the Old Trafford Tour & Museum takes you behind the scenes of one of football’s most legendary clubs. Choose from a full Stadium Tour, an exclusive Legend Tour with a Manchester United great, or a shorter Look-In Tour for those short on time. The experience is designed to be accessible for all fans, with dedicated British Sign Language tours and facilities to support visitors with additional needs. Official Members can enjoy up to 50% off tickets. Manchester United Stadium and Club Tour Where to stay near Old Trafford Back to Top of List There are plenty of great places to stay near Old Trafford and across Manchester city centre. Nearby hotel recommendations: Holiday Inn MediaCity Hilton Garden Inn Manchester Emirates Old Trafford Motel One Another top pick is Hotel Football , a Tribute Portfolio Hotel with 133 rooms, located directly opposite Manchester United’s Old Trafford stadium and a short walk from Emirates Old Trafford cricket ground . Famous for its rooftop 5-a-side football pitch, it’s a must-visit for football fans, families, and business travellers. Hotel Football offers the Ultimate Manchester Football Package, including a stadium tour, entry to the National Football Museum , and an overnight stay for a hassle-free football getaway in Manchester. Holiday Inn MediaCity Hilton Garden Inn Manchester Emirates Old Trafford Motel One Hotel Football Explore Manchester United's premier league fixtures Back to Top of List Planning your visit around a match? Check the latest Manchester United's Premier League Fixtures. How to get to Old Trafford Back to Top of List Old Trafford, home of Manchester United, is located just a couple of miles southwest of Manchester city centre and is easily accessible by public transport, making it simple to get to your next Man U game. By tram Several tram stops are within easy walking distance of the ground: Old Trafford (Bury - Altrincham line) Trafford Bar (Rochdale/Shaw and Crompton, East Didsbury, and Manchester Airport lines) Wharfside (Trafford Park line) Exchange Quay (Eccles/Ashton lines) How to use the trams: Use contactless tap-in/tap-out at tram stops A return ticket from the city centre is around £3.50 for adults Family travelcards are available from tram ticket machines Post-match travel advice: After the match, trams traveling towards Manchester city centre on the Trafford Park line will not stop at Imperial War Museum . Instead, fans should use the Wharfside stop to catch trams back to the city centre or consider walking to Exchange Quay. To help reduce congestion, it is recommended that fans heading to Altrincham use the Old Trafford stop after the game. This helps ease crowding at Trafford Bar, particularly for those traveling on the East Didsbury and Manchester Airport lines. Check the Metrolink network map and service updates before travelling. By bus If you’re planning to travel to Old Trafford by bus, the easiest way is to use one of these Bee Network bus services: Bus 250 Bus 255 Bus 256 Bus 263 Bus X50 These buses will bring you closest to the stadium. You can check out the nearest bus stops to Old Trafford using our dedicated map. Bus Ticket Information – Bee Network Hopper Ticket You can buy a Bee Bus single ‘hopper’ ticket for just: £2 for adults £1 for children You can only buy this ticket on the bus. The hopper ticket lets you take one trip, and then you can use it on other Bee Network buses for free within 60 minutes. Post-Match Shuttle Bus Service After the match, there will be 15 shuttle buses operating a fast ‘load and go’ service from Chester Road (outside the Ford garage, near Throstles Green). These buses will take you straight to Manchester city centre, dropping off at: Deansgate-Castlefield Portland Street Piccadilly Gardens By car If you're driving to Old Trafford on match day, be prepared for heavy traffic. Road congestion usually builds up around 2 hours before kick-off as fans head to the stadium. Here’s how much extra journey time you should plan for, depending on where you’re coming from: From the west of Manchester → Add 20 minutes to your journey. From the east (via Mancunian Way) → Add 15 minutes. From the south (M60 Junction 7 via A56 Chester Road) → Expect up to 30 minutes extra. For the quickest access to official car parks, use Parkway and Wharfside Way (M60 Junction 9). Match Day Car Parking at Old Trafford Official car parking at Old Trafford is available and can be booked online via the Manchester United website. If you’re parking elsewhere, please ensure you park responsibly and respectfully, allowing other road users and local residents to move freely in and out of the area. For more details on match day parking options, visit the Manchester United website . Key matchday information Back to Top of List Old Trafford is Fully Cashless Old Trafford operates as a fully cashless stadium. All purchases at food and drink kiosks, official club shops, and other concession points must be made using card or contactless payment methods Security & Bag Policy To ensure a safe and smooth entry, Manchester United advises all supporters to arrive early, with turnstiles opening two to three hours before kick-off. Security checks are in place at all entrances. Bag Policy Highlights: Only small handheld bags no larger than 20cm x 15cm x 5cm (approximately A5 size) are permitted. Backpacks, rucksacks, suitcases, and large handbags exceeding these dimensions are strictly prohibited. Essential medical bags and infant care bags are allowed but must be declared for additional screening. Secure bag drop facilities are available at the following car parks: E2 Car Park (a dedicated area for away supporters) N2 Car Park W2 Cosgrove Car Park Manchester United Foundation Car Park The service costs £5 per item. Stay Updated on Matchdays For real-time updates on matchday operations, security measures, and fan information, supporters are encouraged to follow Manchester United’s official website and social media channels: Website: manutd.com X (formerly Twitter): @ManUtd Learn more Pre-match entertainment Back to Top of List While Manchester United does not operate an official fan zone on matchdays, the area around Old Trafford comes alive with bustling pubs and lively supporter gatherings that create a unique pre-match atmosphere. On Manchester United match days, the area around Old Trafford is packed with fans heading to their favourite spots before kick-off. Pubs like The Bishop Blaize, The Tollgate, and The Trafford are always busy, with supporters gathering for a few pints and singing in the streets on the way to the stadium. For a more laid-back pre-match, Cafe Football at Hotel Football serves food and drinks right next to the ground, making it a popular choice for families and groups. Over in MediaCity, Kargo offers a casual spot with street food and outdoor seating, while Matchstick Man, by Salford Quays Tram Stop , provides a quieter place to grab a drink by the water before the walk to Old Trafford. Kargo MKT Explore Kargo MKT, a diverse food hall in Salford offering an array of local and international flavours. Located at MediaCity & The Quays, it provides a communal setting for visitors to enjoy a variety of dishes crafted by talented chefs and food vendors. Whether you're in the mood for… Manchester United Women Back to Top of List Since forming in 2018, Manchester United Women have made huge strides in a short space of time. The team won the Championship in their first season and have been competing at the top of the Women’s Super League ever since. Under head coach Marc Skinner, the Reds achieved their best-ever league finish in 2022/23, securing second place and qualifying for the UEFA Women’s Champions League for the first time. That same season also saw the team reach their first Women’s FA Cup final at Wembley. Learn about Man United Women Search for something... Continue your Manchester story by exploring further. Things To Do in Manchester Whether you’re seeking culture, nightlife, history, or just good fun, there are plenty of things to do in Manchester. Be absorbed by the beautiful attractions such as the gothic architecture at John Rylands Library and Manchester Cathedral ; take in fine art at Manchester Art Gallery and the Whitworth ; discover history, old and new, at Manchester Museum and the Imperial War Museum North ; see contemporary arts redefined at HOME ; or even learn to ski at Chill Factore . Of course, Manchester is synonymous with football; it’s written in our DNA. So make some time to make a tour of the grounds of Manchester United and Manchester City , and discover the social history of the beautiful game at the National Football Museum . You can guarantee a ticket to any Manchester United home game with a Matchday VIP Experience. For those who enjoy getting active , a short journey from the city centre provides access to beautiful walks within Greater Manchester , such as Hollingworth Lake , Heaton Park , Sale Water Park and Haigh Hall . And if you need to keep the kids entertained, there are plenty of things to do in Manchester. The Science and Industry Museum , Play Factore and LEGOLAND Discovery Centre are great fun for all the family. Manchester is renowned for its entertainment , with a plethora of cinemas , theatre and legendary clubs for great night-time amusement. There are many opportunities to go sightseeing in Greater Manchester, with a number of walking tours , bus and taxi tours such as the Sightseeing Manchester Bus Tour . As the Gateway to the North , its easy to expand your Manchester visit even further with a trip to the beautiful countryside, including the Lake District and the Peak District, and cosmopolitan cities such as Chester, Leeds, Liverpool, Newcastle and York. Manchester City stadium tour Read More Sport in Manchester Well-known for its world-famous football teams, Manchester has much more to offer in the sporting world. Starting with football, Manchester is home to two world-famous and iconic football teams; Manchester City and Manchester United. Though a local rivalry exists, the two teams have propelled Manchester onto the global stage in world football. Manchester United are at home in Old Trafford, the largest club football stadium in the UK, whilst Manchester City occupy the recently expanded Etihad Stadium, which was originally built for the 2002 Commonwealth Games. With both clubs offering stadium and club tours, as well as unique match day experiences, a visit is a must for any sports fan visiting Manchester. As well as this, Manchester also has a number of lower league professional teams, including Rochdale, Oldham, Bolton, and Wigan. Emirates Old Trafford , home of Lancashire Cricket Club is a world-class sporting venue. With over 150 years of history the Club is one of the most sought-after venues for international cricket and has witnessed some of the sport’s most iconic moments. Manchester has a huge influence over some of the UK’s best known Olympians and Paralympians. Swimming and cycling world-champion Paralympian Dame Sarah Storey, Taekwondo stars Jade Jones and Lutalo Muhammed, cyling gold medallists Jason Kenny and Laura Trott, relay medallist Kelly Massey, and 2016 gold-medallist hockey captain Kate Richardson-Walsh MBE all either live or train in Manchester. Manchester is also the home to many other well-known sports teams. The Manchester Giants Basketball team reformed in 2011, and have reclaimed their place in the professional British Basketball League. Previously one of the largest clubs in UK basketball, Manchester Giants have rekindled the thriving amateur basketball scene in the region. Playing their home games at the Lucozade Powerleague Sportsdome opposite to Old Trafford, Manchester Giants offer the chance to catch professional basketball in the heart of Manchester. Another team to recently reform is the Manchester Storm ice hockey team. Once one of Europe’s best supported teams, Manchester Storm reformed in 2015 and play in the Elite Ice Hockey League (EIHL), playing home games at the Altrincham Ice Dome. Sportsbreaks.com offer personalised ticket, travel and hotel packages and give you access to a wide range of sporting events across the globe, including Manchester United and Emirates Old Trafford. Travelling around the North of England Visit 5 cities across 8-days with the North of England Cities Experience Hull, Leeds, Manchester, Liverpool, & Newcastle, five very dynamic, postindustrial cities in the North of England, founded on the forces of traditional industry, and now being defined by a bold cultural renaissance. Nowhere else in England is there a concentration of iconic urban destinations undergoing such a dynamic transformation. Through art, music, literature, theatre, dance, architecture, cafes, restaurants, nightlife, festivals and events these cities offer experiences housed in richly varied regenerated environments. Each city is naturally unique and has its own personality, yet as a group they combine to deliver a compelling travel offer that is not only culturally rich but also effortlessly travelled and experienced. All the cities are walk-able and have a range of accommodation, boutique to high street shopping, and local & independent food and drink. Witness the transformation for yourself & soak up the culture, heritage, history, regeneration and transformation of England’s northern cities. Beginning in any city, the TransPennine Express ‘North of England City Experience’ ticket connects all these cities with frequent services bringing you into the heart of your destination. Travel at your own pace with one easy-to-buy rail ticket enabling 4 days travel between the cities over an 8-day period for just £99, offering better value than individual tickets. Department stores Department Stores in Manchester Manchester is the ultimate shopping destination, offering a wide range of department stores that cater to every shopper's needs. Whether you're looking for high-end luxury fashion, everyday essentials, or the latest home goods, Manchester’s department stores provide the best of both high street and designer shopping. With a vibrant retail scene, the city has everything you need to make your shopping trip truly special. Department Stores in Manchester City Centre The heart of Manchester’s retail scene lies in its bustling city centre, home to renowned department stores like Marks & Spencer , House of Fraser , and Harvey Nichols . These iconic stores offer a blend of premium quality and everyday affordability, making them a must-visit for shoppers. Marks & Spencer is synonymous with convenience and quality, offering everything from stylish clothing to gourmet food, home decor, and more. As a staple of the UK high street, it’s the perfect place for a wide selection of fashion, food, and household essentials. House of Fraser is another flagship store that offers an exceptional mix of luxury brands and high street favourites, with clothing, beauty products, and home goods that cater to all tastes. Harvey Nichols is the go-to destination for luxury shopping, featuring a curated selection of high-end fashion, beauty, and lifestyle products. Visit the Trafford Centre For an even broader range of department stores, head to the intu Trafford Centre , one of the largest shopping centres in the UK. Located just outside Manchester city centre, this retail hub features major department stores such as Selfridges , making it a top choice for fashion lovers and bargain hunters alike. Selfridges is a retail icon known for its luxury fashion, beauty, and lifestyle collections. From premium designer brands to trendy high street options, Selfridges caters to shoppers who demand the best. Why Choose Manchester for Shopping? Manchester is a top shopping city in the UK, offering a diverse retail experience that combines high street bargains with luxury finds. From the stylish department stores in the city centre to the vast shopping experience at the Trafford Centre, Manchester is the perfect place to indulge in retail therapy. Whether you're looking for the latest trends, designer labels, or family-friendly deals, Manchester’s department stores have something for everyone. Don’t miss out on the incredible shopping opportunities waiting for you in this vibrant city. Visit Manchester’s department stores and experience a retail adventure like no other! Events in Manchester From arts and exhibitions to comedy and entertainment, Manchester offers a fantastic number of events throughout the year, catering to a wide range of interests and passions. Immerse yourself in the vibrant cultural scene with thought-provoking exhibitions at many of the city's museums and galleries, from the Science and Industry Museum to the National Football Museum . Headline concerts at AO Arena and Co-op Live complement breakthrough artists at some of the city's more intimate venues such as Band on the Wall , Deaf Institute , Night & Day Café , and Matt & Phred's . Theatre-goers will be in their element, with established productions and innovative performances taking place at Manchester Opera House , Palace Theatre , Aviva Studios , The Lowry , Royal Exchange Theatre , and many more. Sports enthusiasts will find themselves immersed at the iconic Old Trafford and Etihad Stadium , but also across many other sports including cricket's Emirates Old Trafford , swimming, and cycling. Whether you're a music lover, art aficionado, history buff, or sports enthusiast, Manchester's calendar of events promises an eclectic and dynamic experience that reflects the city's vibrant spirit. Your event will then be reviewed by the team to assess if it is suitable. Due to the high volume of submissions we receive, we are unable to notify you of the result. Members of Marketing Manchester can submit unlimited events. Non-members will be limited to 10 events per year. If you'd like to enhance the visibility of your event or join the Marketing Manchester membership scheme, get in touch at info@marketingmanchester.com . Please note: Events will not be accepted without high-quality images. Images need to be at least 1220x619 pixels , in landscape orientation, and must be photography only (no artwork, graphics, or text overlays). If you do not upload an image, your event will not be accepted. By submitting an image, you confirm that you hold the appropriate copyright for it to be used across Visit Manchester's digital channels, and will be liable for any copyright claims that may arise from the use by Visit Manchester. Text content for the event should be around 200 words, written in third person only. If you have an enquiry about event submissions, please email webmaster@visitmanchester.com . Ratings Powered by

Accessible Manchester Manchester is a diverse and energetic city, bursting with character and welcoming to all. As the birthplace of the industrial revolution, Manchester has a rich history in science, politics, music, arts, and sport, blending its heritage with a progressive vision. It is our ambition to make Greater Manchester increasingly accessible and for visitors to easily find businesses, experiences and travel options that can meet their access need and to ultimately enjoy the range of experiences that Greater Manchester has to offer. Places to Visit Greater Manchester has teamed up with AccessAble to provide detailed access guides to help you plan your visit. All detailed access guides can be viewed on the AccessAble microsite for Manchester. You can also tailor your search to specific experiences and business types, such as attractions , restaurants , theatres , hotels and many more . Transport information Greater Manchester can be easily accessed by public transport routes. Whilst here, Greater Manchester is well-connected by regional and national train services. We also have the Bee Network, a public transport system providing tram and bus services to get around Greater Manchester. The Bee Network provides integrated ticketing and a contactless tap-and-go payment option and is easily recognisable throughout Greater Manchester by the yellow and black vehicles and the symbol of the worker bee. TfGM's accessibility hub - provides a number of guides about travelling across Greater Manchester in different ways and includes support available. Tram - accessible information for users of the Metrolink tram network Bus - accessible information for users of the bus network Train - accessible information for users of the train network Manchester Airport - facilities and services for those requiring assisted travel at the airport. You can also view an in depth accessibility guide for all three of the Airport's terminals. Toilets Manchester City Council provides a list of public toilets in Manchester city centre and Changing Places toilets . You can search the Changing Places website for registered facilities across Greater Manchester . Ratings Powered by
