Gorilla Pubs & Bars in Manchester Manchester has long been known for its incredible pub scene, with plenty venues across the city – the highest number outside of London. From cosy, traditional pubs with open fires to stylish bars serving craft cocktails, there really is for everyone. If you're after a laid-back pint, a Sunday roast, or a lively night out, Manchester’s pubs and bars won’t disappoint. Pubs and Bars in Manchester One of the best things about Manchester’s pub culture is its variety. You’ll find everything from historic alehouses pouring locally brewed beers to modern gastro pubs serving up top-quality food. The Northern Quarter is packed with independent spots full of character, while Deansgate and Spinningfields offer a mix of classic pubs and sleek bars. No matter your taste, there’s always somewhere new to try. Pubs in Manchester City Centre If you're looking for a great pub in Manchester city centre, you won’t have to go far. The city is full of great spots. For something more relaxed, head to one of the historic pubs tucked away in side streets or explore the buzzing beer gardens when the sun is out. Many pubs also offer free WiFi, making them a good choice if you need to catch up on emails while enjoying a pint. Where to Eat and Drink in Manchester Manchester’s gastro pubs take pub dining to the next level, combining great food with a welcoming atmosphere. Whether it’s a hearty Sunday roast, locally sourced small plates, or an expertly cooked steak, there are plenty of places where food is just as much of a draw as the drinks. Many of these pubs champion local suppliers, giving you a real taste of the region’s best produce. Day Bars in Manchester Not every great drinking spot comes alive at night—Manchester also has plenty of bars and pubs that are perfect for daytime drinks. Whether you're looking for a quiet place for a coffee and a pint, a stylish venue for brunch, or a lively spot to kick-start a weekend afternoon, you’ll find no shortage of options. With many venues offering outdoor seating, they’re a great choice when the weather is on your side. Read More Search for something... Continue your Manchester story by exploring further. Manchester Accommodation Business Improvement District The Manchester Accommodation BID is a ground-breaking new initiative led by the city’s hotel and serviced apartment providers to help create new events and additional activities that will attract more people to visit and stay in Manchester and Salford. It will also contribute to the enhancement of overall guest experience and help to expand the city’s visitor economy by: amplifying marketing campaigns that drive overnight stays; securing large-scale events, conferences, and festivals in low-season months; improving guest welcome and street cleanliness. The above activities will be funded by the City Visitor Charge; a supplementary £1 Charge per room/unit per night* for guests, added to the final accommodation bill. The statutory Charge will be collected from all paid accommodation establishments that fall into the Manchester Accommodation BID zone and will be applicable to all bookings from 1 April 2023. For more information visit the Manchester ABID website . *Charge may be £1.20 after VAT is applied at some establishments Ratings Powered by

What's on at Lowry Lowry, a cultural beacon situated on the vibrant Salford Quays waterfront in Greater Manchester. Renowned for its striking modern architecture and commitment to the arts, Lowry is a dynamic space that seamlessly blends contemporary performance with artistic innovation. As you step inside, you'll discover a diverse array of events, from compelling theatre productions and dance performances to thought-provoking exhibitions in the galleries. This iconic venue hosts both established artists and emerging talents, providing a stage for creativity to flourish. Lowry's commitment to accessibility and community engagement ensures that its events appeal to a broad audience, making it a cultural destination where everyone can experience the transformative power of the arts. The Real Greek Greek Restaurants in Manchester Looking for a taste of the Mediterranean in Manchester? The city’s Greek restaurants offer a mouth-watering selection of authentic dishes that transport you straight to Greece. From sizzling souvlaki to flaky spanakopita, comforting moussaka, and fresh, vibrant Greek salads, these spots bring the best of Greek cuisine to your plate. The rich history of Greek migration to Manchester, starting in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, has shaped the city’s diverse culinary scene, ensuring that Manchester is home to some of the best Greek food in the UK. Whether you're a lifelong fan or trying Greek food for the first time, Manchester’s Greek restaurants promise a dining experience you won’t forget. Explore the Best Greek Restaurants in Manchester For a truly authentic experience, The Real Greek is a must-visit. Known for bringing both traditional Greek cuisine and the vibrant atmosphere of Greece, this restaurant captures the essence of Mediterranean dining. If you’re looking for something with a modern twist, Fenix offers elevated Greek dishes inspired by exotic lands and legends, turning every meal into an escape into the heart of Greek culture. For a more relaxed vibe, head to Sokrates Taverna in Horwich, where you'll enjoy traditional, no-fuss Greek meals in a friendly, laid-back setting. If you're after a lively atmosphere, Bouzouki delivers the classic Greek taverna experience with a side of fun. After your meal, join in the lively entertainment and games to round off your Greek night. Authentic Greek Cuisine in Manchester If you’re craving traditional Greek flavours, Manchester has no shortage of options. The city’s Greek restaurants serve up classics like souvlaki, moussaka, and spanakopita, all made with the finest ingredients. Every dish captures the essence of Greek cooking, combining fresh produce, bold flavours, and rich Mediterranean traditions. Whether you're in the mood for a light meal or a full feast, you can’t go wrong with these delicious offerings. A Mediterranean Feast for Any Occasion Looking to celebrate a special occasion, catch up with friends, or enjoy a casual night out? Manchester's Greek restaurants are perfect for any event. Each one offers a warm, welcoming atmosphere where you can relax and enjoy your meal. From hearty family meals to intimate dinners, there's something on the menu for everyone. With a range of vegetarian, vegan, and Halal options, these restaurants make it easy to enjoy a true Mediterranean feast in the heart of Manchester. Read More Search for something... Altrincham Market House Read More Family Friendly Restaurants in Manchester Manchester offers plenty of family-friendly restaurants with child-friendly menus, highchairs, and a welcoming atmosphere. School holidays and weekends are the perfect time for a family day out. These restaurants provide great places to refuel after exploring the city. Where Are the Best Family-Friendly Restaurants in Manchester? The Corn Exchange is a great spot with options like Vapiano for Italian, Byron for burgers, and Zizzi for handmade pizzas. Each offers relaxed dining with children's menus, ideal for a treat during half-term or a fun weekend meal. What Are the Best Child-Friendly Restaurants? Hard Rock Café has an exciting American vibe, Gusto offers upscale Italian, and Rudy’s Neapolitan Pizza serves high-quality pizzas in a casual setting. Great for a family meal during the school holidays or a special weekend outing. Where Can You Eat with Children in Manchester City Centre? The Botanist has a unique nature-inspired setting, TGI Fridays offers a lively atmosphere, and The Counter House in Ancoats serves fresh, healthy meals in a relaxed space. Which Restaurants Have the Best Kids’ Menus? Tampopo serves Pan-Asian dishes in a family-friendly space, Bill’s offers fresh, seasonal meals, and Nando’s has customisable options for all ages. What Are the Best Affordable Family Restaurants? For budget-friendly options, Pizza Express offers affordable Italian dishes, and Wagamama serves nutritious, child-friendly meals. Perfect for families looking for a great meal without breaking the bank during the school holidays or a weekend lunch. Finding great places to eat with children in Manchester is easy, with plenty of options for every taste and budget. Plan a fun-filled day out during half-term, a weekend meal, or a quick bite at these family-friendly restaurants. Read More Search for something... Haunt Manchester Haunt Manchester “Manchester is Gothic physically - in its Gothic buildings such as the Town Hall and Chetham’s and John Ryland’s libraries - but also in a deeper, philosophical, undercurrent. Manchester was the famously dark and smoky ‘shock city’ of the industrial age, and it persists in having a Gothic philosophical identity as a place that is brooding, wild and moody” – Jonathan Schofield (Manchester Confidential) Welcome to Haunt Manchester!  This site aims to delve into the dark histories and spooky secrets of the area whilst also exploring all things alternative, Gothic and goth from across Greater Manchester. From Gothic buildings, to ghostly walking tours and Halloween fun, this is your one-stop shop for everything atmospheric, weird and wonderful in the region. Back Best food halls and street food spots in Greater Manchester By Visit Manchester on Jul. 01, 2022 10 min read Whether you’re searching for new flavours, are an indecisive eater or simply need a place with options to suit everyone’s tastebuds, Manchester’s Street food offering could be the answer. With a mix of cuisines and flavours all under one roof, what could be better? In the last few years, street food halls have become a firm favourite with Manchester’s residents and visitors alike, and it’s a good job we have plenty to choose from. With street food vendors ranging from the authentic to the quirky, street food halls offer a place for some of the most exciting up-and-coming chefs to make the food they love at a reasonable price, and we can all benefit. Some of Manchester’s previous street food offerings have now become some of our best-loved restaurants, with food halls giving talented chef’s a much-needed platform to show what they can do. Far from the days of street food meaning a single lonely burger van, Greater Manchester’s Street food scene has exploded in recent years with establishments popping up all over the city-region. Foodies love the fuss-free, casual nature of these places but also the chance to try something new without a hefty price tag. It doesn’t matter if you’re looking for a quick bite or to spend an afternoon with friends trying a mix of foods and drinks as you go, street food halls offer quality, delicious food and great places to chill. We’ve rounded up some of the best street food markets and food halls, so that next time you’re searching for a bite to eat, you know where to go. Mackie Mayor On the edge of Manchester’s beloved Northern Quarter, you’ll find a Grade II listed market building (the only remaining building from the Smithfield market) which is now home to some of Manchester’s favourite street food vendors. Mackie Mayor is a modern food hall which has precisely the urban, relaxed vibe you’d expect from its location. With great offerings for breakfast, brunch, lunch or dinner, you really could spend all day eating in here. There are currently nine independent kitchens and bars showcasing the best regional food and drink. The vendors include Honest Crust Pizza, Tender Cow, Baohouse, Fin Fish Bar and Reserve Wines. It doesn’t matter whether you’re looking for a coffee or something a little more exotic, there’s something for everyone. Plus, it’s dog-friendly, so furry friends can come along too! GRUB Just five minutes’ walk from Manchester Victoria station, just outside of the hustle and bustle of Manchester city centre, a converted textile warehouse hosts Manchester’s longest-running street food market. Describing itself as Manchester’s biggest and friendliest street food venue, GRUB is open Wednesday to Sunday at The Red Bank Project. It has a mix of indoor and outdoor spaces including Manchester’s best-kept secret beer garden. Street food is served week in, week out by Manchester’s best independent businesses. You'll find that Rudy’s Pizza and Hip Hop Chip Shop started here once upon a time. You’ll be spoilt for choice with a huge range of vendors covering a whole range of cuisines from Greek to Sri Lankan and absolutely everything in between. There are even vendors to satisfy your sweet tooth because your dessert stomach needs feeding too. Escape to Freight Island If you like your street food served with a side of entertainment, Escape to Freight Island could be for you. In the heart of the regeneration of Depot Mayfield, this market and festival space offers incredible food and drink alongside entertainment and events. It’s home to several different restaurants, food trucks and bars serving up everything from “the most popular burger in Manchester” to American pies. It’s safe to say you’ll be spoilt for choice. Escape to Freight Island also regularly team up with Manchester chefs and restaurants to create one-of-a-kind dishes for a limited time, which should be enough of a reason to draw you back in. Sit outside or inside and enjoy the eclectic mix of events, entertainment and flavours at the party animal of Manchester’s street food scene. Society MCR A hub of street food, craft beer and cocktails, Society is a recent addition to Manchester city centre’s street food scene, but it’s a great one. With five independently owned kitchens, you can enjoy pan-Asian cuisine, Indian street food, towering burgers and much more. It’s a great place to socialise throughout the day whether you’re looking for an exciting lunch spot or the perfect place for after-work drinks. Resident DJs will be on hand to entertain you throughout the evening and give that cool, effortless Manchester vibe. Plus, Society is becoming a firm favourite for the city’s beer lovers with Vocation, one of the fastest-growing craft breweries in the UK on site. Enjoy award-winning beers and creative cocktails while you enjoy dishes from across the world. Hello Oriental If you’re craving a taste of Asia, Manchester’s newest street food offering is the perfect place for you. Hello Oriental is home to an Asian-inspired bakery and café, Vietnamese restaurant and street food hall. Located in the centre of Manchester’s new Circle Square development on Oxford Road, you’ll find Chinese roasts, dim sum, bao, noodle dishes, bubble tea and more. Or for lighter Vietnamese flavours, expect classic dishes like pho, summer rolls and Vietnamese salads. Plus, there’s an oriental supermarket on-site if you feel inspired to cook up some East Asian flavours yourself. New Century Kitchen Once home to a legendary dance hall, the iconic New Century Hall re-opened in summer 2022 as a remarkable new social destination in Manchester’s NOMA district. The ground floor is now home to New Century Kitchen , a food hall and the beating heart of New Century, which is made up of six independent street food traders, a terrace that spills out onto Sadler’s Yard for al fresco dining, and a stunning mid-century style bar and interior. Guests can choose a wide selection of vibrant global cuisine, including pizza, sushi, steak, burgers, Vietnamese cuisine, and Indian Street Food, all whilst dining in New Century Kitchen. There’s also a selection of fantastic local beers, wines, creative cocktails, as well as artisan coffees, tea, juices, and smoothies, on the menu as well. Bury Market Voted Britain’s Favourite Market in 2019 and 2022, Bury Market is famous across our city-region and is making a name for itself across the globe. A traditional market located in a market town, you can find everything in Bury Market which is why it attracts thousands of visitors every week. There are over 200 stalls including a fish and meat hall so that you can whip up some delicious dishes at home. However, foodies will know, that it’s also a great place to grab a bite to eat. You’ll find delis and street food vendors of all sorts as well as great bakeries for a bite to eat, after all, shopping is tiring work. The Produce Hall Stockport Over the last 160 years, Stockport’s Produce Hall has been home to fish and meat markets, cheese stalls and sweetshops. Now, it’s home to delicious kitchens and bars serving up flavours that cater to all tastes. The bar hosts an eclectic mix of local beers and brilliant beverages from further afield while each kitchen serves delicious food daily. There’s something for everyone, including Caribbean soul food, Mexican treats, stone-baked pizzas, burgers and Cambodian cuisine, all serving lighter bites or moreish meals depending on what you fancy. Foodie Friday’s Stockport Market Sticking with Stockport, if you’re looking for a way to fill your Friday evening then look to Stockport institution Foodie Fridays . On the last Friday of every month from 6 pm to 9 pm, Stockport Market hosts street food, craft ales and live music. The event is loved by people across the town and is a fabulous feel-good foodie activity. Traders include I Knead Pizza, Oh Mei Dumpling, Halloumination and Tapas Y a la Carta and so much more. Expect everything from Halloumi to Fried Chicken, Thai favourites to toasted quesadillas. If you’re looking for the most delicious way to spend a Friday night in Stockport, you’ve just found it. Altrincham Market Altrincham is one of the UK’s original market towns and so it makes perfect sense that it’s now home to one of our city-region's most celebrated street food halls. Altrincham Market is at the heart of the town’s reinvention and focuses on independent traders and chefs. The Market House is currently home to ten food operators including Honest Crust pizza, Tender Cow, Great North Pie Co and Market House Coffee. There is also New Market Square with Mummas Fried chicken, Rubens Mezze Grill and Manchester-favourite Federal Café Bar. This dog-friendly spot is a favourite amongst Altrincham residents but has also become a destination in itself with people from across Greater Manchester travelling for brunch dates, light bites or even a casual dinner plan. The market is closed on Mondays, but for the rest of the week, you can fill your boots. Arndale Market There’s nothing quite like shopping to build up an appetite and street food often makes the perfect break from retail therapy. So, it’s handy that the award-winning Arndale Market in Manchester’s central shopping centre has so many delicious options for you to try. Cheese toasties, pies, pastries, burritos, Thai street food, poke bowls and vegan junk food are just some of the possibilities, so trust us when we say you really will be spoilt for choice. Plus, there are sweet treats like smoothie bowls and Portuguese natas if you need dessert too, and why wouldn’t you? Stretford Food Hall Aptly named FoodHall , Stretford FoodHall can be found at Stretford Mall in the heart of Trafford, and has space for three vendors which operate on rotation. Resident independent restaurants cook up fresh food every day, from vegan burgers and tacos to Thai noodles, Korean chicken and even Dutch kitchens. Coming back to check out new traders is all part of the excitement! Stretford FoodHall is a great community space whether you want to work, catch up with friends or even hold an event. Makers Markets The Makers Markets pop up all over Greater Manchester and present the perfect excuse to go and explore some local food options. With 18 artisan markets across the North West, there’s sure to be a Makers Market near you. In Greater Manchester, you’ll find the Makers Market appear in Chorlton, Cheadle, Northern Quarter, Sale, Stockport, Salford Quays and West Didsbury but there are other locations in Cheshire too. Expect an abundance of delicious bakes, cakes and treats, mouth-watering street food, amazing arts and crafts and so much more! If you’re not hungry by now, then we don’t know how else to help. As you can see, there are so many options when it comes to street food in Greater Manchester which means countless dishes and cuisines to get stuck into. If you’re ever looking for an excuse to try something a little different, or your group has a wide variety of tastes, then these food halls are the ideal solution. So, what are you waiting for? Go and fill your boots with some mouth-watering dishes. You can find more places to eat and drink in Greater Manchester, here . What's on at Manchester Opera House and Palace Theatre Indulge in the grandeur of theatrical splendor at Manchester Opera House and Palace Theatre, two iconic venues that define the city's rich cultural landscape. Manchester Opera House, with its opulent décor and historical charm, sets the stage for an array of top-tier musicals, ballets, and operatic performances. Its regal atmosphere transports audiences to a bygone era, offering a truly immersive theater experience. Meanwhile, Palace Theatre, with its striking architecture, stands as a beacon of contemporary entertainment, hosting blockbuster West End shows, riveting dramas, and world-class musicals. Both venues boast an impressive lineup of events that cater to diverse tastes, from classic theater enthusiasts to those seeking the latest in Broadway sensations Search for something... Unmissable Music in Manchester From Parklife to Warehouse Project and Pride to ground-breaking performances in offbeat venues including the White Hotel and Hidden , Manchester is the home of Unmissable Music. The city region boasts a rich music heritage as home to the Halle orchestra (Est 1857) and was the birthplace for world famous artists including The Hollies, Smiths, New Order, Oasis, Stone Roses, Blossoms and 1975. The legacy of the Hacienda nightclub can be seen in the people who came clubbing and decided to settle. But Manchester is also a fertile breeding ground for the exciting new acts that will help shape the future of music, with venues of all shapes and sizes, and live music experiences to suit every taste. MediaCity and The Quays MediaCity and The Quays is an iconic waterfront destination that's part of Salford Quays. MediaCity and The Quays MediaCity & The Quays is an iconic waterfront destination positioned on the banks of the historic Manchester Ship Canal, in Salford, Greater Manchester. It’s a place bursting with creativity and culture, boasting one of the UK’s most visited arts attractions - Lowry and award-winning Imperial War Museum North . It’s home to the BBC and Coronation Street’s famous cobbled set and experience, while dock10 attracts TV show audiences all year round thanks to the many shows filmed here including The Voice and Countdown. Expect a vibrant bar and restaurant scene including Quayside’s new Central Bay waterfront foodie destination – home to Kargo MKT, which champions up and coming culinary talent and with 20 independent kitchens makes it one of the largest food halls in the area neighbouring 11 Central a brand new microbrewery and bar. Across MediaCity & The Quays, there is a choice of popular names including wagamama, The Botanist, The Alchemist to Turtle Bay and Pizza Express. As well as the thriving food and drink scene, you can find a mix of high street brands and convenience-led stores within Quayside MediaCity. MediaCity & The Quays’ wide, open spaces enables it to host an eclectic roster of events from immersive art installations to family orientated festivals. It’s easy to access too - located just 10 minutes from Manchester City Centre with fantastic transport links and three dedicated Metrolink stations (the biggest rail system in the UK) means it couldn’t be easier. Sporting Events in Manchester Sport is written into Manchester's DNA. From the 2002 Commonwealth Games to iconic Premier League football teams, Manchester has a wealth of experience in welcoming international sports events to the city. Manchester United and Manchester City regularly host European games, and welcome fans from all over the world to experience the thrill of the game. Emirates Old Trafford is home to Lancashire Cricket Club, and also plays host to England ODI and Test Match games.  Alongside this, Manchester attracts sporting events including cycling, rugby, swimming, squash and much more across its world-class purpose-built venues. Peel Tower, Bury Explore Bury Just north of Manchester, the borough of Bury is a great combination of award winning attractions, excellent food and drink and excellent shopping opportunities. In Bury town centre you can head to Bury Art Museum & Sculpture Centre and immerse yourself in some of the best international and local art, or spend an evening at The Met which, having reopened after a multi-million pound refurbishment, offers a fantastic programme of touring theatre and music. You’ll find plenty of places where you can delve into Bury’s past. Discover amazing stories at the award-winning Fusilier Museum , or step aboard the beautifully restored East Lancashire Railway and be transported back to the age of steam. Enjoy a ‘Day Out with Thomas’, a heritage rail ale trail or sit back and relax on a stylish diner train as you travel through beautiful the Irwell Valley. Bury’s great outdoors includes Burrs Country Park , with its activity centre and riverside walks, and Prestwich Forest Park with its popular mountain bike routes. Just outside Ramsbottom , Holcombe Hill offers spectacular views across Greater Manchester; which are even better if you climb to the top of Peel Tower ! Across the borough there are plenty of trails and footpaths linking Bury’s stunning open spaces so you can choose a leisurely stroll, or a ten mile hike! For shopping try Bury Market , with over 350 stalls it’s buzzing with atmosphere, packed with bargains and has some of the best local produce around, including of o course the famous Bury Black Pudding. You’ll find high street names in The Rock and Mill Gate shopping centres, while Ramsbottom and Prestwich are the places to go for specialists and independents. When it comes to eating out, Bury is well and truly on the foodie map. Ramsbottom is home to multi award-winners - choose from the stylish Hearth of The Ram , The Eagle and Child , sourcing ingredients from its allotment garden, or Levanter Fine Foods , offering authentic Spanish dishes. Famous for stunning wedding cakes and exquisite afternoon teas, 3 rd generation, family-run Slattery in Whitefield offers indulgent chocolates and confectionary- all made on the premises, while The Clarence , in Bury town centre, combines foodie pub, cocktail bar and microbrewery all rolled into one. Discover more at visitbury.com . Things to do in Bury Check out our highlights Burrs Country Park Burrs Country Park is a beautiful country park located just a mile outside Bury town centre. Film and TV in Manchester Hero image credit: @filmtourismus. Discover the magic of TV and cinema in Greater Manchester. From British TV classics such as Coronation Street, to streaming hits like Fool Me Once, and Hollywood blockbusters including Captain America: The First Avenger and Sherlock Holmes, the city-region has rolled out the red-carpet to the world’s biggest stars. Stroll down Dale Street and follow the footsteps of Captain America, stalk the streets with Thomas Shelby in Castlefield, or discover where Meryl Streep transformed into the Iron Lady in Manchester’s Town Hall. See the sights with a film-focussed walking tour or explore at your own pace with the Manchester film and tv map. Cinephiles can sit back, relax and enjoy the best films on the big screen in Greater Manchester’s cinemas, or discover something new at one of the city-region’s prominent film festivals, such as the annual Manchester International Film Festival, the Manchester Animation Festival, queer-focused SCENE, and the acclaimed Bolton Film Festival. With so much to see and do, it’s time to call “action!” on an adventure in Greater Manchester. Zouk Tea Bar & Grill Halal Friendly Restaurants in Manchester Looking for the best halal restaurants in Manchester? Manchester is home to a thriving halal dining scene, offering a wide variety of options for those seeking delicious, halal-certified meals. From casual kebab shops to upscale restaurants serving authentic international cuisines, the city caters to every taste and preference. With a focus on quality and authenticity, Manchester’s halal restaurants ensure every meal is prepared to the highest halal standards. Explore the city’s best halal dining spots and enjoy food that’s as satisfying as it is compliant with halal requirements. Halal Pan-Asian and Fusion Cuisine If you’re after a mix of Asian-inspired flavours, Manchester offers several halal-friendly fusion restaurants. MOWGLI offers a unique take on Indian street food, with dishes that are hearty yet light, and packed with bold flavours. The restaurant emphasizes the types of foods Indians eat at home and on the streets, all prepared with halal ingredients. For a more upscale, luxurious experience, Vermilion offers a three-storey dining adventure with dishes that span the breadth of Asia. From Indian and Thai-inspired dishes to Chinese delicacies. For a taste of Thailand, Try Thai in Manchester’s Chinatown delivers authentic Thai food made with halal ingredients. Thai cuisine is known for its balance of sweet, sour, salty, and spicy flavours. Halal Steak and Grill For those who crave hearty grilled meats and steaks, halal options in Manchester are thriving. Fazenda Rodizio Bar & Grill in Spinningfields offers a Brazilian churrascaria experience, where servers bring skewers of halal meats straight to your table. It’s a meat-lover’s dream. Halal South-Asian Cuisine Indian cuisine is a favourite in Manchester, and halal options abound. Whether you’re in the mood for a rich, creamy curry or fiery street food, there’s a dish for everyone. Zouk Tea Bar & Grill , an award-winning restaurant, serves up a contemporary twist on traditional Indian dishes, with a variety of halal options. Their menu includes everything from spicy biryanis to indulgent curries. For a more classic Indian experience, Grand Millon Indian Restaurant in Oldham has been serving traditional halal Indian meals for decades, while Blue Tiffin in Royton combines modern decor with authentic flavours for a casual yet satisfying dining experience. If you’re craving something vibrant and full of street food energy, Scene Indian Street Kitchen in Manchester offers halal-friendly dishes inspired by the lively food markets of India. Aman Indian Restaurant in Failsworth also brings you classic Indian meals made with fresh, halal ingredients, ensuring you get a true taste of home-cooked Indian food. Halal Middle Eastern and Mediterranean Cuisine For lighter, yet equally flavourful dishes, Middle Eastern and Mediterranean cuisine is always a great choice. Go Falafel in Manchester offers a delicious selection of fresh, halal-certified falafel wraps and salad bowls. If you’re in the mood for Turkish coffee and snacks, Tegtat in Manchester’s city centre offers traditional Turkish teas and a range of halal snacks and dishes. Read More Search for something... Manchester Central Library Read More Visitor Information Centres Manchester Visitor Information Centre Located in the historic Central Library, the Visitor Information Centre should be your first port-of-call when visiting the Northern capital. A free service for all to use, our friendly and knowledgeable staff are here to help you maximise your visit. Visit us for: Free maps - Covering the city, wider region, transport, and more. Leaflets and literature – Complimentary and up-to-date brochures and listings for the city’s latest events, attractions and tours (including the river cruise, sightseeing bus tour, and walking tours). Tourism tips - One-to-one personal advice on any leisure and tourism related enquires. Travel tips – Guidance on navigating the city’s Metrolink, Bus, and Train network. Hotel help – Insider tips on the best accommodation to suit any budget and preference. Souvenir Shopping – A boutique shop offering a range of Manchester-related merchandise, cards, and guidebooks. Also see our online shop. Planning-ahead pointers – Yet to come to Manchester? Email our Visitor Information desk directly with any queries you have in advance. Address : Manchester Central Library, St Peters Square, Manchester, Greater Manchester, M2 5PD Opening times : Monday - Saturday 09:00 - 17:00 Email : visitorinformation@manchester.gov.uk View our AccessAble Guide Greater Manchester Tourist Information Centres Bolton Tourist Information Centre Central Library Le Mans Crescent Bolton BL1 1SE Phone: 01204 334321 Email: tourist.info@bolton.gov.uk Monday: 09:00 - 19:30 Tuesday: 09:00 - 19:30 Wednesday: 09:00 - 17:30 Thursday: 09:00 - 19:30 Friday: 09:00 - 17:30 Saturday: 09:00 - 17:00 Sunday: Closed Oldham Tourist Information Centre Oldham Library and Lifelong Learning Centre Cultural Quarter Greaves Street Oldham, OL1 1AL Phone: 0161 770 8035 Email: ecs.tourist@oldham.gov.uk Monday to Thursday: 09.00 - 20:00 Friday and Saturday: 09:00 - 17:00 Saddleworth Museum in Uppermill Saddleworth Museum High Street Uppermill Saddleworth Oldham, OL3 6HS Phone: 0145 787 0336 Email: ecs.saddleworthtic@oldham.gov.uk Every day: 13:00 - 16:00 City Hosts Look out for the City Hosts team on the main shopping streets in Manchester city centre offering advice and tips. The City Hosts are on the streets seven days a week, 363 days a year, based in the central retail district, Manchester Piccadilly Station, Victoria Station, and more key routes into the city centre. They are on hand to guide shoppers, visitors and workers, help with directions, public transport information and details on events taking place in the city centre. The friendly face of the city, the hosts act as a point of contact for both visitors and retailers. The team's hours are 10am - 7pm. Ratings Powered by

From cosy neighbourhood… What's on at Manchester Opera House & Palace Theatre Indulge in the grandeur of theatrical splendor at Manchester Opera House and Palace Theatre, two… Follow us Christmas in Manchester Christmas is a magical time in Greater Manchester and the perfect occasion to combine a short festive break with a spot of Christmas shopping. Discover the Best Shopping in Manchester Manchester is a global shopping destination, drawing visitors from all over the country with its blend of international brands, British department stores, boutiques, and creative independents. Whether you’re seeking high-end luxury, unique finds, or great deals, Manchester has something for everyone. Key Shopping Centres in Manchester For a complete shopping experience, visit popular s hopping centres like Manchester Arndale and The Trafford Centre , where you’ll find a huge selection of international brands alongside British department stores like John Lewis , Selfridges , House of Fraser and Marks and Spencer . High street hotspots like Exchange Square and Market Street are also extremely popular. Boutique and Independent Shopping For that extra special something, visit boutique districts around King Street , Spinningfields and New Cathedral Street and browse their designer shops . Or if one-off independents and handmade is more your thing, Manchester's alternative and creative heart, The Northern Quarter , is home to countless vintage stores, record shops, cafés, bars and restaurants. Luxury, Jewellery, and Designer Outlets Hunt for incredible bargains at Cheshire Oaks Designer Outlet , where over 145 boutiques span 250,000 square feet of retail space. This premier outlet offers fantastic deals on a wide range of designer brands, making it a must-visit for savvy shoppers. Manchester also boasts a thriving Jewellery Quarter , perfect for treating yourself or someone special. From exclusive timepieces to contemporary designs and vintage treasures, you’ll find something extraordinary to cherish. Make a Weekend of It Extend your shopping trip into a luxurious weekend getaway. Manchester offers a range of hotels , ideal for relaxing after a full day of retail therapy. From spa hotels to luxury stays , there’s something to suit every taste. If you need any tips on where to eat, drink, watch a show or visit a gallery after your shopping trip, don’t forget, Manchester’s team of City Hosts are on hand to help. Designer Shops in Manchester Designer shops in Manchester Looking for a premium shopping experience? Manchester is home to a world of luxury retail, featuring top international and British designers, high-end department stores, and exclusive boutiques. If you're searching for the latest runway styles or a timeless investment piece, Manchester's shopping scene has it all. King Street: The Heart of Luxury Shopping King Street has long been Manchester’s go-to destination for premium shopping. With a unique blend of fashion, fine jewellery, art, and dining, this historic street boasts over 40 luxury brands, stylish boutiques, and top-tier restaurants. Explore designer collections, indulge in high-end leisure experiences, and enjoy a vibrant calendar of exclusive events. A visit to King Street is an unmissable part of any shopping trip in Manchester. Selfridges & Harvey Nichols: Ultimate Designer Destinations Manchester’s Selfridges and Harvey Nichols redefine luxury shopping. Located in the heart of the city, Selfridges offers an unparalleled selection of designer brands, from globally renowned labels to cutting-edge fashion houses. You'll also find a second Selfridges store in the Trafford Centre , easily accessible by bus or tram from the city centre. Harvey Nichols , another iconic shopping destination, delivers an elite shopping experience with premium fashion, beauty, and lifestyle products. Cheshire Oaks: The UK’s Largest Designer Outlet For those looking to shop designer brands at outlet prices, Cheshire Oaks Designer Outlet is a must-visit. Just a 50-minute drive from Manchester city centre, this shopping haven is the largest designer outlet in the UK, featuring top fashion labels at discounted prices. A perfect day trip for savvy luxury shoppers. Manchester is The Ultimate Luxury Shopping Destination If you're searching for a special gift or treating yourself to high-end goods, Manchester offers a shopping experience like no other. Start planning your shopping trip today and indulge in the best of Manchester’s high-end retail scene. Read More Search for something... Continue your Manchester story by exploring further. Proud, an audio-visual exhibition to celebrate Manchester’s LGBTQIA+ community. Proud Manchester BID presents Proud, an audio-visual exhibition, created by Heard Storytelling, to celebrate Manchester’s LGBTQIA+ community. From the streets of Jamaica, stages of Manchester, dressing rooms of working men’s clubs and the nation’s TV screens, these tales take listeners on personal and candid journeys, all focused on the theme ‘Proud’. Back The Top Afternoon Teas in Greater Manchester By Visit Manchester on Aug. 11, 2024 8 min read Who can resist a sweet treat? Afternoon tea is a British staple whether you’re celebrating something or simply fancy a bit of indulgence. Whether you’re a jam first or cream first sort of person, there is nothing better than handmade scones, sandwiches, cakes and of course, a good old-fashioned pot of tea. There are so many great places to enjoy afternoon tea in Greater Manchester from quirky tea rooms to decadent hotels, that it makes choosing between them incredibly difficult. And so, to help, we’ve rounded up our definitive list of the top afternoon teas in Greater Manchester. 1. The Library Champagne Bar The Library Champagne Bar Welcome to a secluded setting surrounded by beautiful books and original art in the heart of… The Edwardian Manchester is a hotel that oozes luxury and its afternoon tea is no exception. Hosted in the hotel's social space The Library Champagne Bar , guests can expect a tasty journey of their own. Savour one of Manchester’s finest afternoon teas, freshly prepared in-house by The Library’s pâtissiers. A set of delicious sandwiches made using the most exceptional produce is followed by a handcrafted selection of pâtisseries and scones, complemented by Newby Teas – the world’s most awarded luxury tea brand. For the ultimate indulgence, a sommelier recommends an optional Champagne pairing from their favourite maisons. Plus, for Afternoon Tea week The Library will be offering 25% off Afternoon Tea on Thursday & Friday. 2. Hotel Gotham Hotel Gotham Manchester Boutique 5* hotel, Rooftop Private Members Bar, GILT Club & 2AA Rosette Honey Restaurant. Hotel… If you’re looking for afternoon tea with a view, Hotel Gotham can certainly deliver. Served in their art-deco-inspired Honey Restaurant enjoy afternoon tea overlooking the rooftops of Manchester. Hotel Gotham is a hotel that encapsulates opulence and that’s exactly what you can expect from their afternoon tea offering. Escape the streets of Manchester and indulge in all of the traditional treats served with a Gotham Twist. 3. The Midland Hotel The Midland Tea Room by Pommery From the 1st August 2024, the famous Midland Tea Room will partner with Pommery Champagne to… The Midland Hotel is a Manchester institution and so is its tea room. In fact, it’s been a highlight of Manchester’s social scene since the hotel opened in 1903. The Tea Room at The Midland is one of a kind, and Manchester’s only room dedicated to afternoon tea, so you can tell it takes its sweet offering very seriously. The Tea Room works with local suppliers to bring its customers the freshest loose-leaf tea, sandwiches, scones, delicate cakes and pastries. Prices start from £30 per person and there are vegan, vegetarian and gluten-free options available. 4. The Lowry Hotel The Lowry Hotel Iconic Hotel. Independently Minded. Rooted in the independent spirit of Manchester, The Lowry Hotel… The River Restaurant at The Lowry Hotel has become one of Manchester’s most iconic restaurants. With a stunning river setting, you can enjoy scenic views as well as a delicious section of sandwiches, scones, pastries and fondant fancies. Choose from over 80 teas, Champagne, G&Ts or cocktails to complement your treats, and you can even create a personalised tea blend. It’s safe to say you’ll be spoilt for choice. The afternoon is just £59 for two. 5. Dakota Manchester Dakota Manchester Dakota is a lifestyle brand for the independent thinking, discerning traveller. An eight-story new… Manchester’s newest luxury hotel Dakota Manchester provides a true sense of luxury just on the edge of the Northern Quarter. It’s an idyllic escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. Their classic afternoon tea offers the same sense of decadence and is one all tea lovers should try. The menu includes freshly baked scones, a selection of finger sandwiches and homemade teacakes and fancies. There is a selection of teas to choose from or the option to add a glass of fizz or a specially crafted gin cocktail. Prices start from £28 per person. Dakota Manchester promises quality and luxury, and their afternoon tea is no exception. 6. Refuge The Refuge With its welcome ambiance and sociable buzz, The Refuge has become a hotspot where you can play all… The Kimpton Clocktower Hotel’s resident restaurant Refuge is one of Manchester’s most stunning venues, it’s steeped in history and glamour and almost instantly transports you back in time. Their afternoon tea is served in The Winter Garden, which brings the outdoors into the gorgeous space. For just £29 per person, you can indulge in savoury treats such as sausage rolls and sandwiches, scones and a variety of cakes from Battenburg to Black Forest Gateaux. There is also a huge selection of cocktails, fizz and of course tea and coffee. 7. Richmond Tea Rooms Richmond Tea Rooms Inspired by the desire to enjoy an exquisite afternoon tea in the heart of Manchester, the warm… For an afternoon tea like no other, head to Richmond Tea Rooms . This Alice in Wonderland-themed café offers a truly enchanting offering which will feel fresh from the pages of a storybook. The décor alone is enough to capture your imagination and combined with their selection of afternoon teas it will deliver an experience you won’t forget. Choose between five different afternoon tea menus including Richmond Tea, Queens Tea and Hatters Tea all with a variety of savoury snacks, scones and homemade cakes. A trip to Richmond Tea Rooms is a treat for all of the senses but the tastebuds in particular. 8. Manchester Art Gallery Manchester Art Gallery Cafe In the gallery cafe you can choose from a selection of freshly made sandwiches and salads, home made… Art lovers and culture vultures, head to the Manchester Art Gallery for afternoon tea and an experience you’ll never forget. Of course, the gallery is full of wonderful art and provides a brilliant day out for all of the family, but the true masterpiece is, of course, the afternoon tea. Choose from a wide range of loose-leaf teas from around the world and taste delicious sandwiches, cakes and scones baked fresh on site every day by our in-house chefs. Prices start from £25 per person and there is also the option to add a glass of Prosecco with vegetarian options available. 9. Mercure Manchester Piccadilly Mercure Manchester Piccadilly A 4-star hotel in the heart of Manchester City Centre with fantastic panoramic views across the… If you like your afternoon tea served with stunning city views, the Mercure Manchester Piccadilly is the place to go. Located in the heart of the city centre, their lounge and restaurant boasts an incredible cityscape view so that you can watch the world go by as you dine. They have a traditional afternoon tea with all of your favourite classic treats and a special Manchester-themed afternoon tea with locally inspired treats including a Vimto Trifle and Manchester Tart. Prices start from £17.50 per person for a traditional afternoon tea and £22.50 per person for the Manchester edition. 10. Bloom & Bicycles The Manchester Floral Bicycle Tour by Blooms & Bicycles Blooms & Bicycles is a community-based bicycle hire company from Manchester with a difference… Next up on our list is an afternoon tea with a difference. Bloom & Bicycles gives you the chance to take your afternoon tea into the great outdoors and make the most of some of Manchester’s stunning outside spaces. Rent one of their retro bikes and enjoy taking in the stunning scenery of Manchester, then settle down for the perfect picnic brought to you by the award-winning French patisserie Bisous Bisous and ethically minded tea and coffee company Worker Bee of Manchester. Made up fresh on the day of your booking, the finest ingredients are put together to provide a selection of artisan sandwiches, fresh mini pastries, macarons and other sweet treats. You can also add champagne to your hamper to celebrate in style. With the bike and hamper delivered to you, it really couldn’t be simpler. 11. Afternoon Tea Taxi Tour Afternoon Tea Taxi Tour What’s better than an afternoon tea? Enjoying a delicious classic afternoon tea on a tour of… What’s better than an afternoon tea? Enjoying a delicious classic afternoon tea on a tour of Manchester, of course! The afternoon tea taxi tour let’s you explore all of the wonderful sights that Manchester has to offer from the comfort of the famous black cab, whilst enjoying a fantastic selection of sandwiches, cakes and scones. Your friends and family can experience a classic afternoon tea in a grade II listed building in the heart of Manchester city centre. It's the perfect opportunity to experience a cultural afternoon in the same building where former Prime Ministers, Winston Churchill and William Gladstone once sat. Starting at £25 per adult or £12 per child, you can expect a variety of finger sandwiches and jam and cream filled scones to make an appearance, with the opportunity to upgrade your tea to prosecco for an extra £5. 13. Oddfellows On The Park Oddfellows on The Park Discover the perfect blend of luxury and convenience at Oddfellows On The Park, nestled within the… When it comes to sipping your afternoon tea in Cheadle, Greater Manchester, and savouring those delicate finger sandwiches while perfecting your etiquette, there's truly no more authentic and charming setting than Oddfellows On The Park . Here, you can anticipate an experience that combines not just culinary delights but also a touch of whimsy and a whole lot of deliciousness. Their carefully crafted menus that change seasonally promise a playful and delightful twist on the traditional afternoon tea, ensuring each bite is a delectable adventure. Starting from £24pp, you do not want to miss this memorable and refined British affair. 14. King Street Townhouse King Street Townhouse King Street Townhouse – A Boutique Retreat in the Heart of Manchester Discover a hidden gem at… Afternoon tea at King Street Townhouse honours one of the very best of British traditions - perfect for celebrating a birthday, engagement, or a 'just because' treat. Their Afternoon Tea Lounge is a slice of calm in Manchester's city centre and a peaceful spot to sit with a coffee while watching the world go by. Their Pastry Chef at King Street Townhouse mixes curiosity and seasonal inspiration to continually reimagine their afternoon teas with a modern yet luxurious spin. Afternoon tea served: 7 days a week | 12 – 6pm! To view more afternoon tea options in Greater Manchester visit our full listings page . Embankement Cafe The Best Cafés and Delis in Manchester Manchester has a café culture that’s as diverse as the city itself. From bustling delis serving fresh lunches to cosy coffee shops hidden down side streets, there’s no shortage of places to pause for a brew, a bite, or a leisurely brunch. Whether you’re after your morning flat white, a light lunch, or an afternoon treat, you’ll find plenty of spots that will quickly become your new favourites, perfect when you’re searching for a cafeteria near-by. Independent Coffee Shops You’ll Love in Manchester Looking for something with a little more character than the high-street chains? Manchester’s independent cafés are full of personality. Here, skilled baristas take coffee seriously, pairing expertly made drinks with cakes, pastries and sandwiches from local suppliers. Many also double as community hubs, offering a warm welcome. You could check out Ezra & Gil or Federal – these are popular spots for indie coffee shop lovers. Where to Find the Best Brunch Spots in Manchester Brunch in Manchester is the most important meal of the day. Across the city, you’ll find everything from elegant delis serving smashed avocado toast and perfectly poached eggs, to lively cafés offering hearty breakfast plates piled high with local produce. Many also make a great choice if you fancy lunch at a cafe after a busy morning of sightseeing or shopping. Vegan and Vegetarian-Friendly Cafés in the City If you’re after plant-based options, Manchester won’t disappoint. Many cafés now offer creative vegan and vegetarian menus, with everything from dairy-free lattes and indulgent pastries to fresh, colourful brunches. Plenty of these spots also focus on sustainability and locally sourced produce, so you can enjoy your food knowing it’s good for both you and the planet-whether you’re looking for a relaxed deli or a stylish cafeteria café with plant-based flair. For a sweet, plant-based treat, check out Gooey . Hidden Gem Coffee Shops in Manchester’s Neighbourhoods Some of Greater Manchester’s best cafés aren’t found in the city centre. Venture into neighbourhoods like Stockport , Ancoats and Didsbury and you’ll uncover hidden gems loved by locals. These smaller spots often serve unique blends, seasonal menus, and offer a relaxed, community feel that makes them worth seeking out. Many are perfect for when you want a quieter café nearby that avoids the busier city-centre haunts. Cafés in Manchester’s Northern Quarter No guide to Manchester’s café scene would be complete without a trip to the Northern Quarter . Known for its creative, independent spirit, the area is packed with coffee shops and delis that have character. From minimalist espresso bars to laid-back brunch cafés decorated with local art, the Northern Quarter is where you’ll find Manchester’s café and brunch culture at its most vibrant. Your Perfect Coffee Break in Manchester Whether you’re searching for ‘a café near me’ for a quick bite or planning a day of exploring Manchester’s independent coffee scene, you’ll be spoiled for choice. With everything from speciality coffee houses to family-run delis, Manchester is the perfect city to slow down, sip, and savour the moment. Read More Search for something... Christmas in Manchester Christmas is a magical time in Greater Manchester and the perfect occasion to combine a short festive break with a spot of Christmas shopping . With hundreds of high street and independent boutique shops to choose from, Greater Manchester attracts visitors from far and wide, particularly during this period – and rightly so! With over 200 stalls spread across nine locations, the Manchester Christmas Markets are a must-visit for locals and tourists, offering six weeks of festive fun and shopping. Manchester's bars and restaurants offer a welcome respite after a day's shopping. With new restaurants, bars, gastropubs, microbreweries, and cafes opening weekly, the city is establishing itself as one of the UK’s most exciting foodie destinations. If you're planning a longer trip, Manchester offers a wide range of accommodation , from unique boutique hotels and luxury pads to beautiful countryside settings and cosy family hideaways. Direct Flights To and From Manchester Airport Manchester connects you to the world with over 190 direct flights from Manchester Airport, making travel easier whether you're flying to Manchester or jetting off to your next destination. With seamless connections across North America, Europe, the Caribbean, and beyond, you can skip the hassle of layovers and enjoy a smoother journey. If you're arriving in Manchester, you'll find direct flights from major cities like New York, Las Vegas, Toronto, and Berlin, as well as domestic routes from Aberdeen, Belfast and London Heathrow. For those departing, Manchester Airport offers a gateway to some of the most exciting destinations worldwide, from vibrant European capitals like Lisbon and Vienna to sun-soaked Caribbean escapes. Explore Oldham Lying to the northeast of Manchester, the borough of Oldham is a great combination of spectacular and unrivalled countryside, quaint villages and market towns, award winning food and drink establishments, excellent shopping opportunities and heritage sites. Almost 25% of the borough lies within the Peak District National Park, so walkers, cyclists and horse riders have lots to enjoy, the Oldham Way, Pennine Way and Pennine Bridleway being just three of the amazing routes through this diverse and beautiful landscape, whether you want a leisurely stroll or a ten mile hike. Oldham has lots to offer for a great day out or extended stay. The dramatic moorland landscape of the South Pennines provides the perfect backdrop for Saddleworth’s picturesque villages, Castleshaw Roman Fort and the Huddersfield Narrow Canal. Beside the Canal in Uppermill, Saddleworth Museum is situated in a converted 19th Century mill, and tells the story of those who helped shape Saddleworth’s landscape and character. A great place for outdoor activities, there’s walking and sailing at Dovestone Reservoir, canoeing at Castleshaw and much more. Wonderful woodlands, waterways and wildflower meadows can be found at our country parks at Daisy Nook, Alexandra Park and Tandle Hill. You can even find mining bees and fossilised mussels at Glodwick Lows Local Nature Reserve and get involved with Northern Roots, an urban farm set in the heart of Oldham. Oldham has a lot to offer, including the Odeon cinema complex in Parliament Square in the converted Grade 2 Listed Old Town Hall, the popular Summit Up climbing centre, bustling markets, a Gallery featuring regular exhibitions and much more. With a wide range of vibrant events and unique traditions like the Whit Friday Brass Bands contests, Saddleworth Rush Cart Festival, Festival Oldham, Illuminate Festival, the Halloween Half Marathon, Diggle Blues Festival and a packed Christmas events programme, visitors will find a varied events to suit everyone. Oldham Town Centre is a shoppers’ haven, with an array of shops, a shopping mall and a traditional market, as well as a free town centre play area for your little ones to enjoy, and numerous cafes, restaurants and bars. The town centre line has three stops – Oldham Mumps, Oldham Central and Oldham King Street – meaning the many shops, attractions, events and leisure offer is all within a short distance. Journeys from Manchester to Oldham only take around half an hour. Oldham is looking to the future, with many regeneration projects currently underway, including the restoration of the Old Library Building, a new market and events space, and a new theatre for the future generations to enjoy. Manchester’s Free Council Firework Displays Set to Return in 2026 Your browser is not supported for this experience. We recommend using Chrome, Firefox, Edge, or Safari. From… Restaurants Discover Manchester's culinary delights with our Restaurants guide. From cosy neighbourhood… What's on at Manchester Opera House & Palace Theatre Indulge in the grandeur of theatrical splendor at Manchester Opera House and Palace Theatre, two… Follow us Christmas in Manchester Christmas is a magical time in Greater Manchester and the perfect occasion to combine a short festive break with a spot of Christmas shopping. Back Back with a bang! Manchester's fireworks displays set to return from 2026 By Visit Manchester on Nov. 27, 2025 2 min read Council-organised firework displays in Manchester’s parks are set to return from next year, it has been revealed. The popular events have not been held since 2019 when they could not take place because of the Covid pandemic. Following that, they remained paused on a trial basis while the Council sought to reprioritise funding to support a wider range of free community events across the city throughout autumn and winter. But the door was never shut on their potential return and now an improving financial position means that the Council is in a position to bring firework events back, while continuing to support other community events. Papers setting out the Council’s financial position as it prepares to set its budget for 2026/27, being considered by scrutiny committees next week (week commencing 1 December) show that fairer funding being introduced by the Government next year will leave the Council better off than previously anticipated. This reintroduces the principle that the amount of money councils are given should be linked to the level of challenges and needs in their area. This link was severed by the Coalition Government elected in 2010, which saw Manchester among the places hardest hit by funding cuts and unfunded pressures such as increased demand for care services. While the exact financial settlement will not be received until late December this year, it is anticipated that the fairer funding formula will see more money for frontline services and support for vulnerable people. Pressures remain after so many years of cuts but this creates the opportunity not just to protect frontline services but to invest in the things which residents have said matter the most to them - and begin to build back some of the things which were hit by austerity. The proposal to bring back fireworks event is one such example. Council Leader Cllr Bev Craig said: “Manchester prides itself on free community events and we know many people have missed Bonfire night firework spectaculars. That’s why we are pleased to confirm they’ll be back by popular demand in 2026. “We know that generations of Mancunians have enjoyed council-organised displays and that free family events are a great way to bring people together. “That’s why when funding was squeezed we sought to support a wider range of community events over a longer period. “But now that this Government is actually investing in councils like ours rather than the cuts we had from Governments since 2010, we can bring back bonfire events while continuing to back other free events across the city. “In the coming months we will talk about our investments in communities, cleaning our streets, frontline services, young people and many more initiatives that will make Manchester better, but for now here’s one example of reversing cuts to our city and building up for a spectacular 2026.” Explore More of Manchester... What's On in Manchester Step into the dynamic and diverse city of Manchester, where a plethora of experiences and events are on offer for residents and visitors alike. From exhibitions that showcase creative expression to live theatre at various venues around the city, Manchester's cultural scene is ever-evolving. Stay tuned for the latest gigs and concerts, taking place at iconic stadiums and intimate venues alike. Dive into the eclectic festivals throughout the year that bring the city alive with celebrations and cultural exchanges. Immerse yourself in world-class sport, from football and cricket to rugby and cycling. Whether you're strolling through markets, exploring museums, or partaking in the vibrant nightlife, Manchester's lively atmosphere ensures there's always something exciting happening across the region. Explore Manchester Events Manchester is a hub of diverse events that cater to every interest. Music lovers can enjoy unforgettable performances at venues like the AO Arena , Co-op Live , and O2 Apollo . Art enthusiasts will find an array of exhibitions in Manchester , ranging from contemporary installations to historic collections. The city’s vibrant festivals, as well as the iconic Manchester Christmas Markets , offer a mix of seasonal events and cultural celebrations. Sports fans can witness thrilling matches at Etihad Stadium and Old Trafford , while theatre lovers can immerse themselves in productions at the Manchester Opera House & Palace Theatre . With so much happening, exploring music events , theatre shows , and sports events is the perfect way to fully experience the city. Plan Your Visit to Manchester Planning a trip to Manchester is easy with so much to see and do. Explore things to do in Manchester , from its iconic attractions to hidden gems. Whether you’re here for a concert, festival, or a relaxing weekend, the city has something for everyone. For accommodation and places to stay , Manchester offers a variety of options, from luxury hotels in the city centre to budget-friendly stays . Wherever you choose to stay, you’ll be within reach of the city’s top activities and attractions . The story behind the Manchester bee – and why it’s used everywhere in the city Your browser is not supported for this experience. We recommend using Chrome, Firefox, Edge, or Safari. Skip navigation Skip to main content Family Friendly Create lasting memories with our guide to family-friendly attractions in Manchester. From… Restaurants Discover Manchester's culinary delights with our Restaurants guide. From cosy neighbourhood… What's on at Manchester Opera House & Palace Theatre Indulge in the grandeur of theatrical splendor at Manchester Opera House and Palace Theatre, two… Follow us Christmas in Manchester Christmas is a magical time in Greater Manchester and the perfect occasion to combine a short festive break with a spot of Christmas shopping. Back The story behind the Manchester bee – and why it’s used everywhere in the city By Visit Manchester on Mar. 20, 2020 6 min read By Anne Beswick There are bees all over Manchester, swarms of those sweetest and busiest of insects are everywhere. Even in the depths of winter they are here, on every bollard and bench, on buildings and bins all over our city. The bee is the symbol of Manchester and this city of industry is rightly proud of its link with the hard-working insect. In 1842, the early city fathers had to decide on a coat of arms that would tell the world who we were. It was a Victorian branding exercise. They included a globe with seven bees to show how we worked and traded across the seven seas. The Manchester bee was born of industry. Manchester’s bee is a worker bee, reflecting a city made by the workers; made by the people, not a city that has grown from royal patronage or easy natural resources. Mancunians have worked hard to make this place thrive. The standard bee on our street furniture has been around since the 1970s but most of our bees are 19 th century creations. Bee-spotting is a good way to spend time in the city. When you’re strolling the streets, look up, look around and you’ll see them everywhere. On the coat of arms on the exterior of Manchester Town Hall - which is currently undertaking a large refurbishment to lovingly return it to its 1868 splendour - you will find the busy worker bees proudly displayed. You’ll see lots of references to cotton on the building, and cotton was the industry that made Manchester rich, the city’s equivalent of honey. More bees can be found at Spring Gardens, Hotel Gotham and Zizzi in King Street has a fine traditional beehive in the window that you can view whilst walking past. There is Beehive mill in Ancoats, and St Ann’s Square has oversized 1980s bees opposite the Royal Exchange . Stroll down to the Kimpton Clocktower on Oxford Road and look way up, at the clock face where bees tell the quarter hours. The ancient-and-modern University of Manchester also has three large bee symbols on its coat of arms. Manchester claimed the bee because she is an industrious little grafter, individually insignificant but collectively a superorganism. Together we are stronger. And bees are amazing; jaw-droppingly stunning. An individual worker bee lives for about three weeks in the busiest summer months. She visits between 50 to 100 flowers on each flight and up to 2,000 flowers daily. As well as producing honey she makes beeswax, propolis (a sort of disinfectant that is plastered around the entrance to the hive) and royal jelly to feed the queen. Worker bees are all female whilst the males are called drones. The latter are useful for one thing then they are thrown out of the hive and the females get on with all the work.  Please consider this and draw your own conclusions. Just remember that Manchester is well-known for its strong women! Emmeline Pankhurst, Enriqueta Rylands, Dame Nancy Rothwell, Maxine Peake, to name a few. The special thing about the human relationship with bees is that we can control them and exploit their products. Honeybees ( Apis mellifera ) are the only insects that have been domesticated and have been since at least the days of the ancient Egyptians. Jars of honey were found in the tomb of Tutankhamun. The Old English custom of “telling the bees” reflects the close bond between beekeeper and bee-kept. This commands that all major family issues (births, marriages and deaths but general gossip too) must be reported to the bees or they will fly off, die, or fail to produce honey. This could be seen as a quaint old custom or just a way of encouraging that proper attention is paid to the hive. And Manchester did not always pay good attention to her adopted insects. One thing we are not so proud of hereabouts is that we practically invented air pollution or, at least, the Industrial Revolution left us with a legacy of biological degradation second to none. We have spent many years rebuilding our environment and connecting back with the wider world around us and this means that our bees are back! There are beehives all around the city, on top of the Cathedral , the Printworks , Manchester Art Gallery , Manchester Central conference centre and even on some commercial buildings around the city. These bees are lovingly tended to by volunteers with an evangelical zeal for their new charges. Come the warmer days of spring and summer, real honeybees flit above our heads, busy as Mancunians. Proper Manchester honey can even be bought in some of the associated buildings and their shops. The Manchester and District beekeepers Association (mdbka.com) has its home at Heaton Park just north of the city where you can see a demonstration hive and get lots of information and advice if you wish to give beekeeping a go. We can all help the bees. Even if you don’t think that baggy combination of white canvas and netting is quite your look you can do your bit by putting out food for bees. They need flowers; simple, open flowers from spring to autumn. They like native and exotic species equally; bees aren’t prejudiced, as long as there is nectar, pollen and easy access. You can be part of this and grow your own bee-friendly flowers. In the Spring, bees love; rosemary, pussy willow, bluebell, primrose, and Hawthorne. Mid-summer calls for other plants such as; foxglove, honeysuckle, sage, clover, geranium, teasel, and thyme; and bee-friendly plants that grow in late Summer/Autumn include; buddleia, heather, lavender, marjoram, sedum, and Ivy. In Manchester, flowers are coming back too. Planters are dotted about, flowering green walls appearing, gardens are springing up in previously unlikely spaces and sympathetic apartment dwellers are planting windowsills and balconies and welcoming the bees. Local people are working together to blur the division between urban and rural and the bees are back. Manchester is back too. After many mid-twentieth century years in the doldrums, this city is on a rapid ascent. As well as all the business, sport, culture and conferences, tourists are coming in ever-larger numbers. Before the Industrial Revolution bees made honey and people loved it.  Industry turned the world upside down forever. Manchester, the original, modern city was born. Now the city is growing up and linking back to the best bits of the past.  Welcome home bees. Super Duper Family Festival Food Halls in Manchester If you're craving new flavours or are an indecisive eater looking for a variety of options, Manchester’s street food scene is your ultimate destination. With a wide array of cuisines and dishes, there's something for every taste. Manchester’s street food halls offer the perfect spot to indulge in delicious meals. Best Street Food in Manchester Manchester’s street food offering is a fusion of cultures and flavours, all under one roof. From Mexican tacos and Asian bao buns to gourmet burgers and vegan delights, there's no shortage of options for food lovers. Whether you're seeking a quick snack or a full meal, street food markets provide a fun, casual dining experience that everyone can enjoy. Why Street Food Halls are a Favourite in Manchester In recent years, street food halls in Manchester have become a must-visit for both residents and tourists. These lively, bustling spaces bring together a mix of local vendors and international food stalls, offering an eclectic selection of dishes. The best part? You’ll always find something new and exciting to try — no matter your cravings. Where to Find Manchester’s Best Street Food Manchester boasts a variety of street food markets and food halls, each offering something unique. Mackie Mayor is a stunning indoor market known for its focus on quality and locally sourced ingredients, making it a must-visit for food lovers. If you're in the mood for a relaxed, outdoor vibe, Grub Manchester is the place to be, serving up delicious street food alongside craft beers. For those looking for a centrally located, bustling spot, Arndale Market is perfect, offering a wide range of international flavours all in one vibrant space.
