lit.COLOGNE 2026 - Europe's biggest literature festival To content Search What are you looking for? Events Sights Gastronomy Bike tours KölnCard Booking PDF Share lit.COLOGNE Tip Lecture/reading Europe’s biggest literature festival Toni Morrison, Jonathan Franzen, Paul Auster, Donna Leon - but also Karl Lagerfeld, Patti Smith, Charles Aznavour and Angela Merkel, they've all been there. We’re talking about Europe’s biggest literature festival, which takes place in Cologne once a year: lit.COLOGNE. If you’re looking for the emotions evoked when the intellectual world of literature and written culture is enlivened by in-person presence, lit.COLOGNE is the exciting framework where you can find them. Its events are held in unusual places and feature outstanding figures from the world of literature. Tip : The lit.COLOGNE spezial 2025 offers a literary highlight to kick off the book autumn. Three remarkable authors – Ocean Vuong, Caroline Wahl, and Susanne Abel – will present their latest works. The annual blockbuster event for all lovers of literature Every spring, up to 200 events attended by almost 100,000 visitors are held over a period of almost two weeks. During this time, lit.COLOGNE offers an extraordinary stage on which all lovers of culture and literature have a chance to encounter one of their favourite authors. You can look forward to an inspiring experience of the literature and themes you’re interested in — at lit.COLOGNE. The programme is published and advance ticket sales begin in December every year lit.COLOGNE, the paradise for literature fans, is held in a variety of locations and interesting venues all over Cologne. There are many events that have been specially planned for the festival, ranging from theme-oriented evening events to readings, individual talks or portraits, and much more. If you want to meet outstanding nonfiction authors, exciting newcomers or Nobel Prize laureates working in varying genres live in Cologne, you’ll have brilliant opportunities at lit.COLOGNE. The festival is always characterized by a wide spectrum of themes that cut through bestseller lists, mass media and high culture. Thanks to its status as an outstanding annual cultural event, lit.COLOGNE has collected numerous awards in recent years. For example, a gala event at the WDR-Funkhaus radio hall opens lit.COLOGNE with the presentation of the German Audiobook Prize. The annual programme for the coming year’s event is presented at the beginning of December, and ticket sales also begin at that time. The organizers thoughtfully cater to visitors’ needs. Since 2013, many of the events have been barrier-free. Sign language interpreters, as well as induction loops for hearing aid users, are provided. For children and young people, lit.COLOGNE offers lit.kid.COLOGNE Enjoy lit.COLOGNE with the whole family! From the very start, the festival has included a special area designed in detail for kids and teenagers, starting with preschoolers and primary school-age children. The readings are held in immersive venues that bring books together with a real-life environment. The aim is to give young eyes and ears a special experience! There are also readings of great books for school classes. One figure alone shows that the organizers are seriously committed to the idea of making literature fun for a younger audience: in 2022, 78 of the total of 179 events were designed for children and teenagers. All information: lit.kid.COLOGNE Offshoots of lit.COLOGNE: lit.COLOGNE Special, phil.cologne & lit.Ruhr Since 2011, lit.COLOGNE Special has been held simultaneously with the Frankfurt Book Fair, thus providing an additional literature festival in the autumn. Another offshoot of lit.COLOGNE, a philosophy festival known as phil.COLOGNE , has been held since 2013. By presenting philosophical dialogues and related events, it offers a broad audience access to philosophy and its real-life themes in a non-university setting. Another event organized by lit.COLOGNE is lit.RUHR , which has been held in the Ruhr region since 2017. Its main venue is the Zollverein coal mine industrial complex in Essen. Like lit.COLOGNE, this festival also offers a programme for children and teenagers: lit.kid.RUHR. New format at lit.COLOGNE: lit.COLOGNE POP - all forms of art and culture lit.COLOGNE POP takes a special role within lit.COLOGNE and, as an independent platform, is addressed primarily to the younger audience. Its programme covers all kinds of forms of culture: discourse, literature, music, theatre, film, analogue encounters that reflect current topics, topics that influence us, that trigger and move us - over two days. The lit.COLOGNE POP will end with a club night. About the history of lit.COLOGNE, held in Cologne since 2001 The concept behind lit.COLOGNE was born in 2000 against the background of the organizers’ dissatisfaction with the way literature was being presented back then. Readings held in bookstores were only attracting small audiences. The organizers felt that book lovers should be able to look forward to a richer experience and a more stimulating atmosphere for encountering authors. A new model was offered by the film, music and theatre scene. The organizers decided to add professional presenters and translators to the mix and to showcase dialogue-oriented literary events more substantively as communicative encounters. Incidentally, lit.COLOGNE was included in the Guinness Book of Records in 2006 for organizing the world’s biggest German lesson — an event that was held in the sold-out Lanxess Arena. Cologne sights: the most important destinations | Cologne Tourism To content Search What are you looking for? Events Sights Gastronomy Bike tours KölnCard Booking Sights in Cologne Cologne is home to about one million people — and about six million visitors come to this metropolis on the Rhine every year to explore the city and its tourist attractions. Of course the most outstanding highlights are Cologne Cathedral and the city’s 12 famous Romanesque churches. One good thing about Cologne is that you can combine visits to many highlights, monuments, hotspots and museums by simply walking around — for example, from the Cathedral through the Altstadt (Old Town) to the Rheinauhafen (Rheinau Harbour) district and back along the Rhine. Or you can visit the Zoo and the Flora botanical garden, cross the Rhine in a cable car and walk back along the right bank, crossing the Rhine again to the Cathedral via the Hohenzollernbrücke with its load of “love locks” weighing many tonnes. Cologne is a green metropolis with many attractive parks and gardens that offer pleasant opportunities to relax after gathering so many new impressions. Arts & Culture in Cologne | Cologne Tourism To content Search What are you looking for? Events Sights Gastronomy Bike tours KölnCard Booking Art & Culture Cologne: 2,000 years of being “in” Cologne’s more than 2,000 years of history — the city’s DNA, so to speak — includes a flourishing art scene that dates back to the Middle Ages. In addition to many ancient treasures and cultural monuments, Cologne boasts a remarkably dense network of galleries, a very active art scene, one of the world’s oldest art fairs, and many events across every genre of art and culture throughout the year. From exhibitions to guided tours, performances, evergreens, festivals and urban art, there’s an attractive mix of tradition and modernity that has become a hallmark of Cologne’s range of cultural offerings. Stunksitzung The cabaret alternative program to the carnival Info about the Stunksitzung Kolumba Cologne Extraordinary art museum of the Archdiocese of Cologne All info about Kolumba Sights The most important sights at a glance More about the sights Gloria in Cologne Since 1956. for theater, concert, party, comedy All info about the Gloria Museum of Applied Art in Cologne Extensive collections from 800 years of European craftsmanship All info about the museum Museum Ludwig Cologne One of the most important art museums in Europe All info about Museum Ludwig Chocolate Museum Cologne The world of chocolate The Chocolate Museum C ulture Enjoy, learn and discover Cologne is renowned as the home of many highlights of the German cultural scene — for example, its festivals of contemporary music and high-quality literature from all over the world. It’s also known for pure entertainment. Its many venues, including smaller ones, for concerts, events and readings create an appealing framework for the city’s cultural scene. Here you can take a look at Cologne’s evergreens and its current event calendar. Culture in Cologne Events in Cologne M useums “Must-visits” In addition to its famous municipal museums, Cologne has numerous private museums, collections and exhibition venues. Some of them are still being discovered by long-term residents of Cologne! The spectrum of Cologne’s museums ranges from traditional art museums to museums specializing in technology, local history, cultural history and culinary history. It’s time to explore other perspectives and discover new horizons… Museums in Cologne S treet Art Urban life – with a message Cologne is one of Germany’s hotspots for street art. Several routes, guided tours and specialized galleries offer you an entry into the street art scene. You can see a lot of this public art — including its messages of social criticism — in neighbourhoods such as Ehrenfeld and the Belgian Quarter as well as in the city centre. And for all those who are interested in creative approaches to the socialization of city, art and life, a look at the Ebertplatz is highly recommended. The street is calling you… Street Art in Cologne S ights Exploring and discovering history Cologne Cathedral is a landmark with a long history and probably the city’s best-known attraction. It’s impossible to miss — but only a few people actually climb the 533 steps to its 157-meter-high viewing platform. Will you be one of them? Also worth a visit are Cologne’s historic Altstadt (Old Town), the Cologne Zoo, the Flora botanical gardens, the new Rheinauhafen (Rheinau Harbour), the bridges over the Rhine with their “love locks”, the four remaining city gates, the brewery restaurants and the cable car. You can experience many of the highlights of Cologne’s history in a walking tour during a single day. Stunksitzung Cologne 2026: humour for the thinking man | Cologne Tourist Board To content Search What are you looking for? Events Sights Gastronomy Bike tours KölnCard Booking PDF Share Stunksitzung Tip Custom/culture Since 1984 there’s been a cabaret-style alternative programme for celebrating Carnival In recent years, the Stunksitzung has featured “The rat and the mouse”, i.e. the Pope in bed with a cardinal; a sketch in which Bishop Walter Mixa describes Pope Benedict XVI as “the Lord’s weasel, as dumb as a roll of communion wafers”; and a crucifix labelled “Tünnes” (a traditional figure of fun in Cologne). Is this your kind of irreverent humour? If so, we recommend this alternative Carnival programme, because the Stunksitzung’s mockery of current social and political topics has lost none of its sharp satirical bite over the years. Definitely not a traditional “Prunksitzung”: the thinking man’s Carnival revue The Stunksitzung is an antidote to political correctness, and its impudence is legendary. It’s a cabaret show that’s the direct opposite of the numerous “Prunksitzungen” held during Carnival. Both kinds of events are fixed components of Cologne’s “fifth season”. If you’re not keen on the swaying and jollity of the traditional “Prunksitzungen” and prefer the kind of alternative entertainment that satirizes politicians, the German army, the Catholic Church and the Carnival associations such as the Rote Funken, the Stunksitzung belongs on your Carnival agenda. Be sure to buy your ticket well ahead of time and enjoy one of the many Stunksitzung performances during the months before the Street Carnival and pub Carnival  begin. The Stunksitzung ensemble: an alternative tradition The Stunksitzung ensemble was founded in 1983 and held its first session in 1984 — and many members of the original ensemble are still active today. The president of this event until 1995 was its co-founder Jürgen Becker, a renowned German cabaret artist also known as “Heinz the Iroquois”. He was succeeded by Biggi Wanninger in 1999. The house band that has played at the Stunksitzung since 1988 is the Köbes Underground. And since 1991 the event’s venue, to which the fans flock, has been the E-Werk in Cologne-Mülheim. Biting, ironic, critical: beyond old-fashioned jokes and marching-band music The programme takes jabs at international politics and dislikeable characters all over the globe, and it features typically sharp local sketches and artistic numbers. If you like to laugh and enjoy seeing comedians taking swipes at Cologne’s Carnival and its traditional programme, come to the Stunksitzung — there won’t be a dry eye in the house. Kölle alaaf! Read more Dates Useful Information Payment methods Booking of tickets Eligibility Bad Weather Offer Suitable for any Weather Target Group Adult Target Group the Elderly for Groups for individual guests Parking facilities The E-Werk is located on the right bank of the Rhine, on the Schäl Sick. Events Sights Gastronomy Bike tours KölnCard Booking Culture in Cologne A feast for the senses, challenges for the mind, sophisticated entertainment — Cologne can do culture. Again and again, it shines the spotlights on famous artists, authors and other stars of the culture scene. In addition to famous venues, Cologne also offers small and intimate theatres and venues where a cultural event can become an absolute highlight through the up-close experience of an artist from the field of literature, music, theatre, comedy or the like. FAQ: Frequently asked questions about Cologne | Cologne Tourism To content Search What are you looking for? Events Sights Gastronomy Bike tours KölnCard Booking FAQ Practical questions at a glance Where can I exchange currency/money? Ria Money Transfer (Hohe Straße 142, 50667 Cologne) Reisebank in the Central Station (Trankgasse 11, Bahnhofsvorplatz, 50667 Cologne) Where can I purchase Tickets for the public transportation? At the ticket automats in the Central Station as well as the automats inside the tram or underground lines At the VRS booth in the travel desk/office (Reisezentrum) of the Central Station At the KVB booth in the Central Station (located in the lower level of the train station, which leads to the underground platform) Where can I store my luggage? In the lockers within the Central Station In the luggage deposit in the Central Station (in the lobby of the Central Station) A few lockers are available at the train station "Bahnhof Köln Messe-Deutz" Where can I find the taxis/cabs? At the cab/taxi stand next to the Cologne Tourist Board, Burgmauer At the cab/taxi stand at the Central Station (Bahnhofsvorplatz/Dompropst-Ketzer-Straße) Taxi-Ruf Köln (Tel.: +49 (0) 221 2882) Where can I park my car in the center of the town/near the Cathedral? Inside the underground car park at the Cathedral (Kurt-Hackenberg-Platz 2, 50667 Cologne) Inside the underground car park at the Philharmonic (Bischofsgartenstraße 1, 50667 Cologne) Inside the Central Station underground car park (Breslauer Platz 1, 50668 Cologne) Where can I get an environmental sticker for my car/vehicle? At the public office in downtown Cologne (Laurenzplatz 1-3, 50667 Cologne) At the auto checkpoints and auto repairs which are generally responsible for major and exhaust pipe emissions of vehicles Markant Tankstelle (Rolshover Straße 420, 51105 Cologne; Tel.: +49 (0) 221 8301240, open daily 24 h) SB-Tankstelle Z. Hariklar (Schmittgasse 44, 51143 Cologne; Tel.: +49 (0) 2203 982111, opening hours Saturdays and Sundays: 8 a.m. till 8 p.m., Monday till Friday: 7 a.m. till 9 p.m.) SB-Tankstelle Keimes (Dellbrücker Hauptstraße 9-11, 51069 Cologne; Tel.: +49 (0) 221. 684754, opening hours Sundays: 8 a.m. till 10 p.m., Monday till Saturday: 7 a.m. till 10 p.m.) More information on the Website of the City of Cologne . Where are the nearest bathrooms/restrooms in proximity of the Cathedral? Mc Clean-WC Center in the Central Station (E-Passage, open 24 h) WC on the southwest corner of Cologne Cathedral (down the stairs, where you would also enter the tower of Cologne Cathedral, Monday till Sunday: 8 a.m. till 9 p.m.) Where are the closest Pharmacies to the Central Station and Cologne Cathedral? There is a Pharmacy (Apotheke im Hauptbahnhof) inside the Central Station (located at the platforms 10 & 11 at the backside exit towards Breslauer Platz) Dom-Apotheke (Bahnhofsvorplatz 1, 50667 Cologne) Where can I find the next baby-care or baby changing room in the city centre? Mc Clean-WC Center in the Central Station (E-Passage, open 24 h) Railway mission in the Central Station (children's lounge, platform 1 E, accessible by elevator). The room can also be used for undisturbed breastfeeding. It is possible to heat food in the microwave. The railway mission is open daily from 7.00 - 19.00 hrs. In the DM supermarket (Minoritenstraße 1, 50667 Cologne) Where can I charge my mobile phone? You can find lockers in the Central Station where it is also possible to charge mobile phones (A-Passage, next to the staircase leading to platform 1). Where can I rent a wheelchair? The station mission offers to lend a wheelchair on deposit. It is important to call in advance, as a vehicle must always remain in the station mission. 49 (0) 221. 1395-438. The railway mission is open daily from 7.00 - 19.00 hrs. The offer is free of charge, but you are welcome to make a donation. At the company Stortz (Fleischmengergasse 49-51, 50676 Cologne; Tel.: +49 (0) 221 949755 0, open Monday till Friday: 9:30 a.m. till 6 p.m., Saturdays: 10 a.m. till 2 p.m.). Where can I purchase Tickets for long distance busses or FlixTrain? At the travel agency LufthansaCityCenter Frenzen on Breslauer Platz (Johannisstraße 54, 50668 Cologne) At the Kiosk at the roundabout on Marzellenstraße On the websites or via the apps of the different proprietors of long distance busses and trains How do I get to the trade fair grounds of Koelnmesse? From the Central Station you can take the S-trains S 6-19, all generally departing from platform 10 Regional trains leaving from Central Station to Köln Messe-Deutz You can use the underground lines no. 3 or 4 from the stations Neumarkt or Appellhofplatz and get out at the stations Köln Messe-Deutz or Koelnmesse The tram lines no. 1 or 9 depart from Neumarkt or Heumarkt and bring you to the stop Köln Messe-Deutz How do I get to the airport form the Central Station? With the train lines S19, RB27 or RE6 to the station Köln/Bonn Airport (approx. 15 minutes travel time). Transcript

Tourist Information: Plan Cologne digitally or analogue To content Search What are you looking for? Events Sights Gastronomy Bike tours KölnCard Booking PDF Share Tourist Information Cologne Tourist information A premier address for guests from all over the world. Since 1955. It is said: from here you have the best view of the Cologne Cathedral. This was already true in 1955 when the building of the Tourist Information Cologne was constructed as the “House of Tourism” and it still applies today: after extensive modernization and more digitalization in guest consultations. We look forward welcoming you to Cologne and providing you with all the information you need – on sights, events, as well as culinary offerings and personal tips for your stay. The modern concept integrates contemporary informational habits with the stylistic charm of the '50s. Thus, listed elements stand alongside digital stations, conversation islands, and touchscreens as complements or alternatives to personal consultations and service in multiple languages. A cozy book and reading corner invites you to stay and browse before you head upstairs via the original '50s curved staircase to the “balcony with a view” where you also find the inspirational gift shop. From Touchscreen to Your Own Smartphone – or Analog Through a large interactive map or via one of the touchscreens at the counters, you can browse various route suggestions or use the experience planner for sights, events, dining tips, or hotels in the foyer. Everything can be transferred to your smartphone via QR code – for when you're on the go. This also works with regard to personal consultations at the counters. You can find answers to frequently asked questions about your stay in Cologne, such as “Where can I charge my phone?” in the FAQ – with various informational materials available classically in print on-site or as PDF for download. Centrally Located and Welcoming: Including Souvenir Shop on the 1st Floor with a View of the Cathedral Conveniently located in close proximity to the main train station , Cologne Cathedral , Hohe Strasse , and the old town , the Tourist Information at Kardinal-Höffner-Platz 1 offers you a perfect start for your visit: Get inspired here for your exciting stay in Cologne. But before you put your Cologne plans into action, don’t forget to take in the view from the window on the 1st floor of the main portal of the Cathedral. This is also where the CologneShop is located with Cologne souvenirs, brand, fan, and decorative items, as well as many accessories. A Little Journey Back to the Tourism of the '50s... Not only because of its listed architecture and interior design with mosaic columns, wall murals, and staircase does the Tourist Information stand as an exemplar of the '50s. As an institution it also reminds you of the years of progress and economic boom. After the austere post-war years, in the '50s and with the advent of the economic miracle, Germans slowly rediscovered their wanderlust: Dolce Vita instead of drudge work, guesthouses, and guest rooms instead of staying home. Besides tours on foot, by bike, or train to the seaside or the Black Forest, many people also returned to the Rhine metropolis of Cologne. The first point of contact was often just this house of tourism with its three golden crowns on the bay window – symbolically for the Three Wise Men, whose relics rest directly opposite in Cologne Cathedral. A lovely symbolic connection, don’t you think? House of Tourism from 1955 The building was erected in 1955 following the plans of the renowned Cologne architect Hans Joachim Lohmeyer, who was significantly involved in the city's reconstruction. The factual, simple facade, and functional design is typical of the 1950s architecture, as these buildings could be efficiently constructed and flexibly used for various offices. The old “traffic office” with its tourism department was destroyed in the war. The latest modernization with its new interior reminiscent of the 1950s has made the building not only touristic but also energetically fit for the future – everywhere if possible, in consideration of existing monument protection regulations. Case Maclaim - Ensorinstituut - Blauwkasteelstraat | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken Case Maclaim - Ensorinstituut - Blauwkasteelstraat The Crystal Ship brings James Ensor to life in Ostend. The artist speaks to you via augmented reality . In celebration of the James Ensor Year, he not only speaks directly to the audience, but some of his characteristic masks are also available as Instagram filters. Case Maclaim was the perfect street artist to create a portrait of James Ensor - based on his famous 'Self-portrait with masks' from 1899, but including the white 'smiley' that often returns in Case Maclaim's portraits. On this page Bring the artwork to life with augmented reality About Case Maclaim Use face filters on Facebook or Instagram Video: Case Maclaim at work in Ostend All Ensor works from The Crystal Ship Interactive audio walk: The Baths of Ostend Bring the artwork to life with augmented reality Click the button below to open the application in Facebook or Instagram. Use your camera towards the artwork to 'scan' the wall. Turn on your sound and enjoy the experience: the artwork will move and Ensor will speak to you (with real audio clips of Ensor himself). Try it with Facebook Try it with Instagram About Case Maclaim Up until Case Maclaim got involved, street art was characterised by a rather cartoonish style with bold typography. At the end of the 20th century, the German artist and his Ma’Claim Crew put a startling end to that. In fact, today Maclaim is seen as the godfather of (photo)realistic street art , as the guy who erased the line between graffiti and painting. In short, the perfect street artist to create a portrait of James Ensor – based on his illustrious 1899 Self-Portrait with Masks , but featuring the white ‘smiley face’ that often recurs in Case Maclaim’s portraits. Case Maclaim - 2024 Use face filters on Facebook or Instagram Imagine yourself part of an Ensor work for a moment? Click the button below to open the filters in Facebook or Instagram. Use your selfie camera towards yourself to 'scan' your face. The filter will appear over your face. Be sure to try all three! The best results may always be shared using @thecrystalshipostende and #thecrystalship. Try it with Facebook Try it with Instagram All Ensor works from The Crystal Ship Katie Green Caco Pixelpancho Hera Wayne Horse Case Maclaim - 2024 Case Maclaim - 2024 Jaune - 2024 Jaune - 2024 Zio Ziegler Tip: also discover the interactive audio walk: The Baths of Ostend As part of The Crystal Ship, artist Jaune painted miniature scenes of Ostend residents on 30 Ostend façades, which seem straight out of the original work. With a contemporary touch and the requisite satire, he breathes new life into them and also entered into conversation with the residents. Their unique stories and connection to Ensor were immortalised in an audio route . The interactive walk is available in the free app 'Ostend City Walks' under 'The Crystal Ship'. Ministerie van Unieke Zaken | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken Ministerie van Unieke Zaken Contact secretariaat@von-b.be von-b.be Location Adolf Buylstraat 12 Oostende 8400 Show location on map The Ministry of Unique Affairs wages a cheerful jihad against uniformity and sourness, under the dictatorship of whim. As befits a proper Ministry, we have neatly organised everything into departments. In the Department of Curses, you'll find the funniest greeting cards and calendars; in the "Kiss My Clothes" Department, we stock fair-trade textiles with the best t-shirts and sweaters. Mugs for every mood and sense of humour can be found in the Department of Household Goods. And we wrap things up with the Department of Domestic Bags. Each and every product and design is unique, locally conceived and made under the best conditions for people and animals alike. The clues offered in the booklet, help to discover the false Ensor in the James Ensor House. Outside again, the Ostend of Ensor awaits you for the family trail. It's packed with fun assignments and crazy riddles and guides you through the city that was Ensor's muze. It is recommended to book tickets online in advance as time slots will be used! Facilities for children in The James Ensor House: Reduced rate for children aged 6-14 Free entrance for children <6 years old Interactive children's tour in the experience centre Offer for children in the museum shop Tailored to kids Ensor walk through the city Lift available for prams Nursing table in the toilets A cultural outing with the kids: is this a good idea? Our answer to this is short and sweet: of course it is! In a playful and interactive way, young visitors learn all about the wonderful world of James Ensor. The clues offered in the booklet, help to discover the false Ensor in the James Ensor House. Outside again, the Ostend of Ensor awaits you for the family trail. It's packed with fun assignments and crazy riddles and guides you through the city that was Ensor's muze. On a quest for the false Ensor House servant Gust takes you through the James Ensor House and reveals many secrets. Armed with all this information, we're certain that you'll expose that one false Ensor! The James Ensor house offers numerous interactive installations that are fun for kids: the interactive wall, the puzzle screens, the photo corner, and the studio where children can crawl into. Kids who have discovered the false Ensor receive a nice reward at reception! Info & tickets The James Ensor House Walking through the city of Ensor Back outside, the Ostend of Ensor awaits. After visiting The James Ensor House, why not take a walk, just like Ensor strolled so often through his beloved city? For the parents, there is an interactive digital walk, available for € 5.49 in the App Store or Google Play. For children, ask for the family walk with fun assignments at the reception of The James Ensor house and explore Ensor's beloved city together! The Mercator had only two commanders and made 41 voyages. In 1956 it repatriated  the remains of Father Damien from Molokai. In 1960, it sailed into the harbour of Antwerp and in 1961, it was equipped as a museum ship. Since 1964, it has been the pearl in Ostend's crown. Marvin Gaye Midnight Love Tour | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken Marvin Gaye Midnight Love Tour Marvin Gaye arrived by boat in Ostend on a cold winter morning in 1981. The singer had fled the US, without a penny to his name and battling a cocaine addiction. His arrival marked the beginning of a fascinating tale about Ostend and Marvin Gaye and how they influenced each other. The Ostend concert promoter Freddy Cousaert took Gaye under his wing, managing to keep him clean and getting him back on track. One and a half year later Gaye would make an amazing comeback with his LP 'Midnight Love' and above all his single Sexual Healing, which he recorded in Belgium. During the 'Midnight Love Tour' documentary walk you can find out more about his comeback and how the worldwide hit 'Sexual Healing' was created. In addition to the master's voice himself, you can also hear contributions by Jan Hautekiet, Patrick De Witte, Freddie Cousaert, Jamie Lidell, Arno and many others. This digital walk is available for  5,49 via Google Play Store or in the AppStore. Duration of the walk: 1,5 - 2 hours Monacoplein 2, +32 59 70 11 99 All contact details This digital walk (4.6 km) is available for € 5,49 via Google Play Store or in the App Store . Is my dog allowed on the beach? | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken Is my dog allowed on the beach? Dogs are allowed on the beaches without any restriction from October 1 to March 31 . Dogs remain welcome on the beach in April, May, June and September, but only before 10 a.m. and after 6:30 p.m . During the months of July and August dogs are allowed before 10 a.m. and after 8 p.m . Exception: All year long and 24/24, dogs are allowed in the following areas: between beach head 5 on the east bank and the border with the municipality of Bredene on the 'Little Beach' between the west pier and the west jetty. Dogs must be kept on a leash on this part! in the area between Westlaan (Raversijde) (beach head 15bis) and the border with the municipality of Middelkerke (between beach heads 19 and 20. Dogs must be kept on a leash on this part! Certified assistance dogs as well as assistance dogs in training accompanied by their trainer or host family are always allowed on the beach. Dogs must always be kept on a leash : on the 'Little Beach' between the west pier and the west jetty on the Sportstrand in the area between Westlaan (Raversijde) (beach head 15bis) and the border with the municipality of Middelkerke (between beach heads 19 and 20). The owner and / or supervisor of the dog should always be able to take full control of his/her dog. Public order may not be disturbed by the presence of the dog. Click here to view a map. I, Léon Spilliaert | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken I, Léon Spilliaert The famed Ostend artist Léon Spilliaert is known for his enigmatic works. But what if you could step into his world yourself? In Ostend, an innovative installation offers you that chance: a unique experience where you can see the city and art through Spilliaert's eyes. Monacoplein 2, +32 59 70 11 99 All contact details This digital walk (6.45 km) is available via Google Play Store or in the App Store . Download via Google Play Download in the App Store I, Léon Spilliaert Your Portrait, as a Work of Art by Spilliaert Imagine: you're strolling past the window display of the info center, and suddenly you see yourself—not just your own reflection, but a portrait in Spilliaert's style, as if the artist himself had just captured you on canvas. Thanks to a clever video filter, your image is transformed in real time into a mysterious artwork, displayed within a beautifully framed setting. A Holographic Encounter with Spilliaert Want to dive deeper? In the info center of Tourism Ostend, a fascinating, interactive installation awaits, immersing you fully in Spilliaert’s world. Through advanced hologram technology, you see the artist come to life. His self-portraits blend seamlessly into one another, as though you’re conversing with Spilliaert himself while wandering through his Ostend. Walking with Léon Spilliaert In 1935, Léon Spilliaert, the famed Ostend artist, faced a significant change in his life. He and his family were about to move to Brussels, but before saying farewell to his beloved birthplace, he took one last walk through Ostend. This journey, now brought back to life through the art walk in the Ostend City Walks app, offers a unique chance to walk through the city from Spilliaert's own perspective. Whether you’re an art lover, a local from Ostend, or simply curious about Spilliaert's life, this walk offers an engaging and relatable experience for everyone. The art walk is more than a tribute to Spilliaert; it’s a time-travel journey through his Ostend, where art, memory, and the city blend seamlessly into one. It’s Sunday at sea! | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken It’s Sunday at sea! Contact +32 59 51 68 62 info@muzee.be muzee.be Location Venetiaanse Gaanderijen Oostende 8400 Show location on map Opening hours Open today Open tomorrow Sat 28 Jun 2025 to Sun 22 Feb 2026 This week Mon 15 Dec 2025 Closed Tue 16 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Wed 17 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Thu 18 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Fri 19 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Sat 20 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Sun 21 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Next week Mon 22 Dec 2025 Closed Tue 23 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Wed 24 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Thu 25 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Fri 26 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Sat 27 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Sun 28 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 In 2 weeks Mon 29 Dec 2025 Closed Tue 30 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Wed 31 Dec 2025 10:00-17:30 Thu 1 Jan 2026 10:00-17:30 Fri 2 Jan 2026 10:00-17:30 Sat 3 Jan 2026 10:00-17:30 Sun 4 Jan 2026 10:00-17:30 Prices €12 groepen vanaf 10 personen: 10 EUR jongeren van 13 tot en met 25 jaar: 3 EUR kinderen tot en met 12 jaar: 0 EUR Book your ticket now What draws people to the sea again and again? What do they hope to find or feel there? The allure is timeless. Artists try to capture that feeling – their own longing, but that of others too. Ostend expanded to become the ‘Queen of Seaside Resorts’ in the 19th century and is still the place where many Belgians go to encounter the sea today. Both the E40 and the longest IC train in the country lead to it. Mu.ZEE plays a special role in this city by the sea: the museum focuses on art in Belgium from 1880 until tomorrow. The exhibition It’s Sunday at sea! is not just about the appearance of the sea but, above all, what it means to people. The sea is both relaxing and spectacular. It can bring peace but also be overwhelming. Artists sometimes show it as it is, in the open. At other times, they recall it from memory, in dreamscapes or symbols. The sea gives rise to reflection and imagination. An important source of inspiration for the exhibition is the 1899 poem Vers la mer by Émile Verhaeren. This runs like a thread through the exhibition and connects the beginning of Mu.ZEE’s collection – around 1880 – with the present day. From artists such as Ensor and Spilliaert to contemporary names such as Lili Dujourie. Dujourie’s work Il fait dimanche sur la mer! takes its name from a line in Verhaeren’s poem. It shows the sea as it is seen from an apartment with a ‘view of the sea’ – a dream for many. Seven screens show one day of the week each, captured on video. What can you see? As a visitor, you are free to make up your own mind. Everyone’s experience of the sea is different. The title It’s Sunday at sea! sounds cheerful and inviting – Stefan Zweig even translates it as Sunday celebration. But perhaps it also evokes another feeling, such as the languor or stillness of a Sunday. Discover what the sea means to you in the exhibition itself. About Mu.ZEE breezes out In January 2025, Mu.ZEE closed the doors of its well-known main building in Romestraat, Ostend for three years as part of an extensive renovation. During this period, Mu.ZEE will remain active, not only in its own Permekemuseum in Jabbeke and Peiremuzee in Knokke-Heist, but also in the form of exhibitions in Amsterdam, Antwerp, Drogenbos and Koksijde. In Ostend itself, during the closure Mu.ZEE has taken up residence in the stately Venetian Galleries, designed by Henri Maquet and built between 1900 and 1903. Here Mu.ZEE shows the very best of itself, that is to say: art in Belgium from 1880 until tomorrow that speaks to the imagination. On the Ostend promenade overlooking the sea, parts of the Mu.ZEE collection are on display in three areas. The gallery offers space for four consecutive thematic exhibitions, of which It’s Sunday at sea! is the first. In the large hall, next to the gallery, the focus is on one work, artist, archive or ensemble. Lastly, at the back, an active depot offers a glimpse behind the scenes of museum operations and a fascinating collection. In a permanent experimental installation, Mu.ZEE is also examining and showing the influence of light on various materials for three years, thus reflecting on presentations after the reopening of Mu.ZEE in 2028. A brand new exhibition scenography for this temporary home was designed by Theo De Meyer, Laura Muyldermans and Yuichiro Onuma. Het zorgt voor warmte en gezelligheid in koude en donkere dagen. Het is de ideale tijd om in Oostende van cultuur en theater te genieten, of om een winterse outfit te kiezen voor kerst en nieuwjaar. Museum Amandine | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken Museum Amandine Contact +32 59 70 11 99 amandine@toerisme-oostende.be amandineoostende.be Location Vindictivelaan 35-z Oostende 8400 Show location on map Opening hours Closed today Open tomorrow This week Mon 15 Dec 2025 Closed Tue 16 Dec 2025 Closed Wed 17 Dec 2025 Closed Thu 18 Dec 2025 Closed Fri 19 Dec 2025 Closed Sat 20 Dec 2025 10:00-17:00 Sun 21 Dec 2025 10:00-17:00 Next week Mon 22 Dec 2025 Closed Tue 23 Dec 2025 10:00-17:00 Wed 24 Dec 2025 10:00-17:00 Thu 25 Dec 2025 10:00-17:00 Fri 26 Dec 2025 10:00-17:00 Sat 27 Dec 2025 10:00-17:00 Sun 28 Dec 2025 10:00-17:00 In 2 weeks Mon 29 Dec 2025 Closed Tue 30 Dec 2025 10:00-17:00 Wed 31 Dec 2025 10:00-17:00 Thu 1 Jan 2026 10:00-17:00 Fri 2 Jan 2026 10:00-17:00 Sat 3 Jan 2026 10:00-17:00 Sun 4 Jan 2026 10:00-17:00 Prices Default price: €7 Kids up to 4 years: Free Kids up to 12 years: €5 Students up to 26 years: €6 Groups from 20 people: €6 per person On 3 April 1995, the Amandine sailed into the port of Ostend for the last time. Fortunately, the Amandine was given a new life as a museum and you can now revisit this piece of maritime heritage. Using multimedia installations, your museum experience is taken to a higher level. The exhibition and the furnished Amandine give you a good idea of the rough life on board an Icelandic fisherman. Various scenes depict the activities on the boat. An intense experience for all the senses! Share this page Facebook Twitter Photo gallery Email* EN MAIN NEWSLETTER FORM Subscribe Thank you for subscribing ! Surrounded by his beloved dunes, close to his great love — the sea. Every year on April 13th, Ensor’s birthday, flowers are laid… Wellington Hippodrome This racetrack, neighbouring the Thermae Palace Hotel, is named after the Duke of Wellington. It is open all summer to anyone who enjoys a bit of a flutter or is simply fond of horses. During recent years the racetrack has increasingly been used for important concerts. Le Châtelet Iconic, eclectic corner building at the Petit Paris intersection. Was built in the western city extension completed after 1865 under the impetus of King Leopold II. Let yourself be guided by an enthusiastic team and experience the inner city of Ostend in an original way. This is how we deliberately keep the food chain short. Church of Our Lady of the Dunes The Dune church was made a listed monument in 1946. The trapezoidal cemetery with lawns, weeping willows and shrubs followed suit in 1975. Many of the people who are buried here belonged to well-known families of Mariakerke. No-one would expect this oasis of tranquillity and contemplation so near to the sea and Oostende's vibrant city centre. 

The Japanese Garden is open during weekends … Het Groen Lint Ostend has more to offer than just the sea. Did you know that Ostend has a surprisingly green city edge? To strengthen that green city edge, the City had a master plan developed to connect all green zones and landscapes: The Green Ribbon. This green ribbon forms an attractive 35 km loop for… Provincial domain Atlantikwall Raversyde The Provincial Domain Atlantikwall Raversyde is a unique natural area located close to the sea. A diverse landscape invites visitors to a lovely walk. Raversijde is also a home to a rescue centre for birds and wild animals (VOC). 
Go On Time Travel (+6) in the provincial domain Atlantikwall… Leopold Park Leopold Park was laid out in 1860 on the old town fortifications. The beautiful bandstand was inaugurated in 1885. The world-famous floral clock was placed there in 1963, where it still stands now. Sea excursions - Boat trips Enjoy sun, sea and water!
Take part in a lovely boat trip on the sea with Captain Blue from the port of Ostend. Enjoy the real sea air, it has been proven to be very beneficial for different aspects of your health. So, 100% vitamin SEA. You cruise along sailing yachts and coastal fishermen in… The Vicognebos – Ostend A little over 10 ha, Ostend's Vicogne wood consists of young woodland and polder meadows, while the Vicognezwin retention pond, an old antitank trench and the Spuikom basin provide the area with much-needed water. A winding walk will give you a glimpse of the open polder grasslands while taking you… Sluizencomplex Plassendale In the 17th century, the canals Ghent-Ostend and Oudenburg-Nieuwpoort were dug. These two canals were connected in the Plassendale district. Because of different sea currents, two locks were built, one of which was later moved to the Slijkens district, closer to Ostend. 

The cute Spanish toll… Floral Clock Several centuries ago, the Swedish naturalist Carl Linnaeus discovered that flowers always opened and closed at the same time of day. This observation led to the creation of the floral clock.
The clock you can admire today has been in its current location since 1963. Earlier versions were destroyed… Maria Hendrikapark The Maria Hendrikapark is an area of about 45 ha situated south of the city centre. The park has a variety of different ponds, open grass areas, two playgrounds and the Koninginnehof with cafetaria and restaurant, rowing boats, pedal boats, a traffic park, baby-carts and a miniature golf course. It… Children's farm 'De Lange Schuur' The children's farm is located in the Schorre on the edge of Ostend, south of the centre. The children's farm aims to introduce children and young people to all aspects of farm life, so that they may rediscover the connection with nature and the biotope of farm animals. Much attention is paid to… Boat Charters Oostende Boat Charters guarantees an unforgettable experience on a nearly 18-meter sailing yacht where you can take the helm yourself. Whether it's sailing trips or sea-based incentives from Ostend, we ensure a day to remember. Options are available for half or full days, as well as weekends and midweek.
… Kwist podcastwandelroute The Geuzenbos – Ostend Once upon a time in the 17th century the woodland here was a castle domain. Now, only some tree trunks indicate where the building once stood. Overview of the parkings Short-term parking Parking with a mobile home Parking counter Plan Accessible Ostend Overview of the parkings Parking Station Zee P-1 Konterdamkaai 22, 8400 Oostende Parking Station Zee P-2 Konterdamkaai 22 8400 Oostende Parking Maria Hendrikapark Free Iependreef, 8400 Oostende Parking Mariakerke beach Northlaan 13, 8400 Oostende Parking Churchill Natiënkaai 7, 8400 Oostende Sky Parking Oostende Leopold III-laan 6, 8400 Oostende Koninginnelaan Car Park Koninginnelaan 65, 8400 Oostende Parking Kaïrostraat Koninginnelaan 78 8400 Oostende Parking Oosteroever beach Free Ankerstraat Zee Car Park Leopold-II-laan, 8400 Oostende Kursaal 1 Car Park Monacoplein, 8400 Oostende Kursaal 2 Car Park Christinastraat 23F, 8400 oostende Parking Europacentre Christinastraat 18C, 8400 Oostende Mijnplein Car Park Mijnplein, 8400 Oostende Parking Zeedijk Kapucijnenstraat t.h.v. Zeedijk, 8400 Oostende Visserskaai Car Park Visserskaai 25, 8400 Oostende International Airport Car Park Nieuwpoortsesteenweg, 8400 Oostende Short-term parking on the street Parking on the public domain as a visitor The rates for short-term parking on the street depend on the zone. Discover here an overview of all zones and an overview of all parking meters . Orange zone: All days including Sundays and public holidays from 09:00 to 20:00 hrs. Maximum permitted parking time: 2 hours. Rate: 0.10 euros / 4 min 1.40 euros / 1 hour 3.50 euros / 2 hours Green zone: Every day including Sundays and public holidays from 09:00 to 20:00. Maximum permitted parking time: 4 hours Rate: 0.20 euros / 16 min 0.75 euros / 1 hour 3.00 / 4 hours Yellow zone: Every day including Sundays and public holidays from 09:00 to 20:00. Maximum permitted parking time: 11 h. Rate: 0.10 euros / 1 hour 0.50 euros / 5 hours 1.10 euros / 11 hours Seasonal Zone: Every day including Sundays and public holidays from 09:00 to 20:00. The maximum allowed parking duration and time varies per season. From 01/04 to 30/09: parking allowed for a maximum of 4 hours. Rate: 0.20 euros / 16 min 0.75 euros / 1 hour 3.00 euros / 4 hours From 01/10 to 31/03: parking allowed for a maximum of 11 hours. Rate: 0.10 euros / 1 hour 0.50 euros / 5 hours 1.10 euros / 11 hours From 1 January, the fee (penalty rate) for paid parking is 40 euros between 9 a.m. and 2 p.m. and 40 euros between 2 p.m. and 8 p.m. Pink and grey zone: In the Raversijde district, there is a pink zone. Near the Hendrik Baelskaai, there is a grey zone. In these zones, you must request your free parking session via the parking machine, unless you have a residents' card (for residents of Raversijde district). It is no longer necessary to put down your blue disc. The zones have the following provisions: In Raversijde, visitors are allowed to park for a maximum of 8 hours straight between 9 am and 8 pm. This does not apply to residents' card holders. In Hendrik Baelskaai, you may park for a maximum of 3 hours straight between 9 am and 12 pm. Attention: You can pay electronically at the parking meters with all debit and credit cards as well as contactless with your bank card. You can also use a parking application. It is no longer possible to pay in cash. Parking tickets are no longer printed. You will receive confirmation on the parking meter that you have entered all data correctly. You no longer have to return to your car to place your parking ticket behind the windscreen. It is forbidden to park your car in a car park reserved for healthcare providers . If parked incorrectly, your car will be towed away by the services. Parking info for owners of a second home Second residents can park for free for the first 30 minutes in an official parking space on the public domain. This used to be done by means of a parking token, but from 1 January 2023 this will be replaced by a one-off digital registration. Only after you have completed this registration, you can park for free for 30 minutes. This can always be done by entering your number plate via the parking meter after you have parked. Second residents have until 31 January 2023 to register via the parking counter , but can already use the 30-minute free parking via the parking meter. Parking with parking card for people with disabilities Persons with a disability who have a valid parking card can - in addition to the reserved spaces - also park for free along the public road in the places where one normally has to pay, provided a onetime registration at the parking counter. Do take into account the specified duration that applies and places that are reserved for residential parking, healthcare providers or other specific indications on site. This one-time registration of a parking card for persons with a disability should be done in the parking counter or via the digital counter . Parking with a mobile home In Ostend there are a few parking spaces for mobile homes: Randparking Mercatorlaan: 8 places Diksmuidestraat: 6 places All information about parking with a mobile home on the public domain Questions about parking? Go to the parking counter From Monday 5 December 2022, the temporary parking counter of the City of Ostend will open, located in the offices of the Economisch Huis Ostend, Gistelsesteenweg 1c, 8400 Ostend. You can also go to the digital parking counter via oostende.intouch.be/eloke t. Monday: 2 p.m. - 5 p.m Tuesday: 8.30 am - 12.30 pm Wednesday: 8.30 am - 12.30 pm Thursday: 2 p.m. - 7 p.m Friday: 8.30 am - 12.30 pm New: Plan Accessible Ostend To ensure that our beautiful city remains liveable, accessible and safe , a new plan comes into effect in the old city centre as of 8 June 2023. Two major axes divide the historic centre into four parts, thus creating 4 zones which together form the city centre. In each of these zones, the focus is placed on a liveable and accessible environment. Car drivers who want to go from one zone to another can do so via the Leopold II-laan, the Van Iseghemlaan, the Visserskaai or the Vindictivelaan. These measures will prevent unnecessary traffic by those seeking their way about, while ensuring everyone gets to their destination in the city centre in an easier and faster way. The vibrant city center has a lot to offer throughout the year, but just outside the center there are a lot of possibilities. Several cycling routes will take you to unique green spots in and around Ostend, while a (digital) walk makes you look at the city and its history in a completely different way. Ostend City Walks Discover Ostend’s most popular city walks ! Exploring with kids, following in the footsteps of James Ensor and Marvin Gaye, checking out Roblox or TikTok locations? Do you never grow tired of new experiences? This brand-new app will then be right up your alley! Discover not just one, but all Ostend city walks. No matter which tour you start, make sure you stop at every highlight you encounter and check the fascinating anecdotes, pictures, sound clips or videos. Discover all of Ostend’s secrets! Download the free app Must do: The Crystal Ship art route More than 50 renowned and world-famous artists made enormous paintings on walls as well as fantastic art installations in open spaces in Ostend. All together, this creates an artistic journey in and around Ostend. ‘The Crystal Ship - art festival in the city' is the biggest festival of its genre in Europe. Niet zomaar events. We creëren extra toerisme en beleving in en rond Oostende. Om dit allemaal mogelijk te maken, doen we beroep op enthousiaste vrijwilligers. Heb je zin om deel uit te maken van organisaties zoals Nieuwjaarsduik, The Crystal Ship, Oostende voor Anker, Ostendaise - North Sea Food Fest, Garnaalkrokettenfestival, Inpakbar, ... meld je dan aan via onderstaand formulier. Functies Algemeen medewerker - Afhankelijk van het evenement sta je in voor volgende taken: onthaal, kassa, bar, afwas, enquêtes afnemen, cadeautjes inpakken, ... Logistiek medewerker - Je helpt mee met de op- en afbouw van evenementen. - Fysiek werk schrikt je niet af. Parkeerwachter / steward - Je onthaalt de bezoekers op een vriendelijke manier en houdt toezicht op een parking of op een bepaalde locatie. - Je werkt graag in de buitenlucht. Paroles Paroles | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken Paroles Paroles Contact +32 495 57 77 37 info@parolesparoles.be parolesparoles.be Location Brandariskaai 5-7 Oostende 8400 Show location on map Opening hours Open today Open tomorrow Mon 15 Dec 2025 Closed Tue 16 Dec 2025 18:00-21:30 Wed 17 Dec 2025 18:00-21:30 Thu 18 Dec 2025 18:00-21:30 Fri 19 Dec 2025 17:45-21:30 Sat 20 Dec 2025 17:45-21:30 Sun 21 Dec 2025 Closed Facilities Free WiFi Parking Dog friendly Wheelchair accessible Payment methods: Bancontact, Cash, Rest"O"Cheques, Visa/Mastercard Share this page Facebook Twitter Since summer 2023, Paroles Paroles has been a newcomer to the Ostend hospitality scene with a mention in the H!P category of Gault&Millau. You will find this sharing restaurant, café and event café in the new SKY DISTRICT at 50m from Ostend station. The dishes, designed in the format of entremets, invite you to 'share' and allow you to put together your own unique menu. Choose a spot at the bar or one of the cosy tables where barman Matthew will spoil you with delicious wines and sophisticated cocktails, and let yourself be tempted by the flavourful dishes straight from Chef Terence McGarrity's open kitchen. Inspired by the festive atmosphere and flavours of bars in Barcelona, Berlin and Paris, they present a contemporary menu with worldly influences. At Paroles Paroles is not just about delicious food; relax on the large sun terrace with fun tapas, tasty natural wines and an inspiring beer list. For special occasions, they also offer an atmospheric event venue for up to 40 people. Photo gallery Email* EN MAIN NEWSLETTER FORM Subscribe Thank you for subscribing ! Ensor walk | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken Ensor walk Download the app and take the brand-new Ensor-themed walk to visit all the locations that were significant to the life and work of James Ensor. You will be given information and will be able to see things for yourself at each of these places, using the latest high-tech. Young and older Ensor fans will love this walk. The trip starts at the Ensor House, taking you to 13 different places. There is unique audio and visual material available for each of these places. The app is available in five languages (Dutch, French, English, German and Spanish) and can be downloaded for free from the App Store. You pay a one-off fee of 5.49 euros to unlock the entire walk. The walk is free when you visit the James Ensor House. We are currently developing a separate children's walk. Vlaanderenstraat 29, +32 59 41 89 00 All contact details This digital walk (3 km) is available via Google Play Store or in the App Store . Are shops open on Sundays? | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken Are shops open on Sundays? Yes, in Ostend you can shop when it suits you, seven days a week as most of the shops in the city centre and in Torhoutsesteenweg are also open on Sunday. Whether you need to run a quick errand or want to spend a pleasant afternoon browsing the shops, Ostend’s shopkeepers are at your service all week long, from Monday until Sunday.  An unsurpassed luxury and a facility that you won’t find in any other Flemish city. Located by the sea, it offers 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms, comfortably accommodating up to 10 guests. Everything is in place to ensure an unforgettable stay: made-up Auping boxspring beds, bath, bed and kitchen linen, complimentary coffee from Ostend's local roaster Aroma, free Harney & Sons tea, free use of 10 brand-new Dutch-style bikes, a fully equipped kitchen, wifi, Netflix, Sonos sound system, and an extra fridge stocked with soft drinks, wine, prosecco, and beer. The luxurious villa also features a south-facing garden with a small gate providing direct access to the dunes, promenade, beach, and sea. Within a 10-minute walk, a ferry takes you straight to the lively city center of Ostend. In short: Villa Plage is your guarantee for an unforgettable stay on the Belgian Coast. Well they do! Discover the brand new story trail about the history of the fort. Fort Napoleon was the setting for hundreds of years of history. The wide walls of Fort Napoleon were silent witnesses of all events in the fort. We now let them whisper their secrets in a completely new exhibition. If you stand close enough to the immense stone walls, you hear what happened in the Fort during the past 2 centuries. There is an adapted tour for children. Come and listen, enjoy the peace and be amazed by the impressive architecture of the monument. Also, there is now  a brand new tourist information point in Fort Napoleon. The staff are happy to help you with all kinds of tourist information and tickets for events and shows. Winter in Ostend | Visit Ostend Skip to main content Menu Menu Parking Webshop Accessible Ostend Search Favorites Home To see and to do Food and drinks Shopping Accommodation Practical en nl fr de Webshop Accessible Ostend Log on Search Zoeken Winter in Ostend Winter in Ostend is a magical spectacle for the whole family. It brings warmth and coziness to the cold, dark days. It’s the perfect time to enjoy culture and theater in Ostend, or to choose a winter outfit for Christmas and New Year’s. Winter activities There is plenty to do in Ostend again this winter! Visit the Christmas markets, have fun in the Christmas tree maze or go on a treasure hunt in the city. Christmas market with ice skating rink Wapenplein Fri 28 Nov 2025 to Sun 4 Jan 2026 't Ostends Kerstpling Vissersplein Thu 18 Dec 2025 to Thu 1 Jan 2026 Christmas Tree Labyrinth Fri 19 Dec 2025 to Sat 10 Jan 2026 Gift Wrapping Bar Wapenplein Sat 29 Nov 2025 to Sun 4 Jan 2026 Christmas Tree Bonfire Sat 10 Jan 2026 New Year’s Dive 2026 Drie Gapers Sat 3 Jan 2026 15:00 End-of Year Fireworks Display Groot Strand Wed 31 Dec 2025 to Thu 1 Jan 2026 Fireworks Groot Strand Sat 3 Jan 2026 18:30 The Tijdloze Tribute Festival COREtec dôme Sat 27 Dec 2025 19:30 Ice skating on Wapenplein This winter, young and old alike can once again enjoy ice skating on the skating rink on Wapenplein from 28 November to 4 January! Opening hours Monday to Thursday outside the Christmas holidays: 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Friday to Sunday and during the Christmas holidays: 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. GIFT TIP : Put skating tickets under the Christmas tree! Buy tickets Have your gifts wrapped for free Ostend is the perfect place to buy gifts for your loved ones. Shoppers can have their parcels wrapped for free at the Wrapping Bar on Wapenplein. Our wrapping specialists will wrap your Christmas gifts in unique Ensor gift wrapping paper, Ostend gift wrapping paper or Gaston de Garnaal wrapping paper. More info For families Ice skating on Wapenplein square, drinking hot chocolate at one of the Christmas markets or searching through the Christmas trees in Mariakerke. Children can enjoy themselves at the interactive exhibition in Fort Napoleon and go on a treasure hunt in the city. The Shopping Voucher is a collection of gift vouchers for not one, but for several shops in Ostend. The vouchers are valid at all participating local businesses, which include clothes shops, hairdressers, beauty salons, bike shops and more… Aantal Happy Mappy kleurplaat Oostende Deze levensgrote kleurplaat omvat alle Oostendse highlights. Op een grootte van maar liefst 69,4 cm x 100,2 cm ontdek je alle hoekjes en kantjes van de stad. Spot jij de zeehondjes, James Ensor, de surfende garnalen of die heerlijke pot mosselen? Ook onmiskenbare landmarks als de Rock… €14.5 Music record "Masqué: Songs inspired by James Ensor" Five Belgian artists were inspired by a painting from the oeuvre of James Ensor and wrote a song around it. Arno, probably the most famous of one, gave it his all and wrote both a French and West Flemish version of his song. The other artists are Isolde Lasoen, Johannes Is His Name, SJ Hoffman… Aantal Practical Information How do I get to Winter in Oostende? There are several ways to get to Winter in Oostende. We recommend using the bicycle as much as possible, as it allows you to ride almost directly to the event. Public transportation also takes you right to the doorstep of the event. By Bicycle You can make use of the 100 fixed bicycle racks spread throughout the city center or the spacious underground bicycle parking under Stationsplein. By Bus De Lijn buses will take you close to the city center. You can disembark at the Oostende Stadhuis or Oostende Marie Joséplein stops,  Oostende Centrum, Oostende Kapucijnenkerk, or Oostende Vlaanderenstraat stops. Click here for the full schedule and route planner. By Coastal Tram The Coastal Tram is the ideal means of transportation if you're coming from one of the other coastal municipalities to Winter in Oostende. Take the Marie Joséplein stop, and you'll be on Wapenplein or Groentemarkt within a few minutes. Click here for the full schedule and route planner. By Train The train station in the city center is within walking distance of the seaside promenade and shopping streets. Within 10 minutes of walking, you can reach Wapenplein or Groentemarkt. Click here for the full schedule and route planner. By Car E40 : The E40 highway connects Brussels to Oostende. In just over an hour, you can drive from Brussels to Oostende. E17 : From Antwerp, take the E17 and then the E40 towards Oostende. Click here for all parking information in Oostende. During heavy traffic, LED signs are activated upon entering Oostende, guiding you to the most accessible parking areas. Email* EN MAIN NEWSLETTER FORM Subscribe Thank you for subscribing !
